{"uri": "8184507124", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "01:54:51", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T01:54:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T01:53:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://expressdigest.com/all-the-australian-towns-where-peter-dutton-will-install-nuclear-power-plants-and-theyll-be-up-and-running-sooner-than-you-think-if-he-wins-the-election/", "title": "All the Australian towns where Peter Dutton will install nuclear power plants - and they'll be up and running sooner than you think if he wins the election", "body": "By Brittany Chain, Political Correspondent For Daily Mail Australia\n\nPeter Dutton has grand ambitions to build seven nuclear reactors across Australia - with at least two up and running by 2037.\n\nThe Opposition Leader is making his pitch to the public for Australia's nuclear future after ongoing pressure for him to release more details.\n\nLithgow and the Hunter Valley are the proposed NSW sites, Mount Murchison and Tarong in Queensland and Traralgon in Victoria. Mr Dutton proposes one site in South Australia in Port Augusta, and another in Collie in WA.\n\nCoalition MPs were briefed on the plan at 8.30am and details started to trickle out immediately afterwards, with hopes to have the first plant up and running by 2035 and the second just two years later.\n\nLabor argues Mr Dutton's plan amounts to a 'stupendous act of economic self-sabotage'.\n\nFollow Daily Mail Australia's live blog as Mr Dutton reveals new details about Australia's nuclear future - if he becomes Prime Minister at the next election.\n\nSee where Dutton intends to open seven nuclear power plants Happening now: Peter Dutton unveils vision for Australia's future if he's elected PM\n\n'We need to ensure hospitals can stay on 24/7, we need to ensure that cold rooms can stay on 24/7, we need to make sure that our economy could function 24/7 and we can only do that with a strong baseload power.\n\n'I want to make sure that the Australian public understand today that we have a vision for our country to deliver cleaner electricity, cheaper electricity and consistent electricity.\n\n'This is a plan for our country which will underpin a century of economic growth and jobs for these communities.\n\n'There is no sense of pretending that our economy can operate without the stable energy system and our plan today which will include these seven sites is integral to the energy roadmap for our country into the future.\n\n'The assets will be owned by the Commonwealth, very important point, and work with experts to deliver these programs.'\n\nMr Dutton took a swipe at the Premiers who have already announced they won't support nuclear.\n\n'We'll work with the state premiers, some debate about that I see, as you know, somebody famously said I would not stand between the Premier and a bucket of money.\n\n'We've seen the premiers in different debates before where they've been able to negotiate with the Commonwealth and will be able to address those issues.'\n\nAussie towns which could go nuclear: New details of proposal begin to trickle out\n\nIn spite of Mr Dutton's best efforts, reported details of his nuclear proposal are starting to trickle out.\n\nNSW, Victoria, Queensland, South Australia and Western Australia are all earmarked for nuclear reactor sites if the Coalition wins the next election.\n\nLithgow and the Hunter Valley are the proposed NSW sites, Mount Murchison and Tarong in Queensland and Traralgon in Victoria.\n\nMr Dutton proposes one site in South Australia in Port Augusta, and another in Collie in WA.\n\nHe hopes to have at least two up and running by 2037, with the first set to be established in 2035 - 11 years away.\n\nAll of the sites which have been identified are within Coalition-held seats.\n\nClimate groups slam Dutton's proposal\n\nClimate Council CEO Amanda McKenzie described the proposal as a 'smokescreen for its commitment to climate pollution' and a 'clear case of radioactive greenwashing'.\n\n'The winners from this scheme are the multinational coal and gas corporations who will keep polluting until well past mid-century. On the other hand, as a result of this scheme, Australians will suffer from worsening unnatural disasters due to climate pollution.\n\n'Communities are being pummelled by heatwaves and dangerous bushfires one week, and extreme rainfall and flooding the next.\n\n'Dutton's scheme is: let the climate burn, let the mega fires burn, let the sea levels rise, let the heat become unbearable.'\n\nAnd Solutions for Climate Australia director Dr Barry Traill said 'nuclear reactors are not a plan for climate, they're a fantasy that serves to delay and distract from getting on with climate action.\n\n'This shows a huge failure of leadership by Mr Dutton to come up with a plan to keep Australians safe.'\n\nDutton draws clear battle lines: Coalition vs Labor and 'green millionaires'\n\nThroughout the hour-long press conference, Mr Dutton made several references to 'Labor and those green millionaires' who stand opposed to nuclear energy.\n\nBy doing so, he drew a clear line in the sand and offered an insight into how he plans to win this battle.\n\n'There are so many people conflicted in this space because they're investors in clean energy or a particular technology. I'm agnostic to all that,' he said.\n\n'I want to deliver a system which will bring prices down and help pensioners keep their heating on. I want to keep small business alive.\n\n'I can't stand the thought that in a country with an abundance of national resource we're paying the highest electricity prices in the world.'\n\nBut Mr Dutton accused the Labor party and Greens of having ulterior motives to rejecting his proposal.\n\nHe said: 'Of course, the Labor Party and those green millionaires we were talking about before, who have made their money off the backs of electricity prices going up and people paying more - they'll come out with a scare campaign.\n\n'I want a mature conversation in our country.'\n\nAustralia is behind the rest of the world's 20 largest economies on nuclear, Dutton says\n\nMr Dutton argued that out of the world's 20 largest economies, Australia 'is the only one not using nuclear energy or moving towards it'.\n\nThe Coalition cited nuclear energy policies which are either in place or committed to in the United States, France, Canada, China, Brazil, Russia, Switzerland, Mexico, Japan, Italy, Spain and the United Kingdom.\n\nPictured: An infographic from the Coalition's new website providing information on nuclear\n\nLittleproud reassures Teal MPs and voters 'we're all on the same journey'\n\nNationals leader David Littleproud said despite the differences in opinion about Australia's energy future, the Coalition still remains committed to net zero by 2050.\n\nHe said Australia will still meet its obligations to the Paris Agreement under the Coalition's nuclear proposal, despite failing to acknowledge interim targets.\n\n'I'll just say while the ideology of our Teal members - I don't disagree.\n\n'We're all on the same journey. It's just how we get there.'\n\nDutton says he's 'happy' for next election to be a 'referendum on energy'\n\nOn the back of Labor's loss with the Indigenous Voice referendum, Mr Dutton has invoked the term during his speech.\n\nHe said: 'I'm very happy for the election to be a referendum on energy, on nuclear, on power prices, on lights going out, on who has a sustainable pathway for our country going forward.'\n\nDutton takes swipe at PM Anthony Albanese\n\n'If the Labor Party chooses a leader with back bone, somebody like Bob Hawke, as opposed to their current leader, then we'd have a mature debate about this,' he said.\n\n'But the Prime Minister wants to put out photos of fish and pictures of beaches and pretend in his nirvana that the wind turbines spin around when the wind is not blowing. And he pretends that the solar panels can work of a night time.\n\n'We need a Prime Minister who can stand up for our country. And this Prime Minister can't do that.'\n\nDutton lashes 'green millionaires'\n\n'I'm not interested in lining the pockets of rich green millionaires, I want to bring down the price of electricity for average mums and dads.\n\n'If we look at the international experience, let me answer that question because if international experience as we know, electricity is cheaper where there is a presence of nuclear energy.\n\n'That is the fact. So we can rely on the international experience.'\n\n'We are going to the next election seeking a mandate from the Australian people, a very clear mandate that we want support to modernise our energy system.\n\n'That's the mandate that we seek and that's the mandate that I believe that we will act on the Parliament and we will work with the premiers in a constructive way.'\n\nDutton grilled about cost of his plan\n\nDutton has refused to go into detail today about the cost of his proposal, arguing that today is simply about revealing the proposed locations.\n\n'As we know the government's transition [will cost] about $1.2 - $1.5 trillion and that will be passed to consumers.\n\n'Our proposal will cost a fraction of that, we will have more to say in relation to the cost in due course and as you know we've done this in a step-by-step process.\n\n'The focus today is on the sites.'\n\nBut Mr Dutton said international experience indicates that nuclear energy will always be cheaper than the alternative.\n\n'It's time for the Coalition to lead our nation away from this madness': Nationals leader David Littleproud celebrates nuclear proposal\n\nDavid Littleproud said today is a 'proud day for the Nationals', who have long championed the benefits of nuclear energy.\n\nHe said a nuclear approach moving forward is a 'win for the regions' and will be the legacy of the Coalition if they win the next election.\n\n'It's time for strength and leadership, time for the Coalition to take over to lead our nation away from this madness of renewables approach.'\n\nState premiers vow not to repeal nuclear bans\n\nBoth Chris Minns in NSW and Jacinta Allan in Victoria have this morning doubled down on their states' nuclear bans, in spite of Peter Dutton's impending announcement.\n\n'Our ban stays in place, we're not repealing it. I'd be surprised if the NSW Liberal and National party want to repeal it as well,' Mr Minns said.\n\nAnd Ms Allan was adamant there would be no nuclear sites in Victoria while she remained premier.\n\n'They want to bring more expensive, more risky, more toxic energy solutions to the people of this country. We won't stand for that. We absolutely will not stand for that,' she said.\n\n'What works is exactly what we're doing now. investing in renewable energy, solar in wind and battery storage.'\n\n'Trainwreck': Sussan Ley slams Labor's energy policy and notes 'we are paying the highest electricity prices in the world'\n\nSussan Ley appeared on Sky on Wednesday morning where she promoted the impending nuclear energy announcement.\n\n'Let's face it, policy in this country around energy under this government is an absolute trainwreck.\n\n'We are paying the highest electricity prices in the world. You've just noted on your program, that today is the coldest day so far this year.\n\n'There will be Australians who are choosing between heating and eating.'\n\nClimate warrior businessman\n\nSimon Holmes \u00e0 Court's blunt questions he says Dutton must answer about nuclear\n\nClimate warrior Simon Holmes \u00e0 Court has issued a series of 18 questions he says Mr Dutton must answer if he wants the Australian public to support nuclear energy.\n\nMr Holmes \u00e0 Court has a \u00adClimate 200 fund which backed the 'Teal' independents in the last election - many of whom snatched previously safe Liberal seats in affluent parts of Sydney.\n\n- Where nuclear reactors will be located\n\n- How the Coalition intends to remove state bans given nuclear is currently banned in Victoria, NSW and Queensland\n\n- What will happen if locals object\n\n- When will the reactors begin generating power\n\n- How much will they cost\n\n- How will the waste be managed\n\n- Who will provide disaster insurance\n\n- What will be the emissions impact\n\nHe said: 'Without good answers to the questions above, the Coalition cannot be taken seriously.\n\n'Any plan that has us paying more and blowing our carbon budget is a toxic joke.'\n\nAnnouncement to be made at 10am\n\nPeter Dutton will hold a joint press conference at 10am to make his pitch to the Australian public.\n\nIt is understood he'll be joined by Nationals leader David Littleproud, and Liberal deputy leader Sussan Ley.\n\nLabor comes out swinging against nuclear\n\nTreasurer Jim Chalmers on Wednesday trashed Mr Dutton's nuclear ambitions, describing it as 'economic insanity, pure and simple'.\n\nDr Chalmers told ABC Radio: 'Nuclear takes longer, it costs more, and it will squander Australia's unique combination of advantages. It is the worst combination of economic and ideological stupidity.'\n\nKey Updates Dutton draws clear battle lines: Coalition vs Labor and 'green millionaires'\n\nView post\n\nAustralia is behind the rest of the world's 20 largest economies on nuclear, Dutton says\n\nView post\n\nDutton says he's 'happy' for next election to be a 'referendum on energy'\n\nView post\n\nDutton lashes 'green millionaires'\n\nView post\n\nHappening now: Peter Dutton unveils vision for Australia's future if he's elected PM\n\nView post\n\nState premiers vow not to repeal nuclear bans\n\nView post\n\nAussie towns which could go nuclear: New details of proposal begin to trickle out\n\nView post", "source": {"uri": "expressdigest.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "expressdigest.com"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8184600022", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "03:50:40", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T03:50:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T03:49:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.sustainabilitymatters.net.au/content/energy/news/australia-s-nuclear-future-or-fantasy--705202703", "title": "Australia's nuclear future or fantasy?", "body": "The Federal Coalition has today (19 June 2024) released details on its vision for nuclear energy in Australia.\n\nOpposition Leader Peter Dutton said a future Coalition government will introduce zero-emissions nuclear energy in Australia to work in partnership with renewable energy and gas as part of a balanced energy mix.\n\nThe Coalition's plan named seven locations for proposed nuclear power plants:\n\nDutton said each of these locations have technical attributes that make them suitable for a nuclear plant, including cooling water capacity and transmission infrastructure, existing poles and wires, and a local skilled workforce.\n\n\"A key advantage of modern zero-emissions nuclear plants is they can be plugged into existing grids. This means they can effectively replace retired or retiring coal plants and avoid much of the new spending needed for Labor's 'renewables-only' system, including new transmission poles and wires,\" Dutton said in his statement.\n\nAccording to the plan, if elected, the Coalition government would initially develop two establishment projects using either small modular reactors or modern larger plants such as the AP1000 or APR1400. \"They will start producing electricity by 2035 (with small modular reactors) or 2037 (if modern larger plants are found to be the best option),\" Dutton said.\n\nDutton said he is expecting scare campaigns opposing nuclear, but \"we believe Australians are up for this discussion and are open-minded about including zero-emissions nuclear technology as part of a balanced energy mix\".\n\nThe GenCost economic report released by CSIRO in May included nuclear costs for the first time. While the report found no technical barriers to large-scale nuclear power generation in Australia's electricity system, it determined that nuclear power was more expensive than renewables and would take at least 15 years to develop, including construction.\n\nSo what do mining, climate and engineering academia representatives think of the Coalition's nuclear plan?\n\nThe Mining and Energy Union said the proposed plan would be no help for coal power workers and it was \"disappointed the Coalition has announced this policy with no consultation with these coal power regions about whether they want a nuclear future\".\n\n\"Power stations in the proposed sites for nuclear would be long closed before the plants would become operational, and if no support is provided, those workers and communities will have already packed up their lives and moved on,\" the union said.\n\nSolutions for Climate Australia Director Dr Barry Traill views this announcement as a dangerous distraction from the urgent need to take action to reduce climate pollution this decade.\n\n\"Nuclear reactors are the most expensive energy source for Australia, produce toxic waste and would take literally decades to build, during which coal and gas giants would continue to produce billions of tonnes of additional climate emissions,\" Traill said.\n\n\"Our recent report showed that conservatively at least 2.3 billion tonnes of additional climate pollution would be released if this nuclear reactor fantasy was pursued.\"\n\nDr Asma Aziz, senior lecturer in power engineering from the School of Engineering at Edith Cowan University, said Australia needs diverse generation and storage but also requires proper assessments before making any decisions.\n\n\"Nuclear energy's carbon footprint is comparable to wind and less than solar, but it faces high capital costs, long build times, substantial operating expenses and integration difficulties, making it impractical for addressing the climate crisis,\" Aziz said. \"Integrating nuclear power plants (NPPs) into the grid involves complex regulatory and engineering challenges due to their constant 'baseload' supply, which requires other plants to be load following'.\n\n\"Other major drawbacks include safety concerns, high costs and long-term radioactive waste storage. Japan, Germany, Belgium, Spain and Switzerland are phasing out nuclear power due to these issues. In the USA, aging reactors are being retired early due to high costs. France's reactor in Flamanville is significantly delayed and over budget. Small modular reactors (SMRs) are not yet viable, with recent cost estimates at $20,100 per kW compared to $700-$1700 for solar and wind.\"", "source": {"uri": "sustainabilitymatters.net.au", "Belgium"}}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Business/Energy", "label": "dmoz/Business/Energy", "wgt": 23}, {"uri": "dmoz/Science/Technology/Energy", "label": "dmoz/Science/Technology/Energy", "wgt": 37}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Environment", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Environment", "wgt": 23}, {"uri": "dmoz/Science/Physics/Nuclear", "label": "dmoz/Science/Physics/Nuclear", "wgt": 33}, {"uri": "dmoz/Health/Pharmacy/Nuclear_Pharmacy", "label": "dmoz/Health/Pharmacy/Nuclear Pharmacy", "wgt": 27}, {"uri": "news/Business", "label": "news/Business", "wgt": 77}], "image": "https://d1v1e13ebw3o15.cloudfront.net/data/83548/pool_and_spa_master/..jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9662030", "eventUri": "eng-9662030", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, {"uri": "8186076858", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "23:40:37", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T23:40:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T23:39:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.crikey.com.au/2024/06/20/journalists-must-interrogate-peter-dutton-nuclear-plan/", "title": "Journalists who fail to interrogate Dutton's nuclear dream should resign", "body": "There is no credible nuclear plan, and journalists reporting the announcement seriously are misleading the public.\n\nIf a journalist's basic job is to report the news and assess the veracity of facts and claims, then the journalists reporting Peter Dutton's nuclear dream as if it's a real policy should reconsider their professional calling. They're not fit to cover the local flower show, let alone federal politics.\n\nDutton's press conference yesterday purported to announce \"details\" of his \"plan\" to build seven nuclear power plants across Australia. It provided none of these things. He named seven supposed sites and said that the Australian government would own the theoretical nuclear power plants.\n\nTwo of them would be built by 2035, apparently, although the AFR's Phil Coorey promptly reported this on X as \"Seven nuclear plants operating from 2035\". Simon Benson at The Australian was immediately proclaiming Dutton had \"reshaped the election and the path to net zero\" with his bold plan, with News Corp colleagues already touting \"growing optimism in the Coalition ranks\" due to the opposition leader's \"nuclear-framed energy and climate policy\". The ABC news homepage reported that \"Nuclear power plants would be built at seven locations in five states under the opposition's nuclear policy, opposition leader Peter Dutton has confirmed.\" Will they really? Has he really?\n\nDutton's press conference was farcical. He provided no costings, no plan for the nuclear waste involved, no detail on what specific type of nuclear reactors would be built, nor how much power they would generate, nor how they will be budgeted or financed. His team hasn't done any community consultations in the areas named, and would need to change a raft of laws and regulations to begin planning these mythical reactors. Environmental approvals? What are they? Dutton acknowledged that the states' cooperation would be required, yet leaders in key states including Victoria, New South Wales, Western Australia and Queensland immediately came out against his plan.\n\nDutton proposes \"small modular reactors\" for Australia. Fun fact: no small modular reactors currently operate commercially anywhere in the world. Only two currently exist -- in China and Russia. The latter took two decades to construct, and neither are prototypes for more models because there is no current market for such things. They're even more expensive than conventional nuclear reactors. Is Dutton planning to source nuclear tech from China or Russia?\n\nEven conventional nuclear power, on best current estimates, costs between four and six times solar and wind power. Have these journalists had some kind of collective seizure that makes them suddenly believe in expensive energy, in \"picking winners\", in giant, open-ended public spending on unproven technology, on unlegislated white-rabbit schemes requiring (but not having) broad public and political support? Or is now not a good time to mention these objections?\n\nThe sites Dutton named would need to be acquired, in some cases from private companies, and in others from planned or existing ventures. The man who isn't even in government is going to oversee the introduction of an entirely new industry in Australia, create the (as yet non-existent) local professional expertise, then contract secure and competent construction companies, consult with the community and other stakeholders, finance, legislate, build and operate new plants within 10 and a half years. (For what it's worth, the CSIRO estimates that nuclear couldn't be deployed before 2040.)\n\nIn its recent nine years of government, the Coalition couldn't even build the carparks it promised, let alone complex projects like fast rail or Snowy 2.0. If News Corp journalists in particular were honest, they'd hound Dutton more than they ever hounded Kevin Rudd over the NBN, which was the picture of fiscal rectitude in comparison. They won't, of course.\n\nHere are some questions that Dutton must be asked, and must answer, if he's to be taken seriously: How would his government overcome the state bans on nuclear power? How would he get Senate support for legislative change, given it's been almost two decades since the Coalition had Senate control, and the Greens, Labor and most independents don't support nuclear? What does the staged timeline look like? What will the reactors cost? Were will the money come from? Who would buy more expensive power anyway? Who will insure such a venture? How can a decades-long project be responsibly mounted without bipartisan support -- or does he expect the Coalition to be in power from next year until beyond 2040? How can he seriously argue that it's irresponsible to have even short-term climate targets, and then go all-in on an uncosted nuclear fantasy?\n\nApart from anything else, why would a government \"cap\" investment in renewables (as the Coalition promised this week) while spending vastly more on something unproven, unsafe, uninsurable and toxic? Why would a nation already blessed with cheap, sustainable renewable energy sources embark on something so ludicrous?\n\nWe won't, of course, and that's the nub of the issue.\n\nThese nuclear plants will never be built, and everyone knows it. The point of the exercise is for Dutton to present himself as a man with a \"strong plan\", a \"visionary policy\" to talk about so he can avoid the fact that he has no climate policy -- and in fact not many policies at all. (The other tragic aspect of this game is that Labor will see a policy platform even worse than its own pro-gas vandalism, and present itself as the responsible option by comparison. Thankfully the public has better climate choices.)\n\nThere is no nuclear plan, and journalists reporting the announcement seriously are participants in the charade. They're misleading the public.\n\nHow can journalists do a better job covering Peter Dutton's nuclear plan? Let us know your thoughts by writing to letters@crikey.com.au. Please include your full name to be considered for publication. "https://www.crikey.com.au/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/20240611166026586695-original.jpg?quality=70", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9662030", "eventUri": "eng-9662030", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.0117647058823529, "wgt": 188, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8184504602", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "01:50:44", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T01:50:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T01:49:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.crikey.com.au/2024/06/19/peter-dutton-nuclear-power-plan-locations-cost/", "title": "Big-government Dutton STILL can't say how he will build seven nuclear reactors", "body": "Peter Dutton has unveiled his plan for seven nuclear reactors in Australia. But he can't say how he'll build them, or how much it will cost.\n\nDespite Peter Dutton this morning unveiling \"details\" of his plan to build a fleet of nuclear power plants across the country by 2040, we're still no closer to understanding exactly how the Liberal leader will achieve such an improbable feat.\n\nDutton has committed the Coalition to building seven reactors on the sites of coal-fired power stations: two in Queensland, at Tarong and Callide, two in NSW, at Liddell and Lithgow, one at Port Augusta in SA, one at the current Loy Yang A site in the Latrobe Valley in Victoria, and one at Muja in south-western WA.\n\nThere is a little detail in the timing. The glossy brochure handed out by the Coalition claims \"the timeline for establishing a civil nuclear program in Australia including building two establishment projects is 10 to 12 years from the government making a decision until zero emissions nuclear electricity first enters the grid.\"\n\nSeparately, it also states \"a federal Coalition government will initially develop two establishment projects using either small modular reactors or modern larger plants such as the AP1000 or APR1400. They will start producing electricity by 2035 (with small modular reactors) or 2037 (if modern larger plants are found to be the best option).\"\n\nThat timeline is at odds with the CSIRO's estimate that nuclear could not be deployed until 2040 at the earliest. There are no small modular reactors currently in operation in any developed country, and the US project touted by the Coalition, NuScale in Idaho, was shut down in November due to soaring costs.\n\nAccording to the CSIRO's costings, seven reactors at $8.6 billion each for a 1000MW reactor, would cost $60.2 billion, however the first build would suffer a first of a kind premium of up to 100% in addition to that. That does not include a cost blow-out of 20-30% of a kind that has characterised nearly all major infrastructure projects in Australia over the past two decades.\n\nAccording to the CSIRO, small modular reactors will cost two to three-and-a-half times more than large-scale nuclear plants per unit of output.\n\nDutton has also confirmed what Crikey has long pointed out -- the reactors will have to be publicly owned, meaning taxpayers will fund the $60-90 billion cost.\n\n\"The Australian government will own these assets, but form partnerships with experienced nuclear companies to build and operate them,\" Dutton said this morning.\n\nThis reduces, but does not remove, one of the key impediments to any nuclear build -- that companies will refuse to invest in their construction because of a potential change in government, with a new government restoring a nuclear ban. The Coalition would likely offer onerous break fees as part of any deal with companies interested in building reactors, in order to deter future governments from halting construction.\n\nIt will also mean the Commonwealth will enter the power generation industry at a truly colossal scale, far beyond what any state government has ever managed. Dutton has made a commitment to a radical expansion in the size and role of the federal government.\n\nHowever, there remains the biggest hurdle of all: state governments. The Coalition might be able to purchase existing sites from private companies to build the reactors -- though not in Queensland, where Callide and Tarong are government-owned. But it will not be able to build reactors without state cooperation, including the repeal of state prohibitions on nuclear power. Dutton joked this morning about premiers and buckets of money, but his chances of convincing Labor governments in NSW, Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia to allow nuclear power plants appear slim.\n\nDutton may have more luck in Queensland, with his own party, the Liberal Nationals, set to take power in October. However, state LNP leader David Crisafulli appeared to kill that off this week, saying when asked about repealing Queensland's ban on nuclear power \"the answer is no, and I've made my view very clear on that.\"\n\nCrisafulli is likely to come under more pressure between now and the state election to categorically rule out cooperating with Dutton.\n\nDutton has refused to offer any costing of his plan, but Crikey's CSIRO-based costing this week -- just over $70 billion for six (not seven) large-scale nuclear power plants by 2040 -- now looks too modest: the addition of small modular reactors will increase the cost, and the extremely rapid timeframe for deployment will likely require greater expenditure.\n\nAnd if Dutton really thinks he can bribe Labor premiers to open themselves up to a world of political hurt by agreeing to nuclear power plants, he will need a very large bucket of money indeed. That doesn't feature in the costings -- and will likely be in the billions as well.\n\nMore realistically, it's all intended as a distraction from abandoning climate action and maintaining fossil fuel-based power. Dutton and his colleagues were in power for nine years and never expressed the slightest interest in pursuing nuclear power -- or even removing the Howard government's ban on it. There's a reason for that -- in Australia, it's a ludicrously expensive fantasy.\n\nDo you back Dutton's nuclear plan? How would you feel about a nuclear power plant near your home? Let us know your thoughts by writing to letters@crikey.com.au. Please include your full name to be considered for publication. "news/Business", "label": "news/Business", "wgt": 70}], "image": "https://www.crikey.com.au/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/20240619147301794307-original-copy.jpg?quality=70", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9662030", "eventUri": "eng-9662030", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.05882352941176472, "wgt": 188, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8184587759", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "03:36:51", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T03:36:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T03:36:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "http://theconversation.com/peter-dutton-has-promised-to-solve-our-energy-problems-but-his-nuclear-policy-still-leaves-australians-in-the-dark-232816", "title": "Peter Dutton has promised to solve our energy problems - but his nuclear policy still leaves Australians in the dark", "body": "University of Queensland provides funding as a member of The Conversation AU.\n\nIn 1971 on a family holiday, my father drove us to look at a huge concrete slab at Jervis Bay, on the South Coast of New South Wales. Still visible today, it was the foundation for what would have been Australia's first nuclear power plant. The project had just been cancelled by then-prime minister Billy McMahon who had recently replaced John Gorton. A Treasury analysis showed coal-fired power was much cheaper.\n\nThat long-ago episode is still relevant to Australia's policy choices. Today, Opposition leader Peter Dutton revealed seven sites across Australia where the Coalition, if elected, would build nuclear power stations. Unsurprisingly, the plan has already run into opposition from state politicians, both Labor and the LNP.\n\nThe announcement answers a few basic questions about the Coalition's nuclear plans. For example, Dutton said the plants would be Commonwealth-owned, and built at the site of decommissioned coal plants. But central issues remain unaddressed. Exactly what kind of reactors will be built? Who will build them? And how much they will cost?\n\nAs the Jervis Bay experience shows, nuclear energy can be a hard sell in Australia. Times have obviously changed since the 1970s, but significant political and economic barriers remain - and the problem of cost is still unsolved.\n\nWhat the Coalition has revealed\n\nThe seven sites for nuclear power plants mooted by the Coalition are:\n\nTarong and Callide in Queensland Liddell and Mount Piper in NSW Port Augusta in South Australia Loy Yang in Victoria Muja in Western Australia.\n\nAt a press conference in Sydney, Dutton said:\n\nWe know the government has [a] renewables only policy which is not fit for purpose. No other country in the world can keep the lights on 24/7 with the renewables only policy.\n\nWe want to utilise existing assets that we have got [...] new poles and wires that are used at the moment on the coal-fired power station sites can be utilised to distribute the energy generated from the latest generation nuclear reactors.\n\nUnder the Coalition plan, the federal government would own and pay for the plants. In this respect, Dutton is following the precedent set by the Snowy Scheme - and more recently, by the National Broadband Network.\n\nThis is a welcome acknowledgement of the reality that, whatever technology we adopt, private investment is likely insufficient to manage the transition away from coal and gas in the electricity sector - let alone the massive electrification in other sectors needed to meet Australia's 2050 targets.\n\nDutton says he remains committed to the 2050 target for now, despite flagging the Coalition will abandon Australia's 2030 emissions goal.\n\nThe Coalition says it will develop two \"establishment projects\" using either small modular reactors or larger plants. It claims the small reactors will start producing electricity by 2035, and the larger plants by 2037.\n\nThese timeframes are at odds with analysis by the CSIRO, which recently found reactors could not be operational in Australia until the 2040 at the earliest.\n\nThe same report found construction of a large-scale nuclear power facility would cost at least A$8.6 billion, and possibly up to $17 billion. It said the electricity produced would be about 50% more costly than renewable energy.\n\nOn Wednesday, Dutton refused to provide a price tag for the Coalition policy. But he claimed it would be a \"fraction\" of Labor's renewable energy policy.\n\nLessons from Jervis Bay\n\nDutton this week ruled out Jervis Bay as a nuclear reactor location, should the Coalition win the next federal election. But the 1970s experience still holds valuable lessons.\n\nThe Jervis Bay territory was ruled directly by the federal government - circumventing any potential state opposition. The Coalition faces a different battle with regards to its proposed sites.\n\nQueensland LNP Leader David Crisafulli on Wednesday said he did not support Dutton's plan for a nuclear power station in Central Queensland, and has previously ruled out lifting a state ban on nuclear power if elected in October.\n\nNSW Labor Premier Chris Minns says building a nuclear reactor in the Hunter Valley is impossible under existing laws, and would disrupt the renewable energy transition.\n\nDutton pledged to work with state premiers to resolve such issues, and suggested financial incentives would be offered.\n\nIt's unclear whether existing coal plant owners, including state-owned generators, will be willing to sell the sites to the federal government. However, Dutton said on Wednesday that, according to legal advice, the government could compulsorily acquire the sites if needed.\n\nWhen Jervis Bay was on the table as a nuclear site, there was no question the federal government would build, own and operate it. The idea that something as crucial as a nuclear power plant might be entrusted to a state government, let alone a foreign corporation, was never entertained.\n\nThe national government was at the postwar height of its power and confidence. It employed the best and brightest, and was expanding the scope and scale of its activity. The Snowy Mountains Scheme, a massive engineering endeavour built under the Commonwealth's defence power, was nearing completion.\n\nDutton says the government will own the proposed nuclear plants, but form partnerships with nuclear companies to build and operate them. But which companies?\n\nInternationally, about 60 nuclear plants are under construction, mostly in Asia. The vast majority are Chinese and Russian designs, built by Chinese and Russian firms. Presumably, for national security reasons, that is not an option for Australia.\n\nThe only real contenders for large modern projects in Australia are South Korea's KEPCO, and Electricity de France (EDF).\n\nKEPCO built four plants at Barakah, in the United Arab Emirates, between 2009 and 2024. But no new orders for KEPCO plants outside South Korea have been announced since 2009.\n\nEDF is building a reactor at Flamanville in France and two at Hinkley Point in the United Kingdom. The projects have suffered massive delays and cost overruns. The UK government is also struggling to organise finance for an additional EDF reactor proposed at the existing Sizewell plant.\n\nAnd what about the so-called small modular reactors suggested by Dutton? This term is applied to two types of technology.\n\nFirst, there are reactors of less than 100 megawatt capacity, which would be built in a factory and shipped to the required site where they would be installed as individual modules.\n\nThe most promising contender was the NuScale Voygr design, however its pilot project has been abandoned. Similarly, Rolls Royce has spiked its plans for a factory in Wales that would have progressed technology used in small modular reactors.\n\nThe term is also applied to cut-down versions of existing large-scale designs: reactors of 300 to 500 megawatt capacity compared to the traditional 1,000 to 1,500 megawatts. These are \"modular\" only in the sense that most parts are built in factories and assembled onsite.\n\nThe government of Ontario in Canada has announced plans for four such reactors to be built by GE-Hitachi, but no final commitment has been made.\n\nMeanwhile, the climate crisis continues\n\nAs the next federal election rolls closer, Dutton will come under pressure to reveal crucial details underpinning the Coalition's nuclear plan - most importantly, how much it will cost.\n\nNothing announced by Dutton today changes the fact that nuclear energy is, according to reams of expert analysis, economically unfeasible in Australia. This is as true today as it was in the 1970s.\n\nMeanwhile, the climate crisis continues to worsen. Solar panels, wind turbines and energy storage must be rolled out as rapidly as possible - and we must not allow Dutton's policy detour to distract from the task.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8184569667", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "03:16:47", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T03:16:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T03:15:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "http://theconversation.com/dutton-goes-nuclear-proposing-seven-government-owned-generators-with-the-first-starting-in-2030s-232815", "title": "Dutton goes nuclear, proposing seven government-owned generators with the first starting in 2030s", "body": "University of Canberra provides funding as a member of The Conversation AU.\n\nOpposition leader Peter Dutton has announced seven sites for reactors, unveiling his long-awaited and highly-controversial policy for nuclear power with the claim it could start operating from the 2030s.\n\nThe locations are the sites of former or current coal plants. They have the technical attributes needed for a nuclear plant, including transmission infrastructure, cooling water capacity and a skilled workforce, the opposition policy says.\n\nThe program would consist of two phases, starting with two establishment projects in the mid-2030s followed by a build of others through to 2050.\n\nMost sites would have larger reactors, with two - in South Australia and Western Australia - having small modular reactors. All mainland states would eventually have reactors.\n\nThe proposed sites are\n\nLiddell Power Station, New South Wales\n\nMount Piper Power Station, New South Wales\n\nLoy Yang Power Stations, Victoria\n\nTarong Power Station, Queensland\n\nCallide Power Station, Queensland\n\nNorthern Power Station, South Australia (small modular reactor only)\n\nMuja Power Station, Western Australia (small modular reactor only)\n\nDutton said the generators would be owned by the Commonwealth government.\n\nThe first could begin operating in 2035 if small modular reactors are used, or 2037 \"if modern larger plants are found to be the best option\", the opposition says.\n\nThis is much earlier than the CSIRO has estimated that an initial plant could begin.\n\nThe CSIRO said in its May assessment of generation technology costs for Australia, that \"due to the current state of the development pipeline in Australia, that the earliest deployment would be from 2040\".\n\nDutton said he would be \"very happy for the election to be a referendum on energy, on nuclear, on power prices, on lights going out, on who has a sustainable pathway for our country going forward\".\n\n\"We are going to the next election seeking a mandate from the Australian people, a very clear mandate that we want support to modernise our energy system ... which is about economic growth and jobs for decades and generations to come,\" Dutton said. said.\n\nThe opposition says the timeline for nuclear energy including building two establishment projects is ten to 12 years, \"from the government making a decision until zero-emissions nuclear electricity first enters the grid\".\n\nThe Coalition policy says a key advantage of the nuclear energy plants was they could be plugged into existing grids. \"This means they can effectively replace retired or retiring coal plants and avoid much of the new spending needed for Labor's 'renewables-only' system, including new transmission poles and wires.\"\n\nThe government would partner with nuclear companies from aboard on development and operation.\n\nEach community around a site would receive a benefits package enshrined in legislation.\n\nIt would include:\n\nmulti-billion dollar facility guaranteeing high-paying jobs for generations to come\n\nan integrated economic development zone attracting manufacturing, value-add and high-tech industry\n\na regional deal unlocking investment in modern infrastructure, services and community priorities.\n\nEstablishing a civil nuclear programme would require an expanded Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency to license and regulate the power stations, a Nuclear Energy Coordinating Authority, and a government business enterprise to be called Affordable Energy Australia.\n\nDutton could not give a cost for the nuclear plan, saying only it would be \"a fraction\" of the government's energy transition plan costing $1.2 trillion to $1.5 trillion. He said the opposition would have more to say on cost \"in due course\".\n\nThe opposition leader announced his plan at a news conference in Sydney, after a pre-budget announcement had been deferred. He was flanked by a bevy of colleagues including Nationals leader David Littleproud.\n\nTreasurer Jim Chalmers said in a social media post: \"With Australia's advantages and opportunities, nothing could be more economically irrational or fiscally irresponsible\" than the nuclear policy\".\n\nChalmers told the ABC: \"Peter Dutton's nuclear negativity is economic insanity, pure and simple. Nuclear takes longer, it costs more and it will squander Australia's unique combination of advantages\".\n\nApart from a fierce campaign from federal Labor, Dutton faces attacks from the states. His plan is opposed by the Liberal-National opposition in Queensland where there is a state election within months.", "source": {"uri": "theconversation.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The {"uri": "8183828482", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "15:03:14", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T15:03:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T15:01:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/environment/article/2024/jun/19/queensland-could-be-nuclear-hub-under-coalitions-new-energy-plan", "title": "Queensland could be nuclear hub under Coalition's new energy plan", "body": "State's existing coal-fired power plant sites being considered, along with NSW's Hunter Valley, South Australia's Port Augusta\n\nQueensland is emerging as the nuclear capital under the Coalition's proposed energy plan, with speculation it could be home to up to two reactors in the opposition's energy plan.\n\nCoalition MPs will learn of their party's nuclear plans almost at the same time as voters, as Peter Dutton tried to contain leaks of one of his signature election policies.\n\nThe plan, which went to shadow cabinet overnight and will be presented to a joint party room teleconference at 8.30am on Wednesday, has been kept under wraps, with most backbenchers caught by surprise by the snap announcement.\n\nGuardian Australia understands Queensland will play a major role as a nuclear site, with existing power sites at Tarong in Nanango, and Gladstone under consideration.\n\nSuch a move would pit the federal Coalition against the state LNP just months out from the Queensland election. David Crisafulli, the LNP state leader, said on Tuesday he would not repeal the state's nuclear ban if elected and nuclear was \"not on our plan, not on our agenda\".\n\nOther areas raised as potential sites included Port Augusta in South Australia, Collie, south of Perth, the Hunter Valley and Mt Piper in New South Wales, and the Latrobe Valley in Victoria.\n\nThe Australian newspaper reported the reactors would be Commonwealth owned, in a similar structure to the Snowy Hydro 2.0 scheme.\n\nDutton and the Coalition leadership were hoping to capitalise on strong showings in recent opinion polls, which showed voters viewed nuclear power favourably as part of Australia's energy mix.\n\nDutton had previously said the Coalition would only be looking at sites where there was already an \"end-of-life coal fired power station\".\n\nBut some critics questioned whether \"anyone had looked at a map\" when choosing sites, noting there were different requirements for a coal-fired power station and even a small nuclear plant.\n\n\"I don't know how seriously they will have looked at some of these sites,\" one Coalition MP said, under the condition of anonymity.\n\nWater was one of the key issues, given its use in cooling, meaning any potential plant would be best situated along the coast or near a large body of water. Geographic faultlines were also a consideration - central Queensland, where much of Queensland's existing coal-fired power stations are situated has several faultlines recorded by Geoscience Australia, an issue given the stability needed for a nuclear plant.\n\nThere was also the question of where Australia would store the waste.\n\nDutton has said the Coalition's nuclear plan is required to deal with ageing and retiring coal power plants.\n\nThe Australian Conservation Foundation (ACF), in a Wednesday report assessing the Coalition's plans, found the plan to install nuclear power plants around the country would require billions of dollars in government subsidies.\n\nWhile the cost of other energy technologies had decreased over time, the report found nuclear costs had increased because of safety improvements and persistent flaws in management, design, and supply chains, citing a 2020 MIT study.\n\nThe ACF's report, co-authored by anti-nuclear campaigners Dr Jim Green and Dave Sweeney, also concluded additional taxpayer subsidies would be needed to cover insurance for nuclear accidents or incidents.\n\nSome of Australia's major insurers, such as AAMI, CGU, Allianz, QBE and NRMA, also won't insure homes, cars or possessions against a nuclear accident, the report said.\n\nCost blowouts and multi-year delays experienced by the US, the UK and Europe are also likely to occur in Australia, the report found. A number of projects around the world reached commercial operation about two decades after being announced.\n\nAccording to the report's findings, a nuclear power reactor in Australia could only begin operating in about the mid-2040s, if a federal ban on nuclear power was overturned, and would only begin to contribute to emissions reductions by around 2050.\n\nThe ACF's chief executive, Kelly O'Shanassy, said promoting nuclear was prolonging the use of fossil fuels.\n\n\"Major solar and wind projects can be conceived, constructed and connected much quicker,\" she said.\n\n\"Nuclear is an energy source the market doesn't want. The big electricity utilities are not interested, nor are most private investors, so nuclear would require huge public subsidies.\n\n\"We cannot afford to squander more time in moving our economy away from its reliance on climate-damaging coal and gas. Nuclear is a dangerous distraction to effective climate action.\"\n\nThe Albanese government on Wednesday announced it was investing up to $100m in grant funding to lower deployment and operation costs for Australia's solar industry.\n\nThe \"international challenge\", which is open for eight weeks, will invite innovators, customers, financiers and those in construction, operation or maintenance to pitch ideas aimed at slashing the costs of a solar project installation to 30 cents per watt and to reduce electricity costs to below $20 per megawatt hour by 2030.\n\nThe climate change and energy minister, Chris Bowen, said the modern solar panel was, in effect, an Australian invention and he wanted to see more breakthroughs locally.\n\n\"The world added 445 gigawatts of solar [power] last year, more than all other power sources combined, because the world is rapidly moving to renewable energy, the cheapest form of energy,\" he said.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-394442289", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "09:02:04", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T09:02:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T08:18:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.ibtimes.com.au/coalition-proposes-7-nuclear-power-sites-albanese-calls-it-oppositions-fantasy-1848747", "title": "Coalition Proposes 7 Nuclear Power Sites, Albanese Calls It Opposition's 'Fantasy'", "body": "Coalition leader Peter Dutton proposed seven sites across Australia to set up nuclear power plants by 2035-2040, which would be owned by the federal government.\n\nThe sites where the nuclear power plants would be built are Tarong and Callide in Queensland, Mount Piper and Liddell in New South Wales, Collie in Western Australia, Loy Yang in Victoria, and the Northern power station in South Australia, The Guardian reported.\n\nDutton stressed that the seven plants would be built and owned by the government, but avoided answering how much the Australian taxpayer would have to shell out. Instead, he said it would \"cost a fraction\" of Labor's power plans, adding that the cost would be released \"in due course.\"\n\nBlasting the opposition's \"nuclear fantasy,\" Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said it did not make economic sense as Australia had the best \"renewable energy potential,\" AAP reported.\n\n\"It'll be a taxpayer funded nuclear fantasy,\" Albanese told ABC radio. \"Here in Australia, we have the best solar resources in the world. \"This makes no economic sense, as well as leaving us in a position of energy insecurity because of the time that it will take to roll out a nuclear reactor.\"\n\nThe sites located in Coalition-held electorates have been chosen for water availability, connection to the grid and the closure date of existing coal power plants. As the sites were held by private ownership now, Dutton said they would be acquired by the government for setting up the power plants.\n\nOn the energy sources during the interim period while the construction of nuclear power plants is in progress, Dutton said, \"The seven locations can host new nuclear sites and that'll be part of an energy mix with renewables and significant amounts of gas ... particularly in the interim period. During the construction of nuclear power plants, would utilize the existing distribution networks when coal power plants reach the end of their life.\"\n\nThe Opposition leader said two plants would be completed by 2035-37 and the remaining five would be built in the 2040s were \"achievable\" and a \"sensible rollout.\"\n\nPower stations suggested to be built in Western and South Australia could be \"small modular reactor (SMR) only,\" and they are reportedly not commercially viable.\n\nCSIRO had warned against completing an SMR as quickly as 2038. Though cheaper and quicker to build, no SMR projects have been completed globally yet.\n\nDutton will have to counter a long battle on his plans to go nuclear, as it means lifting current bans on the energy source and confronting the states, because several politicians have refused to permit atomic plants in their jurisdictions.\n\nNSW Premier Chris Minns and leader of the Queensland Liberal National party David Crisafulli stated they would not repeal the nuclear prohibition in their states.\n\n\"If all of a sudden you were to introduce nuclear power, that investment is at real risk,\" Minns told reporters. \"It costs a lot of money and second, it takes a lot of time and we don't have a day to wait.\"\n\nIn May, CSIRO and the Australian Energy Market Operator released the GenCost report, which put the cost of building a large-scale nuclear power plant to be at least $8.5 billion.", "source": {"uri": "ibtimes.com.au", "dataType": "news", "title": "International Business Times "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/aap/article-13545745/Dutton-goes-nuclear-bid-blow-open-election-race.html", "title": "Dutton goes nuclear in bid to blow open election race", "body": "The coalition has lifted the lid on its nuclear plans, presenting a list of potential sites for power stations in a move that could make or break its electoral campaign.\n\nWith tens of thousands of Australians learning they could be living next to a nuclear reactor, a chorus of opposition grew on social media and talkback radio while Labor came out swinging on the \"economic insanity\" of the move.\n\nOpposition Leader Peter Dutton's much-anticipated energy policy will place nuclear power plants in Australia's former fossil-fuel heartlands if the coalition wins the federal election.\n\nHe said a coalition government would build seven plants at existing coal-fired power stations, with the assets to be owned by the Commonwealth.\n\nNo costings were provided for the policy even as Mr Dutton said consumers and business were suffering from high energy costs.\n\nThe sites include Loy Yang Power Station in Victoria's Gippsland area, Callide and Tarong in Queensland, Mount Piper at Lithgow in central west NSW and Liddell in NSW's Hunter region.\n\nThe coalition would also build small modular reactors at Northern Power Station in the South Australian city of Port Augusta and at Muja Power Station, southeast of Perth.\n\n\"We want to utilise the existing assets that we've got, the poles and wires that are used at the moment on the coal-fired power station sites ... to distribute the energy generated from the latest-generation nuclear reactors,\" Mr Dutton told reporters in Sydney on Wednesday.\n\nThe Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry said its core policy position was that any energy source should compete in the market while aiming for agreed emissions targets.\n\n\"As we go down the path to net zero it is important that we focus on real-world consequences and keep costs minimised for business and the broader community,\" ACCI chief of policy and advocacy David Alexander said.\n\nThe power plants will form part of an \"energy mix\" that also includes gas and renewables, which the opposition claims will help provide around-the-clock baseload power and drive down prices.\n\nThe first two plants are expected to be completed between 2035 and 2037, as it will take at least a decade from a government decision for nuclear electricity to enter the grid.\n\nThis meant Australia could still reach net-zero emissions by 2050, Mr Dutton said.\n\nBut environmental advocates say the plan will delay an urgently needed shift away from fossil fuels, with Climate Council CEO Amanda McKenzie calling it a commitment to coal and gas.\n\n\"(It's) a clear case of radioactive greenwashing and a scheme for more climate pollution,\" she said.\n\nEven if the small modular reactors end up cheaper and quicker to build than their larger counterparts, no projects have been completed globally and the CSIRO warned it would be \"very unlikely\" one would be up and running as quickly as 2038.\n\nEnergy Minister Chris Bowen decried the proposal as a \"nuclear scam\".\n\n\"It's risky because it undermines investment in renewable energy, it's risky because it means relying on ageing coal-fired power ... which is increasingly unreliable,\" he told reporters.\n\nPrime Minister Anthony Albanese said the plan made \"no economic sense\" and would put Australia in a position of energy insecurity, while Treasurer Jim Chalmers labelled it \"economic insanity\".\n\nA report released by the CSIRO and the Australian Energy Market Operator in May revealed a large-scale nuclear power plant would cost at least $8.5 billion.\n\nMinerals Council executive Tania Constable backed the plan, claiming nuclear power would help decarbonise the economy while maintaining its competitiveness.\n\nTo assuage safety concerns, Mr Dutton said a 470-megawatt reactor would produce waste equivalent to the size of a soda can, which could be stored on site and moved to a permanent home.\n\nEven if the federal election turns in the coalition's favour, the opposition will still have to battle it out against the states.\n\nNSW Premier Chris Minns said he would not lift the nuclear prohibition in NSW, Victoria's government is strongly opposed and Queensland Liberal National leader David Crisafulli - who is tipped win the state's election - has ruled out nuclear energy.", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": {"uri": "8184790338", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "06:46:24", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T06:46:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T06:45:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.afr.com/companies/energy/dutton-s-high-stakes-nuclear-gamble-20240619-p5jn0d", "title": "Dutton's high stakes nuclear gamble", "body": "\"I am very happy for the election to be a referendum on energy, on nuclear, on power prices, on lights going out, on who has a sustainable pathway for our country going forward,\" Dutton said at a lengthy press conference announcing the location of seven proposed reactors across the country.\n\nHe repeatedly cites the use of \"cleaner, cheaper, consistent and reliable\" nuclear energy in other major developed countries as key to their ability to reach net-zero emissions by 2050.\n\nBut keenly aware of overwhelming community angst about domestic cost-of-living pressures, he insists nuclear power would be a \"fraction of the cost\" of the government's renewables strategy.\n\n\"If you think your power price is too high now, wait for a second term of the Albanese government,\" he declared. \"The power prices under Labor will continue to escalate exponentially.\"\n\nThat's despite offering no figures on Wednesday for the Coalition's proposed nuclear power plants, arguing he wants the focus of this announcement to be on the selected sites, all replacing end-of-life coal-fired plants.\n\nThis is an extraordinary policy leap for the Coalition, including the willingness to effectively re-nationalise much of the power industry after decades of backing privatisation. Dutton now refers to Commonwealth ownership and investment in nuclear generation as a \"national asset\".\n\nThe government's relentless attacks on this will all be variations of Treasurer Jim Chalmers' condemnation that the Coalition's \"nuclear road to nowhere ... might be the dumbest policy ever put forward by a major party\".\n\nThis new front in Australia's perpetual energy wars - combined with Dutton's rejection of 2030 emissions targets - will also dismay business leaders yearning for some policy stability and reliable power supply over this decade at least.\n\nLabor, Greens and teals are relishing the prospect of fighting over this territory.\n\nBut while such arguments may be persuasive in teal seats and the inner city, Dutton is targeting struggling households in outer suburbia as well as regional Australian seats where people need skilled jobs to replace those disappearing in coal-fired power.\n\nHe wants to combine this with a younger generation of voters not as spooked by the record of nuclear accidents and more open to the long-term environmental appeal of nuclear's zero-emissions power.\n\nA typically aggressive sounding Dutton dismisses criticism by those he derides as \"green millionaires\" with huge investments in green energy.\n\n\"I'm not interested in lining the pockets of rich green millionaires, I want to bring down the price of electricity for average mums and dads,\" he said.\n\nNor is he deterred by expert analysis of the high cost of building nuclear power plants, particularly in a country with no experience of its use. He prefers to cite the much greater disruption and equally uncertain price of building 28,000 kilometres of new transmission lines as well as the cost of wind turbines that must be dismantled after a much shorter life span than nuclear power.\n\nHis retort to how realistic all this is includes questioning why ambitions for green hydrogen can be regarded as realistic when that technology has yet to be proven at scale in contrast to modern nuclear technology in use in many countries.\n\nLikewise, he ignores the CSIRO's prediction that the 2040s will be the earliest possible timing for nuclear power, maintaining the first two nuclear generators will be built between 2035 and 2037.\n\nThe local communities at these sites he expects to be supportive given the economic boost and jobs, promising to work closely with them about the best options. That will certainly be a test for the Coalition given the inevitability of plenty of local antagonism as well.\n\nThe premiers, he insists, will also be \"pragmatic\" given that Western Australia and South Australia are already willing to host nuclear-powered submarines under the AUKUS agreement while NSW has had a medical nuclear facility operating at Lucas Heights in Sydney since 1958.\n\nFederal Labor's embrace of AUKUS has allowed him to argue the Albanese government clearly has no fears about the safety of nuclear reactors or the disposal of nuclear waste.\n\nNot that such logic will persuade Labor premiers or even the probably new Liberal National premier of Queensland, David Crisafulli. The Coalition is expected to win the state election but Crisafulli doesn't want to campaign supporting his federal leader's plans for two nuclear power plants in Queensland.\n\nThe Coalition argues it will negotiate co-operatively with both the private owners and the states over the sites but that its legal advice is that it has the power to compulsorily acquire them if necessary \"in the national interest\".\n\n\"We go to the next election seeking a clear mandate from the Australian people ... to modernise our energy system,\" Dutton said. The country, he suggests, is ready for a mature debate.\n\nIt still leaves the Coalition banking on its ability to sell an obviously high-risk \"vision\", contrasting it with a prime minister who Dutton argues has neither vision nor the ability to manage day to day government.", "source": {"uri": "afr.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Australian Financial Review"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "2024-06-395418161", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "05:14:48", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T05:14:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T00:34:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://money.usnews.com/investing/news/articles/2024-06-20/column-australias-nuclear-power-proponents-have-questions-to-answer-russell", "title": "Column-Australia's Nuclear Power Proponents Have Questions to Answer: Russell", "body": "LAUNCESTON, Australia (Reuters) - Australia's main opposition party wants a sensible debate about nuclear power as it commits to build seven plants to replace coal generation if it wins the next federal election.\n\nThe conservative Liberal Party and its junior regional partner National Party announced plans on Wednesday for five large-scale nuclear plants in the eastern Australian states of Queensland, New South Wales and Victoria, as well as small modular reactors for South Australia and Western Australia.\n\nIf there is to be a genuine debate on what form of generation is best to replace Australia's ageing and increasingly unreliable fleet of coal generators, there are two main questions that need to be answered.\n\nThe first is the cost of the replacement generation and the second is whether it can be delivered quickly enough to not only replace coal plants, but also to meet Australia's commitment to net-zero emissions by 2050.\n\nThe Liberal and National parties, together known as the Coalition, declined to provide any costings for the their plans, but Liberal leader Petter Dutton did acknowledge it would be expensive, while still claiming it would deliver cheaper power for Australians.\n\nNo credible analyst supports Dutton's assertion, with estimates varying as to the cost of building nuclear generation, but all of them coming in well above the cost of solar and wind firmed by battery storage and pumped hydropower.\n\nThe government's science agency, the CSIRO, estimated that new nuclear power would be twice as expensive as renewables backed by storage, and this was a best case scenario predicated on achieving economies of scale from a long-term and continuous building programme.\n\nThe Coalition said it would be able to have nuclear plants up and running between 2035 and 2037, assuming it started implementing its policy if it defeats the ruling Labor Party in a federal election due in the first half of 2025.\n\nIn theory it would be possible to build the seven gigawatts (GW) of nuclear plants on that time scale, but doing so would be an incredible achievement at odds with the recent experiences of other Western countries.\n\nNuclear plants are notorious for blowing out both on budget and time, with Britain's under-construction Hinkley Point C one such example, where the cost has more than doubled and the start date pushed back at least seven years.\n\nOBSTACLES ABOUND\n\nThe Coalition also did not elaborate on how it would overcome several political and social obstacles to nuclear power.\n\nCurrently nuclear generation is prohibited by federal law, meaning the Coalition would have to pass enabling legislation through both the lower chamber and the upper house Senate.\n\nWhile it may win the election and control the lower house, it would take a massive victory for it to take control of the Senate.\n\nThis means Dutton as prime minister would have to negotiate with cross-bench senators, and given the majority of those are either from the Australian Greens or are progressive independents, it's likely his nuclear plan would fail at the first hurdle.\n\nThere are also prohibitions on nuclear power in several states, and so far the leaders of New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland have rejected any nuclear plants.\n\nBuilding a nuclear industry from scratch would also require importing a skilled workforce of nuclear engineers and other experts, something that seems at odds with the Coalition's plans to reduce migration and its increasing anti-immigrant rhetoric.\n\nWinning a social licence from the communities where the nuclear plants are planned to be located may also present challenges, even if the facilities bring jobs to replace those lost when the coal-fired generators close.\n\nThere is also the question of scale, with the Coalition planning on 7 GW of nuclear plants, which is only a third of Australia's current coal-fired capacity of about 22 GW.\n\nThis means that nuclear won't come close to replacing coal, which in turn means that renewables and storage will be needed as well, or there will be more reliance on costly natural gas.\n\nThe question of funding nuclear is also unresolved, especially since no Australian utility has shown any interest in going nuclear.\n\nThe Coalition has implied that a government-owned corporation will be set up and presumably funded by taxpayers, a position that seems to contradict the underlying philosophy of at least the Liberal part of the Coalition that governments should play a limited role in the economy.\n\nInitial reaction to the Coalition's nuclear plans has been overwhelmingly negative, with one of the few supportive voices coming from the Minerals Council of Australia, a lobby group that includes coal miners.\n\nWhile the council doesn't say it in their media release, part of their support for nuclear is because they recognise that going down that path most likely means coal remains in the generation mix for a much longer period than currently expected.\n\nOverall, it's tempting to dismiss the Coalition's nuclear plans as an expensive fantasy, especially in a country so ideally suited to develop solar and wind.\n\nHowever, the real damage from the nuclear proposal is likely that the energy debate in Australia will descend into a partisan political slanging match, with nuclear and fossil fuels being championed by the right-wing and renewables and storage by their left opponents.\n\nThe opinions expressed here are those of the author, a columnist for Reuters.", "source": {"uri": "money.usnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "U.S. News & World Report"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8184632235", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "04:22:22", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T04:22:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T04:21:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://smallcaps.com.au/dutton-unveils-plan-nuclear-plants-across-australia/", "title": "Dutton unveils plan for 7 nuclear plants across Australia", "body": "Opposition leader Peter Dutton has intensified his pro-nuclear energy campaign by unveiling seven potential sites for nuclear power plants across the country.\n\nMr Dutton has positioned the switch to nuclear power as a central element of the opposition's energy policy in the lead-up to the next Federal election.\n\nThe eagerly-awaited announcement of his preferred sites for new nuclear power stations has elicited a mixed response of anti-nuclear outcry and support.\n\nMr Dutton stated that the seven sites would be situated at power stations that have either closed or are scheduled to close, with two located in both New South Wales and Queensland and one each in Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia.\n\nHis favoured locations include the Liddell and Mount Piper power stations in NSW, the Tarong and Callide power stations in Queensland, the Loy Yang power station in Victoria, the Northern power station in SA and WA's Muja power station.\n\nBoth Muja and Northern have been designated as small modular reactor sites only.\n\n\"Nuclear energy for Australia is an idea whose time has come,\" Mr Dutton declared..\n\nEvery Australian deserves and should expect access to cheaper, cleaner and consistent electricity but, under Labor, this isn't happening.\"\n\n\"Right now, households and businesses around the country are suffering from Labor's expensive renewables-only approach.\"\n\nMr Dutton questioned the current government's target of achieving 65% to 75% in emissions reduction by 2035, noting that they have yet to release modelling and future power price estimates.\n\n\"Power bills have already increased by up to $1,000 for many Australians, despite promises of a $275 reduction.\"\n\n\"Moreover, Labor's climate target of 43% emissions reduction by 2030 has become unachievable.\"\n\nMr Dutton - who is about to embark on a nationwide tour to outline the merits of the plan - emphasised that nuclear power must play an integral role if Australia is to achieve a balanced and consistent energy mix.\n\nHe noted that with 90% of baseload electricity - predominantly from coal-fired power stations - nearing the end of life within the next decade, nuclear energy has proven effective in reducing electricity prices and emissions globally, complementing renewable energy and gas.\n\n\"A key advantage of modern zero-emissions nuclear plants is that they can be integrated into existing grids,\" he said.\n\n\"This means they can effectively replace retired or retiring coal plants and avoid much of the new expenditure required for Labor's 'renewables-only' system including new transmission poles and wires, costs that will ultimately be passed on to consumers in the form of higher bills.\"\n\nHe declared that Labor's strategy would require 58 million solar panels, 3,500 new industrial wind turbines and up to 28,000 kilometres of new transmission lines across the country.\n\n\"Energy experts have warned that the cost of Labor's rollout will be between $1.2 and $1.5 trillion,\" Mr Dutton said.\n\n\"No country in the world relies solely on solar and wind as Labor is proposing.\"\n\n\"By contrast, 32 countries are operating zero-emissions nuclear plants and another 50 are looking to do so.\"\n\n\"Of the world's 20 largest economies, Australia is the only one not using nuclear energy or moving towards using it.\"\n\nThe Minerals Council of Australia (MCA) immediately expressed support for the nuclear power plans.\n\n\"The coalition's nuclear policy provides a crucial pathway for Australia's industries to reduce emissions cost-effectively while maintaining access to reliable baseload power,\" said MCA chief executive officer Tania Constable.\n\n\"High future demand for reliable and clean energy means that all energy types, including nuclear power, will be indispensable in meeting Australia's future energy needs.\"\n\nMs Constable highlighted Australia's strong global reputation for non-proliferation and its world-class uranium industry that includes almost a third of global uranium reserves and supplies around 10% of global uranium used for zero-emissions electricity, positioning it well to lead in nuclear energy development.\n\n\"Nuclear energy stands out as a reliable, zero-emissions, 24/7 baseload energy source that can deliver long-term stability and support for Australia's miners, manufacturers and communities,\" she said.\n\nFor once, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and the Greens are in agreement, both describing the nuclear plan as \"fantasy.\"\n\nSpeaking on local radio while in Perth, the PM remarked, \"the market has sorted it out.\"\n\n\"That's why they're saying not just that they'll have this nuclear fantasy but it'll be a taxpayer-funded nuclear fantasy as well because the markets won't fund something that is 15 years away, something that is the most expensive form of new energy.\"\n\n\"We know that the energy transition is necessary,\" he added.\n\n\"Fourteen coal-fired power plants announced their closures under the former coalition government.\"\n\n\"It's a matter of whether the rollout of renewables with solar continues in order to secure energy supply, or whether we just stop all that happening and wait 15 years for the most expensive form of energy to come back online.\"", "source": {"uri": "smallcaps.com.au", "dataType":
