{"uri": "8184836776", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "07:22:09", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T07:22:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T07:20:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/chris-bowen-labels-coalition-nuclear-070356957.html", "title": "Chris Bowen labels Coalition's nuclear plan a 'risky scam' as premiers affirm state bans", "body": "Paul Karp, Amy Remeikis, Sarah Basford Canales and Josh Butler\n\nChris Bowen has labelled the Coalition's nuclear plan a \"risky scam\", citing the fact owners of six of the seven proposed sites for power plants won't sell and five are located in states with their own bans on nuclear power.\n\nIn a move that frustrated some on his backbench on Wednesday, Peter Dutton revealed the sites but without providing costings for the proposed government-owned nuclear power plants, nor an estimate of the amount of electricity to be added to the system and or justification for the ambitious 2035-37 timeframe for the first two plants.\n\nAlthough the Coalition has said it proposes to build the plants - at Tarong and Callide in Queensland, Mount Piper and Liddell in New South Wales, Collie in Western Australia, Loy Yang in Victoria, and one near Port Augusta in South Australia - it has not committed to doing so.\n\nThe deputy Nationals leader, Perin Davey, revealed that if local communities were \"absolutely adamant\" they didn't want them then the Coalition \"will not proceed\" and will not search for alternative sites.\n\nThe Nationals leader, David Littleproud, later refuted Davey's comments, saying he and Dutton would be \"prepared to make the tough decisions in the national interest\".\n\nThe independent MP Andrew Gee, whose electorate of Calare includes Mount Piper, said that \"even supporters of nuclear power have questions about this announcement\", including cost and whether the current owners had been consulted.\n\nSo far Coalition MPs whose electorates will host the power plants, including Littleproud, and MPs Colin Boyce and Darren Chester, have backed the plan.\n\nRelated: 'Raises red flags': Coalition nuclear power plan met with widespread scepticism from business groups\n\nBut other MPs felt the snap Coalition party room on Wednesday morning wasn't a genuine consultation, with key details missing from the proposal. Those MPs have muted their criticism only because it is pointless to criticise a policy that will likely never come to fruition.\n\nOne federal Liberal MP, who spoke to Guardian Australia under the condition of anonymity, said the Liberals would struggle to campaign on the plan until there were more details and costings.\n\n\"If we don't see the detail of it before the election, the electorate won't take us seriously. Australians aren't stupid,\" they said.\n\n\"It's a bunch of statements without any detail.\n\n\"You can't turn off coal one day and start nuclear the next day like that. You can't unplug one and plug in the other and I think that's why conversations around nuclear are important to see where and how it might work.\"\n\nMost MPs accept the policy as a high-risk, high-reward manoeuvre that could wrong-foot Labor by offering low emissions power, but could also saddle the opposition with an unpopular and expensive policy akin to the tax changes former Labor leader Bill Shorten took the 2019 election or the former Liberal leader John Hewson's ill-fated Fightback! platform he proposed at the 1993 poll.\n\nBowen, the climate change and energy minister, said the policy \"fails at the first hurdle\". \"Mr Dutton needs to explain how he would overturn [state nuclear bans], not abuse the premiers, not berate and complain ... but outline what his own plan is,\" he told reporters in Sydney.\n\n\"The Australian people now have a very clear choice: stick with the plan or go with this un-costed, un-modelled fantasy that Mr Dutton is proposing today.\"\n\nBowen said the policy would cause \"a complete breakdown of investment in renewable energy and that's what the Liberal and National Party wants\".\n\nThe premiers of Victoria, New South Wales and Queensland reiterated on Wednesday that they would not lift their states' bans of nuclear power, as the Queensland Liberal National opposition leader, David Crisafulli, did earlier in the week.\n\nBut Dutton told reporters in Sydney he would negotiate with the states and joked that the proverbial \"bucket of money\" could overcome their objections.\n\nWith none of the sites currently owned by the commonwealth, Dutton also suggested they could be compulsorily acquired. AGL is turning Liddell into a battery, to start operations in 2026, and is planning to manufacture solar panels there.\n\nDutton had conceded that a \"significant amounts of gas\" would be used to generate electricity in the interim, before two plants he claims could be online by 2035-2037 and the rest to commence operations in the 2040s.\n\nThe shadow attorney general, Michaelia Cash, who is a senator for WA, suggested the power station at Collie would be built closer to 2050.\n\nRelated: The Coalition's nuclear power plan offers the worst of all energy worlds: higher emissions and higher electricity costs | Malcolm Turnbull\n\nThe CSIRO's Gencost report advised nuclear power could be set up in Australia no sooner than 2040 and would be at least 50% more expensive than solar and wind, even factoring in the costs of transmission and firming of renewables.\n\nBoyce, whose electorate of Flynn contains the site of the proposed Callide power station, suggested his community would welcome it as it has a \"proud heritage as an energy-producing region and there is a high level of 'energy literacy' in the community\".\n\nChester, who previously warned that his community would need to receive \"direct economic benefits\" if it were to host a power plants, on Wednesday welcomed the release of the plan.\n\n\"I will be listening to locals, consulting the experts, and putting the needs of Gippsland and Latrobe Valley first, and endeavouring to act in the national interest at all times,\" he said in a statement.\n\nThe NSW Liberal senator and former state party president Maria Kovacic said all resources should be leveraged, including wind and solar.\n\n\"An affordable, clean, balanced, stable and efficient energy mix is critical. We need to ensure that we set ideology aside as we deliver on this,\" she said.\n\nAndrew Bragg, the shadow assistant minister for home ownership and a leading Liberal moderate, backed the nuclear policy, labelling the federal nuclear ban \"thoroughly unscientific\" and a \"bizarre prohibition\".\n\nThe Liberal MP Rowan Ramsey, whose seat of Grey contains the Northern power station, said in March that any talk of where nuclear power plants would be built is \"conjecture\" that cannot sensibly be tackled until after the nuclear ban is lifted.", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", {"uri": "8186449773", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "06:29:17", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T06:29:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T06:28:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.theepochtimes.com/world/how-states-responded-to-the-oppositions-nuclear-alternative-to-net-zero-5671184", "title": "How States Responded to the Opposition's Nuclear Alternative to Net Zero", "body": "Australian state leaders have responded to federal Opposition Leader Peter Dutton's plan to construct seven nuclear power plants across the country if elected.\n\nThe Liberal-National Coalition is proposing to replace retiring coal-fired power stations with nuclear facilities, as an alternative path towards net zero -- rather than adopt a mass roll-out of wind turbines, solar panels, and batteries.\n\nThe slated sites for nuclear power plants include Loy Yang Power Station in Gippsland of Victoria, Callide and Tarong in Queensland, Port Augusta in South Australia, Collie in West Australia, as well as Mount Piper in Lithgow, and Liddell in the Hunter Valley in New South Wales.\n\nYet the response from state Labor premiers has mostly been negative, while Liberal Party opposition leaders have largely avoided openly supporting the concept -- barring David Speirs from South Australia.\n\n\"You say you will negotiate with the states. I won't be negotiating.\"\n\nOn June 20, she said she would \"stand with the Victorian community,\" particularly in Gippsland.\n\n\"When you think about the future of our state, when you think about the future we want our kids to grow up in ... I want it to be a state where the energy source is clean, secure, and cheaper,\" she told reporters outside Parliament House in Melbourne.\n\n\"And what's really important about our pathway that we're already on with renewable energy is that we know that it works. We have the lowest wholesale prices here in Victoria in that nation.\"\n\nOpposition State Liberal Leader John Pesutto said he had \"no plans for nuclear as a state opposition,\" but left the door open for future discussions.\n\n\"It may well be that a future federal government initiates a national discussion on nuclear power noting that there is a moratorium currently in place nationally,\" he told reporters on June 19.\n\n\"We know this will cost hundreds of billions of dollars and that will mean people's electricity bills will be higher and I'm concerned about the future generations of Queenslanders who will need to manage this dangerous radioactive waste forever,\" he told ABC Radio on June 20.\n\n\"We just don't need it. We have a detailed, costed plan to get to net zero emissions in our energy system through renewable, through solar and wind, and pumped hydro storage in particular, and that's the plan we're pursuing here.\"\n\nMr. Miles also said it was not assured his government would sell the designated sites for nuclear power plants to the federal government.\n\n\"We still own those generators and we own that land and we own the transmission network from there and so without our cooperation it's very hard to see how he can do it,\" the premier said.\n\n\"I tell you what -- if Labor is in government we will do everything that we can to block his plan to build expensive nuclear reactors on sites we own here in Queensland.\"\n\nThe LNP opposition meanwhile, left the matter for future discussion.\n\n\"It's not on our agenda, because quite frankly, that's a matter for Canberra,\" Opposition Leader David Crisafulli told reporters.\n\n\"Firstly, it costs a lot of money. Secondly, it takes a lot of time and we don't have a day to wait, and I don't think NSW consumers can pay any more when it comes to energy prices,\" he told reporters.\n\n\"The last estimate I saw was that nuclear power generation in this state to replace coal-fired power would cost between $70-$200 billion. Who are they going to send that bill to?\"\n\nHe also said there was significant investment in renewable developments and changing course now would be a \"sovereign risk.\"\n\n\"We've got $30-odd billion of private capital invested in renewable energy,\" he said. \"If all of a sudden you were to introduce nuclear power, that investment is at real risk.\"\n\nNSW Opposition Leader Mark Speakman said he did not have \"enough detail,\" but was open to nuclear.\n\n\"My concern is exclusively around cost. What we know from all the independent research that is out there is that nuclear power in the context of the Australian energy market is actually going to drive up prices rather than driving down,\" he told Sky News on June 20.\n\n\"There's only one or two things that have happened. Either Peter Dutton knows how much the cost is and he's refusing to tell us -- or, even more scary, he's announced a policy without even knowing how much it's possible.\"\n\nHowever, state Opposition Leader David Speirs was one of the few leaders to display overt support for nuclear.\n\n\"If elected in 2026, the South Australian Liberal Party is committed to establishing a Royal Commission into the potential for civil nuclear energy generation in South Australia, so that we can make informed decisions about the future of energy in our state, and create a long-term plan to make electricity more affordable and reliable for all South Australians.\"\n\nMayor Dean Johnson said a local ballot conducted to gauge support found 61.6 percent of voters in favour of the site, compared to 38.4 percent.\n\n\"This is a recipe for disaster. It's a recipe for massive increases in power bills. On any measure it simply does not make sense,\" he told ABC Radio Perth.\n\n\"In Australia, we have no legislative or regulatory framework. We have no workforce. We have no experience. It's going to take years and years and years, and billions of dollars of taxpayer subsidies to support this.\n\n\"You've got more chance of seeing a unicorn trotting down St Georges Terrace than you have of nuclear power being a feasible and reliable option for our energy system.\"\n\nThe opposition again left the door open.\n\n\"I've always said I'm not afraid of nuclear energy,\" said opposition energy spokesperson Steve Thomas.\n\n\"But the business case has to stack up and the community support has to be there to go ahead.\"", "source": {"uri": "theepochtimes.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8185872121", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "19:43:45", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T19:43:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T19:42:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.abc.net.au/news/2024-06-20/dutton-nuclear-plan-must-convince-states/103999636", "title": "Dutton's nuclear power plan relies on convincing the states, but first there's an election to win", "body": "Right now, across Australia, seven Olympic swimming pools worth of radioactive waste is sitting in hospitals and universities because for 40 years, state and federal governments have been locked in a debate about where, and how, to dispose of it.\n\nSince the late 1970s, surveys and field assessments have been carried out, legislation passed and agencies established all to locate the safest, most remote and stable site.\n\nBut every proposal, from Woomera and Kimba in South Australia to Muckaty Station in the Northern Territory, has failed.\n\nWhile the search continues, more than 17,600 cubic metres of radioactive waste remains stored across 100 locations, almost all of it from life-saving nuclear medicines produced at Australia's only reactor at Lucas Heights in Sydney.\n\nIf Australia can't figure out how to permanently dispose of the by-product of X-rays, will it ever be able to settle on a site to store the spent fuel from nuclear power plants?\n\nTime and cost pressures aside, this is just one of the challenges Peter Dutton is facing as he embarks on a mission to convince voters to back his nuclear vision.\n\nYes.\n\nThe year was 1998 and then-prime minister John Howard needed the support of the Democrats and the Greens in the Senate to upgrade the Lucas Heights reactor.\n\nThey would only agree if he added an amendment prohibiting \"certain nuclear installations\", including a nuclear power plant.\n\nThe same ban was later added to federal environmental laws and Queensland, Victoria and New South Wales doubled down, forbidding nuclear power in their states too.\n\nFor context, this was at a time when the word \"nuclear\" was considered toxic: the French had only just ended its controversial weapons testing program in the Pacific, on Australia's doorstep.\n\nIn the lead-up to the 2007 election, Howard sensed the \"scene on nuclear energy is changing\" and called for a full-blooded debate about the issue in Australia. He lost.\n\nDutton is hoping for a different outcome at the next federal election but if he wins, he'll still need to convince federal parliament to lift the ban.\n\nHe won't be able to count on the support Labor or the Greens, meaning, in the event of a minority government, nuclear power could hinge on the likes of Bob Katter or Pauline Hanson.\n\nNo.\n\nThe states are crucial because under Dutton's plan, nuclear power plants would be built in every state except Tasmania. However, as we mentioned above, several states currently have bans on nuclear power.\n\nHistorically, Labor and the trade union movement have been firmly opposed to nuclear, even for civil uses like energy.\n\nVictoria's Premier Jacinta Allan gave Dutton's plan to build two reactors in the Latrobe Valley short shrift.\n\n\"They want to bring more expensive, more risky, more toxic energy solutions to the people of this country. We won't stand for that,\" Ms Allan said.\n\nWhen asked how he'd overcome this hurdle, Dutton was rather blunt, referencing a famous Paul Keating quote.\n\n\"Somebody famously said 'I would not stand between a premier and a bucket of money', and we've seen the premiers in different debates before where they've been able to negotiate with the Commonwealth, and we'll be able to address those issues,\" he told reporters.\n\nDutton is promising \"integrated economic development zones\" and \"regional deals\" for the seven communities earmarked for reactors, hoping it might help sway some state leaders too.\n\nWith wall-to-wall Labor state governments, the Coalition is preparing for a hostile reaction but it has an ace up its sleeve: constitutional powers of compulsory acquisition.\n\n\"We will work with the owners of the sites, and if we find a situation where we apply a national interest test and we require that site to be part of the national grid, then the legal advice we have is that the Commonwealth has ample powers to compulsorily acquire that, with compensation,\" Dutton said.\n\nDutton reckons the AUKUS deal is a game-changer.\n\nAustralia is acquiring a fleet of nuclear-power (conventionally-armed) submarines from the US and UK, and as part of that deal, will need to find a site to store high-grade nuclear waste.\n\nIn other words, future governments will have to address this issue regardless of whether Australia embraces nuclear power.\n\n\"Would the prime minister have signed an agreement with the United States and the United Kingdom which requires Australia to dispose of the waste from the submarines and the reactors, at end of life, if he thought or she thought that it wasn't safe to do so?\" Dutton asked.\n\nUntil a permanent solution is found, he's flagged storing the waste on the site of the seven proposed nuclear power plants.\n\n\"If you look at a 470-megawatt reactor, it produces waste equivalent to the size of a can of coke each year,\" he said.\n\n\"It's stored on site under our proposal and then at the end of the life of that asset, it's a move to a permanent home.\"\n\nThe regulator, Australia's Radiation, Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency (ARPANSA), said \"permanent disposal is considered, internationally, to be the safest long-term management option for radioactive waste\".\n\nIn the US, which has more than 90 nuclear reactors, the waste is stored mainly in dry casks on the locations of current and former nuclear power plants.\n\nARPANSA itself has said it would take between 10 to 15 years to have a nuclear power plant up and running in Australia, due to the need for a significant review of regulation, as well as a skilled workforce.\n\n\"If there was a change in government policy to establish a civil nuclear power program in Australia, ARPANSA notes that further reforms would be required to the national regulatory arrangements to enable its deployment,\" a spokesperson said in a statement.\n\n\"This would include the management of radioactive waste and spent fuel, transport of radioactive materials and for emergency preparedness and response.\"\n\nThis is uncharted territory and challenges abound, but it'll all come to nothing if the Coalition falls at the first hurdle: the next federal election.", "source": {"uri": "abc.net.au", "dataType": "news", "title": "Australian his state's nuclear prohibition would not be removed under his watch and suggested the proposal would stymie investment in solar and wind.\n\n\"We've got $30-odd billion of private capital invested in renewable energy,\" he said on Wednesday.\n\n\"If all of a sudden you were to introduce nuclear power, that investment is at real risk.\"\n\nVictorian Premier Jacinta Allan said her government would not allow the federal opposition to add nuclear to the state's energy mix.\n\n\"They want to bring more expensive, more risky, more toxic energy solutions to the people of this country,\" she said.\n\n\"We won't stand for that.\"\n\nQueensland Premier Steven Miles claimed the prohibitive cost of establishing nuclear energy in Australia would push up power bills.\n\n\"That is not to mention how future generations, my kids, your kids will need to manage dangerous radioactive nuclear waste forever,\" he said.\n\nWA Energy Minister Reece Whitby said it was a \"crazy\" plan and a \"wolf-whistle to extremists\" that makes no sense given the nation had the ingredients for affordable, renewable green energy.\n\n\"This is a nightmare scenario (and) this is the worst possible case you can imagine, to meet our energy needs of the future,\" he said.\n\n\"Nuclear is hugely expensive (and) Peter Dutton is talking about massive taxpayer subsidies of billions of dollars will go on and on and on.\"\n\nSA Premier Peter Malinauskas said Mr Dutton should tell the nation how much the seven power stations would cost to build.\n\n\"Why isn't he telling people, presumably because he knows it will make power more expensive,\" he said.\n\nThe federal opposition leader wants to set up seven plants at coal-fired power stations if the coalition wins the next election, due before May 2025.\n\nPlants would be built at Loy Yang in Victoria's Gippsland region, Callide and Tarong in Queensland, Mount Piper at Lithgow in central west NSW and Liddell in NSW's Hunter region.\n\nSmall modular reactors would be located at Port Augusta in South Australia and Muja, in WA's South West region.\n\nThe policy has also failed to garner the backing of state Liberal leaders.\n\nVictorian plants", "body": "Tens of thousands of Australians in five states could be living near nuclear power plants if the coalition wins the next federal election.\n\nOpposition Leader Peter Dutton has unveiled details of his much-anticipated nuclear energy policy, which will put nuclear power plants in Australia's former fossil fuel heartlands.\n\nA coalition government will attempt to build a total of seven plants at existing coal-fired power stations, with the assets owned by the Commonwealth.\n\nThis includes Loy Yang Power Station in Victoria's Gippsland area, Callide and Tarong in Queensland, Port Augusta in South Australia, Collie in West Australia, Mount Piper at Lithgow in central west NSW and Liddell in NSW's Hunter region.\n\n\"We want to utilise the existing assets that we've got, and the poles and wires that are used at the moment on the coal-fired power station sites ... to distribute the energy generated from the latest generation nuclear reactors,\" Mr Dutton told reporters in Sydney on Wednesday.\n\n\"We have the ability to do that in a way that renewables can't.\"\n\nPrime Minister Anthony Albanese has slammed the plan and says it overlooks Australia's renewable energy potential.\n\n\"It'll be a taxpayer funded nuclear fantasy,\" he told ABC radio.\n\n\"Here in Australia, we have the best solar resources in the world.\n\n\"This makes no economic in Western Australia and Port Augusta in South Australia.\n\nThe reactors will be built on the site of existing, ageing coal-fired power stations, using existing transmission line infrastructure with government would scrap Labor's 2030 target of 43 per cent emissions reduction, but remained committed to net zero.\n\nIn announcing his nuclear policy on Wednesday, Mr Dutton took aim at Labor's \"renewables only\" policy, which he said was not fit for purpose and risked blackouts and harming the economy.\n\nMr Littleproud said Mr Dutton had taken \"courage and conviction\" in putting forward "https://images.7news.com.au/publication/C-15068415/a47ea93735e15ea37a07ed8aa90898923af15833-16x9-x0y75w800h450.jpg?imwidth=1200", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9662030", "eventUri": {"uri": "8184507842", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "02:29:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T02:29:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T01:54:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13544919/Peter-van-onselen-dutton-nuclear-announcement.html", "title": "PVO: Dutton's nuclear plan for Australia is never going to happen", "body": "By Peter van Onselen, Political Editor for Daily Mail Australia\n\nThe great nuclear debate can now begin in earnest. Only it won't be great. Opposition Leader Peter Dutton has announced his plans to campaign for introducing nuclear power into Australia's energy mix at the next election.\n\nThere is so much to unpack surrounding what happens next: the political implications, the policy feasibility of 'going nuclear', what it means for energy prices and emissions reductions targets, as well as what the chances are of it ever happening.\n\nUnfortunately, however, all we are going to get from here is a Seinfeld election campaign about nothing. Labor will focus in on the mother of all scare campaigns, which will be divorced from reality. And the Coalition, even if it can win the election on its big nuclear policy, won't be able to implement it anyway because of opposition across the states.\n\nAustralia is destined to lack the maturity to discuss the viability of nuclear energy free of partisan fights and ideological support or opposition towards the technology, irrespective of whether going nuclear is realistic or not.\n\nSo the central issue for the looming election campaign - nuclear vs renewables - which will likely dominate the next federal election will be a distraction from what the majority of Australians want to focus on: cost of living pressures, the challenges of immigration and housing, as well as how the economy can be reshaped to solve such problems.\n\nPeter Dutton (pictured) is going all in on nuclear power as his solution to energy shortages and to achieve emissions reductions\n\nNonetheless, we need to explain why the nuclear debate is a red herring that will catch so much attention.\n\nLets start with the scare campaign Labor is about to ramp up, coupled with the Coalition's decision to put a massive policy target on its back.\n\nThe last two times an opposition set itself up to impose a massive policy shift if it wins an election was 1993 and 2019. John Hewson's Fightback campaign to introduce a GST and Bill Shorten's attempt to reform negative gearing and franking credits. Both men lost elections judged to be unloseable. Both policy agendas were targeted with brutal scare campaigns.\n\nThe lesson Dutton has decided to ignore is that campaigning on big reforms while in opposition is a recipe for failure.\n\nRead MoreLIVE All you need to know as Peter Dutton goes nuclear\n\nWe know scare campaigns work, not only because of these two historical examples but also because they have worked against incumbents too.\n\nPolitical advertising executives will all tell you until they are blue in the face that negative campaigning is more successful than positive campaigning. Dutton needs to positively explain why his nuclear policy is a good idea, the Labor government only has to go negative and outline all the reasons it is bad policy.\n\nThe worst part of this reality if you're Dutton is that the scare campaign doesn't even have to be true. Just look at the 2016 Mediscare campaign Malcolm Turnbull was up against at the 2016 election.\n\nLabor's claims at the time that Turnbull planned to 'abolish Medicare' were completely untrue and unachievable even if he'd wanted to do it. But that didn't stop Labor campaigning on the issue and voters being frightened.\n\nTurnbull won but only just. The closeness of the election result ended his prime ministership soon enough.\n\nThe degree of difficulty repelling a scare campaign is that much harder in opposition. So why did Dutton embark on the course that he has?\n\nNuclear technology has come a long way, but at the moment there is a ban on introducing it in Australia and the state's would need to get on board to change that\n\nHe can't let the Nationals go off on a campaign arguing against renewables without some sort of alternative to help bring down emissions. Nuclear gives him that. He ideologically believes the state based bans all around the country, as well as nationally, is silly policy, which he's right about. It's policy retrofitted to a 1970s attitude about nuclear power.\n\nDutton also knows that the last (and only) serious independent study analysing nuclear power's viability was handed down back in 2006. It found that yes it is viable, but only if steps to implement the policy shift happen right away.\n\nThat never happened.\n\nSo if you're energy agnostic, as I am, and pro a technology neutral approach to emissions reductions, as I also am, the problem with going nuclear is that Australia may have left its run too late. But we don't know that because we need an up-to-date independent study.\n\nThe problem with Dutton announcing his intention to go nuclear the way that he has is that he really shouldn't be doing so without a proper feasibility study independently and rigorously carried out. What he has commissioned doesn't amount to that level of detailed analysis. You need to be in government first to do that.\n\nThe Labor government won't do it, and for some reason Dutton wants to do more than commit to doing such a study if he wins the next election. Probably because he wants to say he has a tangible solution to energy needs and emissions reductions, not just a thought bubble of doing a study before making a decision.\n\nDutton might also be worried that without details, Labor's scare campaign could go off in any number of directions he hopes today's details will counter. But the scare campaign will do all of that anyway, because as already noted, political scare campaigns aren't rooted in fact.\n\nAn election about nothing on nuclear power is on the cards, just like the Seinfeld show 'about nothing'\n\nEverything from protestors in hazmat suits to images of the Simpsons and the leaky unsafe nuclear reactor that their town of Springwood depended on will come up during the campaign.\n\nLabor will argue that reactors might pop up all over the country, not just in the electorates the Coalition nominates. It will point to international reactor failures, even if the technologies have advanced since then and Australia's topography is very different.\n\nThen we have the final issue which is the reason this whole debate that is about to start in earnest is a waste of time. A campaign about nothing.\n\nThe state's won't approve the policy and the senate probably won't approve the legislation before we even get to the states.\n\nThe Greens look set to control the Senate's balance of power after the next election and they are utterly opposed to going nuclear.\n\nIf state governments stand by their nuclear bans there isn't much the Commonwealth can do to get around that. And state premiers and even Coalition opposition leaders are already lining up to say there is no way they will lift nuclear bans. It might become a constitutional fight.\n\nThis policy is dead on arrival.\n\nThe good news in this should be that the states might be saving Dutton from himself politically, but the dye has been cast already. Even though the fact there is virtually no chance of Dutton's nuclear policy going live - because of the hurdles he has to overcome but can't - should reduce the potency of a Labor scare campaign, it probably won't.\n\nBecause Dutton won't want to accept that he can't get this policy past the states, and it suits the Labor government to pretend that he might to service the potency of its scare campaign.\n\nAt his media conference Dutton noted that Paul Keating once said that it is dangerous to get between a Premier and a bag full of money, suggesting that he can win the states over by bribing them with handouts.\n\nBut it would need to be so much money (or arm twisting via denying Commonwealth grants) that the sheer quantum of what would be required might bankrupt the federal treasury. I can't even reach a lofty financial figure that, in my mind, might get them on board. Politically it also dangerously opens Dutton up to attacks that he is a risky fiscal option to support. Given that is a problem for Labor right now, Dutton risks turning the economic debate around if he keeps suggesting he'll just buy the premiers off.\n\nPolitical scare campaigns work, and Anthony Albanese (pictured) is about to unleash the mother of all scare campaigns against Dutton's nuclear policy\n\nSo here we are as a nation: in need of nuclear but long before now. Unable to overcome the barriers to its consideration, much less implementation.\n\nLabor strategists are utterly convinced their scare campaign against Dutton's nuclear policy will work and at the same time, fix their current political problems.\n\nCoalition strategists are divided as to whether 'going nuclear' will work or not. Some believe they are writing their own political death warrant and never should have gone down this path because the Labor government is teetering on the edge of political oblivion. It wasn't when Dutton first flagged going nuclear.\n\nOthers say modern Australia is ready for this debate and an old fashion scare campaign won't work. We will soon find out.\n\nNo first term government has defeated a first term opposition since 1931, and that election was fought in the midst of The Great Depression. Winning in the circumstances the Coalition is in now was already going to be hard, but the degree of difficulty just went up courtesy of today's policy announcement.\n\nIrrespective of whether going nuclear is good, and irrespective of the failures of this incompetent Labor administration.\n\nOkay, so even though this nuclear debate is ultimately about nothing for the reasons explained, on the assumption anyone has read this far and wants to weigh up the policy pros and cons of going nuclear anyway, to conclude, here they are.\n\nThe pros include that nuclear power helps achieve emissions reductions. They are comparable to renewables in this respect but with base load power renewables currently can't achieve. In theory phasing out coal fired power and introducing nuclear could make a lot of sense.\n\nNuclear power when viable is highly efficient, isn't weather dependent and can operate around the clock. Australia's safe climate and topography makes us ideally suited to housing nuclear reactors.\n\nHigh quality regulatory systems and environmental standards would help ensure safety standards prevent problems. As a well developed nation, we also have the technological capacity to provide the workforces that nuclear reactors require.\n\nAnd Australia has one of the world's largest supplies of yellowcake, the ingredient which fuels nuclear energy.\n\nThe cons are that Australia may have left its run too late, damaging the business case of going nuclear. Even smaller reactors might take more than a decade to build, by which time other technologies have filled the gap they were designed to fill. Turning newly built nuclear power plants into expensive white elephants.\n\nBuilding such controversial technology across political cycles is also a risk. And of course the risk of disasters like those we have seen overseas is always present when nuclear technology is embraced, despite Australia's natural advantages.\n\nAnd with that, let the next round of the climate wars begin!", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E._P._Dutton", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "E. months a \"referendum on nuclear\", Dutton said current policies to scale up renewables were ineffective and unreliable.\n\nAustralia's science agency has warned costly nuclear reactors would take at reactors would come online by 2035 at the earliest, Dutton said.\n\nEventually, five of Australia's eight states and territories would host a nuclear power plant.\n\nPolling released by the Lowy energy.\n\nOver the past decade, an ideological brawl dubbed the \"climate wars\" has dominated Australian politics, repeatedly undermining attempts to reduce carbon emissions.\n\n\"We cannot afford "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.chinadailyasia.com/hk/article/586027", "title": "Australian opposition reveals plan for 7 nuclear power plants", "body": "CANBERRA -- Australia's first nuclear power plants would be operational by 2037 under a plan put forward by the nation's opposition leader.\n\nPeter Dutton, leader of the Liberal-National Coalition, on Wednesday announced his plan to build seven nuclear power stations around Australia if elected Prime Minister at the next general election.\n\nDutton said in a statement that the locations offered important attributes for a zero-emissions nuclear power plant, including cooling water capacity, existing transmission infrastructure and local communities with skilled workforces\n\nUnder the plan, the first two plants would be operational by 2037, with the remaining five online by 2050.\n\nREAD MORE: Australia earmarks billions for naval infrastructure, nuke sub\n\nDutton said all the nuclear power plants would be built at locations where there are currently power stations that have closed or are scheduled to do so and that the facilities would be government-owned.\n\nAll the proposed sites are on the Australian mainland, with two each in the eastern states of New South Wales (NSW) and Queensland -- Dutton's home state -- and one each in south-eastern Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia.\n\nDutton said in a statement that the locations offered important attributes for a zero-emissions nuclear power plant, including cooling water capacity, existing transmission infrastructure and local communities with skilled workforces.\n\n\"Every Australian deserves and should expect access to cheaper, cleaner and consistent electricity,\" he said.\n\n\"Of the world's 20 largest economies, Australia is the only one not using nuclear energy, or moving towards it.\"\n\nThe federal government has had a ban on nuclear power in place in 1998 that would have to be overturned for Dutton's plan to go ahead.\n\nQueensland, NSW and Victoria also have their own bans in place, but Dutton said he would work with the state premiers on the issue.\n\nAppearing on state media Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio on Wednesday, PM Anthony Albanese said Dutton's plan overlooks Australia's renewable energy potential\n\nThe governing federal Labor Party as well as the incumbent leaders of all {"uri": "8186442065", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "06:26:22", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T06:26:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T06:21:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/world/2752406/", "title": "Peter Dutton's nuclear power plan breaks all the rules of policy making. Is it genius or career self-destruction? - ExBulletin", "body": "Peter Dutton has broken every single rule when it comes to unveiling radical politics as opposition leader, tearing up the script and gambling with his party's chances at the next election with his nuclear policy.\n\nIf he can pull it off and convince enough voters that his plan for an Australian nuclear future is feasible and preferable, it will be the most unorthodox approach we've seen from an opposition leader in recent memory. It will rewrite our understanding of how modern politics works and reshape Australia.\n\nDutton has just put a target on his back, and many of his state and even federal colleagues are scratching their heads trying to figure out what the bigger strategy is here. Is cunning genius or political self-destruction longer?\n\nFor months, reporters have been asking when and why the nuclear policy announcement was being delayed. Senior Coalition figures informed me that the opposition, knowing full well that Labor and others would throw everything to tear it apart, were doing their best to deliver a \"bulletproof\" policy that could 'resisted dissection and constant attack.\n\nHowever, when Dutton and his colleagues appeared before the media yesterday, they described a policy with many unanswered questions, including, most importantly, the actual cost of their nuclear proliferation. The coalition says it will reveal the cost in due course. But to leave such an important detail unanswered when the entire debate centers around the cost of energy leaves the policy vulnerable and impossible to critically assess.\n\nIt is amazing and unheard of for a major political party to put forward such a significant and important policy plan without the numbers attached.\n\nA senior Liberal suggested the delay in releasing the figures was to rob Labor of the ability to question the economic basis of policy that you can't pull back and choose the numbers that weren't given. Conventional policy would involve robust independent modeling and accounting disclosures to explain the cost to taxpayers.\n\nTony Barry, director of political research organization RedBridge Research and a former Liberal Party strategist, says the way the policy was announced leaves the Coalition vulnerable to criticism.\n\n\"It's not so much 'bulletproof' as wearing a high vest with a pin on it,\" Barry told me. \"The Coalition has to try to sell its product, while Labor just has to convince people not to buy it, and in that scenario, Labor has the easier job.\"\n\nAmong the many hurdles for the coalition to jump before it can develop a nuclear site will be state premiers, who have lined up against the plan to set up nuclear power plants at seven locations across the country. Peter Dutton says states' concerns were easy to address.\n\n\"Someone famously said, 'I would not stand between the Prime Minister and a bucket of money', and we have seen Prime Ministers in various debates before where they have been able to negotiate with the Commonwealth and will to be able to address those issues,\" he says.\n\nA coalition government would also be needed convince the federal parliament The Senate also lifts restrictions on nuclear power and finds a solution to nuclear waste. It will also have to build a nuclear workforce from scratch.\n\nIs it accessible? It would be a big departure from the usual Australian way of doing business.\n\nAnd then there is the issue of social license. Communities will need to get on board and provide support to build nuclear facilities in their neighborhood. The coalition says polls in some of these seats show support, if narrow.\n\nA survey published by the Lowy Institute Earlier this month out of 2,000 voters showed 61 per cent said they supported Australia including nuclear generation in its energy mix. Public opinion towards nuclear power in Australia has shifted over time. A significant minority (37 percent) \"somewhat\" or \"strongly\" oppose it. Those who \"strongly support\" nuclear power generation (27 percent) outnumber those who \"strongly oppose\" it (17 percent).\n\nBut on the issue of communities' rights to raise objections, nationalists were yesterday at odds.\n\nNationals leader David Littleproud contradicted his deputy, Perin Davey, who said that, \"if a community is absolutely determined then we will not continue\". But the Nationals leader later said Davey's claim was not \"correct\".\n\n\"Peter Dutton and David Littleproud, as part of a coalition government, are prepared to make tough decisions in the national interest. We will be consulting and making plenty of announcements.\"\n\nLoading\n\nPart of the motivation for this massive climate pivot is opposition to the spread of renewables. Given the controversy over poles and wires and their proliferation on the grounds that some communities don't want them, it seems likely that other communities will be pushed to accept the core.\n\nThe coalition is right to note some questions about the pace and cost of renewables deployment. But it's a big step to go from finding tepid support for renewables to assuming there will be full support for nuclear in the community.\n\nIf we accept that community opposition to the idea of nuclear is softening, though we cannot be sure by how much, then the struggle turns to cost.\n\nWill the Coalition be able to convince the public that nuclear will really give them cheaper bills? On this main issue, evidence has not been provided.\n\nTony Wood of the Grattan Institute says there are many unanswered questions about the Coalition's nuclear policy.\n\n\"This is such a fundamental change in direction that the opposition must provide a more compelling case than we might normally ask of opposition parties,\" he says.\n\n\"Everything we have so far says nuclear would be much more expensive. If the opposition gave a firm cost figure (even an order of magnitude) then others, including the Labor government, could compare it to plan A, which in itself is not free.\"\n\nWood says there's also a timing problem (as with Labour's 82 per cent renewables plan), which needs the shutdown of coal to match the start of nuclear.\n\n\"There seems to be a big gap here and it's not clear how the opposition plans to fill it.\"\n\nLoading...\n\nAn unusual part of the opposition's proposal is for the nuclear plants to be government owned and operated.\n\n\"Putting aside Labour's unusual position of pushing private capital and the Coalition pushing public capital, there are no numbers to back up the price claims,\" says Wood. \"I'm pretty sure that Dutton's claim that the high prices are due to Labour's renewables policies is simply wrong. Prices are coming down slightly from 1 July and they've gone up over the last two years for reasons that have little to do with renewable resources.\"\n\nHe added: \"If we abandon plan A, what will the opposition do about the emissions that will occur between now and when nuclear is in place?\"\n\nChris Bowen, the climate change and energy minister, branded Dutton's nuclear plan a \"dangerous nuclear hoax\" that raised more questions than answers.\n\nDutton says he is ready for the \"mother of all scare campaigns\" and welcomes a referendum on his nuclear plan.\n\nSo we are now in a new phase of the climate wars: the stakes are high for both Labor and the Coalition, and the debate will quickly move from atmosphere to detail.\n\nTony Barry points to a statistic he says should frame our thinking. When the debate on the Zeri referendum began, support was around 65 percent; by the time Australians voted, it was 39 percent.\n\nCampaigns matter, goodwill can be wasted.\n\nThere will now be months of debate about the merits of this big and controversial idea. Answers will be of great importance.\n\nPatricia Karvelas is the host of RN Breakfast and co-host of the Party Room podcast. {"uri": "8184693276", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "05:26:25", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T05:26:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T05:24:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/pa/article-13545569/Australian-opposition-announce-plans-nuclear-plants-ahead-elections.html", "title": "Australian opposition announce plans for first nuclear plants ahead...", "body": "Australia's opposition party on Wednesday announced plans to build the nation's first nuclear power plants as early as 2035.\n\nThe party argued the government's policies for decarbonising the economy with renewable energy sources, including solar, wind turbines, and green hydrogen, would not work.\n\nThe policy announcement ensures the major parties will be divided on how Australia will curb its greenhouse gas emissions at elections due within a year. The parties have not gone to an election with the same carbon reduction policies since 2007.\n\n\"I'm very happy for the election to be a referendum on energy, on nuclear, on power prices, on lights going out, on who has a sustainable pathway for our country going forward,\" Liberal Party leader Peter Dutton told reporters.\n\nAustralia\u00b4s then defense minister Peter Dutton addresses Parliament House in Canberra (Rod McGuirk/AP)\n\nSeven government-owned reactors would be built on the sites of ageing coal-fired electricity plants in five of Australia's six states, Mr Dutton said.\n\nThe first two would be built from 2035 to 2037 and the last in the 2040s. The estimated costs would be announced at a later date, he said.\n\nThe current centre-left government has rejected nuclear power generation in Australia as too expensive. Too many coal-fired generators would have been decommissioned before nuclear power could fill the gap.\n\nClimate change and energy minister Chris Bowen accused the Liberal Party of serving Australia's coal and gas industry lobbies.\n\n\"It's not really an announcement. We know that Mr Dutton wants to slow down the rollout of renewables and he wants to introduce the most expensive form of energy that's slow to build,\" Mr Bowen told reporters.\n\n\"But today, we've seen no costs, we've seen no gigawatts, we've seen no detail. This is a joke. It's a serious joke because it threatens our transition\" from fossil fuels,\" Mr Bowen added.\n\nMr Bowen's Labor Party came to power in the 2022 elections, promising deeper cuts to Australia's greenhouse gas emissions by 2030 than the previous coalition government had committed to.\n\nThe previous Liberal Party-led government promised to reduce emissions by between 26% and 28% below 2005 levels by the end of the decade.\n\nLabor promised a 43% reduction, and the Parliament enshrined that target in law, creating difficulties for any future government that wanted to reduce it and offering certainty for investors.\n\nMr Dutton has ruled out announcing a new 2030 target before the next election. However, the major parties have agreed on a net-zero emissions target by 2050.\n\nMr Dutton said Labor could not reach its 2030 target with a policy toward relying solely on renewable energy.\n\nA Liberal Party-led government would use nuclear power, renewable energy sources and \"significant amounts of gas\", Mr Dutton said.\n\n\"I want to make sure that the Australian public understands today that we have a vision for our country to deliver cleaner electricity, cheaper electricity and consistent electricity,\" he added.\n\nAustralia has historically been one of the world's worst greenhouse gas emitters on a per capita basis because of its heavy reliance on abundant reserves of cheap coal and gas.\n\nThe constant conflict between the major parties over the past 17 years on how to reduce emissions led to a carbon tax introduced by a Labor Party government in 2012 being repealed by a Liberal Party-led government in 2014.\n\nAustralia's only reactor has produced nuclear isotopes for medical use in the Sydney suburb of Lucas Heights since 1958.\n\nMr Dutton said the country could only now consider introducing atomic power generation because the major parties had agreed in 2019 to many of whom snatched previously safe Liberal seats in affluent parts of Sydney.\n\nHe wants to know:\n\n- Where nuclear reactors will be located\n\n- How the Coalition intends to remove state bans given nuclear is currently banned in Victoria, NSW and Queensland\n\n- What will happen if locals object\n\n- When will the reactors begin generating power\n\n- How much will they cost\n\n- How will the waste be managed\n\n- Who will provide disaster insurance\n\n- What will be the emissions impact\n\nHe said: 'Without good answers to the questions above, the Coalition cannot be taken seriously.\n\n'Any plan that has us paying more and blowing our carbon budget is a toxic joke.'\n\n23:06Announcement to be made at 10am\n\nPeter Dutton will hold a joint press conference at 10am to make his pitch to the Australian public.\n\nIt is understood he'll be joined by Nationals leader David Littleproud, and Liberal deputy leader Sussan Ley.\n\n23:01Labor comes out swinging against nuclear\n\nTreasurer Jim Chalmers on Wednesday trashed Mr Dutton's nuclear ambitions, describing it as 'economic insanity, pure and simple'.\n\nDr Chalmers told ABC Radio: 'Nuclear takes longer, it costs more, and it will squander Australia's unique combination of advantages. {"uri": "8186157803", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "01:33:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T01:33:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T01:31:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://thewest.com.au/news/peter-dutton-defends-uncosted-nuclear-power-announcement-c-15082912", "title": "'Fantasy': Albo slams Dutton's nuclear push", "body": "Peter Dutton defends uncosted nuclear power announcementJack QuailNewsWireThu, 20 June 2024 9:30AM\n\nOpposition Leader Peter Dutton has hit back at critics of the Coalition's nuclear power plan, defending the decision not to release the policy's cost which is expected to have a multi-billion price tag.\n\nSpeaking on Thursday morning, Mr Dutton said the Coalition had deliberately not released the full details while committing to present the costings \"fairly shortly\".\n\n\"We've got a staged approach here. If we just dumped all of this information out at once, people wouldn't be able to consume it,\" Mr Dutton told 2GB.\n\n\"So we've deliberately taken it step by step.\"\n\nTheNightlyGet in front of tomorrow's news for FREE\n\nJournalism for the curious Australian across politics, business, culture and opinion.\n\nREAD NOW\n\nOn Wednesday, the Coalition unveiled plans to build seven nuclear power plants by 2050 with the first reactor slated to be operational in just over a decade in a move designed to deliver cheaper, zero-emissions and reliable power supply.\n\nNED-12332-The Coalitions-proposed-nuclear-power-stations\n\nContrasting with Labor's approach which will be largely reliant on renewable energy, Mr Dutton called for Australians to have an \"adult conversation\" on the merits of nuclear energy.\n\n\"I honestly believe it's in our country's best interest and we have the ability to set ourselves up economically for generations to come,\" Mr Dutton said.\n\n\"What we're proposing now shows a very stark contrast to the intermittent power and the continued increases in costs and blackouts and brownouts that will feature in the coming years under Labor policy.\"\n\nA recent report from Australia's peak scientific body CSIRO estimated that building a large-scale nuclear power plant in Australia would cost approximately $8.5bn and take at least 15 years to deliver, longer than the Coalition's 10-year timeline.\n\nResponding to the Coalition's intervention, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese labelled the proposal a \"fantasy\" which \"didn't make sense\".\n\n\"There's no costings, there's no serious time frame, there's no proportion of how much nuclear will be as part of their energy system, there's no details on what type of reactor,\" he said.\n\nThe Prime Minister also took aim at the Coalition's lack of community consultation, arguing it was unclear whether they would ignore the regional communities affected if they pushed back against hosting a nuclear power plant.\n\n\"Are these seven sites going to get nuclear reactors imposed on them, must be said, sometime two decades away?\" he said.\n\n\"Is the consultation process just going through the motions? They can't say whether they haven't provided a real one or not.\"\n\nOriginally published as Peter Dutton defends uncosted nuclear power announcement\n\nGet the latest news from thewest.com.au in your {"uri": "2024-06-394113239", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "02:36:53", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T02:36:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T02:03:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://www.news.com.au/technology/environment/sustainability/nsw-victoria-qld-premiers-denounce-peter-duttons-nuclear-plan/news-story/6a9ceb049ea44ff3c3f8e335ba4ea349", "title": "'Toxic, risky': Dutton's nuclear plan lashed", "body": "NSW Premier Chris Minns has led the call from state leaders denouncing Opposition Leader Peter Dutton's plans to build seven nuclear reactors across the country.\n\nOn Wednesday, the Liberal leader made an election pledge to build at least two of the government-owned nuclear plants between 2035 and 2037 at existing coal power stations in Liddell and Mount Piper in NSW, Tarong and Callide in Queensland, Victoria's La Trobe Valley, Collie in Western Australia and Port Augusta in South Australia.\n\nSpeaking to reporters on Wednesday morning, Mr Minns said his government had no plans to remove the state's prohibition on nuclear power plants in NSW.\n\nHe questioned how Mr Dutton would constitutionally force states to build nuclear reactors, with energy policy and infrastructure falling under the purview of state governments.\n\n\"Firstly, it costs a lot of money. Secondly, it takes a lot of time and we don't have a day to wait, and I don't think NSW consumers can pay anymore when it comes to energy prices,\" he said.\n\n\"The last estimate I saw was that nuclear power generation in this state to replace coal-fired power would cost between $70 to $200bn. Who are they going to send that bill to?\"\n\nMr Minns said NSW would continue to prioritise investment into renewable energy, which aims to create at least 12 gigawatts of renewable energy and two gigawatts of long-duration storage by 2030.\n\nA sudden transition to nuclear energy would also threaten the $30bn of private capital investment in renewable energy, with Mr Minns labelling Mr Dutton's policy as a \"sovereign risk\".\n\n\"If all of a sudden you were to introduce nuclear power, that investment is at real risk, and I think that's a sovereign risk for energy and particularly for the narrow path we have to walk to revolutionise our energy sectors in the state.\"\n\nHis concerns were echoed by his fellow Labor premiers in Victoria and Queensland.\n\nVictorian Premier Jacinta Allen also lashed Mr Dutton's nuclear policy and vowed to stand with the Gippsland community.\n\n\"This is the Liberal Party solutions to the challenges of transitioning our energy mix in this country,\" he said.\n\n\"They want to bring more expensive, more risky, more toxic energy solutions to the people of this country. We won't stand for that. We absolutely will not stand for that.\"\n\nShe also called on the state opposition, including Victorian Opposition Leader John Pesutto, to denounce the policy.\n\n\"So unlike the Liberal and National parties who have abandoned time and again the Gippsland community, we will stand with them, we will support them in fighting against this proposal to bring toxic and risky nuclear reactors to the beautiful Gippsland community,\" she said.\n\n\"The question is will their state Liberal National Party representatives also do this?\"\n\nHistorically, Queensland Premier Steven Miles, who will face an election in November this year, has also dudded nuclear energy as financially untenable despite support from the state opposition.\n\n\"What we know about those nuclear reactors is that they will be much more expensive. As much as five times more expensive for your household power bills,\" he said in a May press release.\n\n\"We also know that as a result of those reactors, future generations of Queenslanders will have to manage nuclear waste forever.\"\n\nMr Dutton said he would be open to working with premiers in a \"constructive way\" if the Coalition was reinstalled at the next yet-to-be-announced federal election.\n\n\"As you know, somebody famously said I would not stand between the Premier and a bucket of money, and we've seen the premiers in different debates before where they've been able to "https://content.api.news/v3/images/bin/aa3c5ab789d6f378e1842d0d3663d114", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9662030", "eventUri": "eng-9662030", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, {"uri": "8186082714", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "23:50:00", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T23:50:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T23:48:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://www.abc.net.au/news/2024-06-20/nuclear-dutton-coalition-unanswered-questions-beak-rules/104000664", "title": "Peter Dutton has placed a target on his back. Is his nuclear policy cunning genius or political self-destruction?", "body": "Peter Dutton has broken every single rule when it comes to unveiling radical policy as opposition leader, tearing up the script and gambling with his party's chances at the next election with his nuclear policy.\n\nIf he can pull it off and convince enough voters that his blueprint for an Australian nuclear future is feasible and preferable, it will be the most unorthodox approach we've seen from an opposition leader in recent memory. It will rewrite our understanding of how modern politics works and radically Australia.\n\nDutton has just placed a target on his back -- and many of his state and even federal colleagues are scratching their heads trying to work out what the larger strategy here is. Is it cunning genius or the longest political self-destruction?\n\nFor months journalists have been inquiring about when and why the nuclear policy announcement was being delayed. Senior Coalition figures informed me that the Opposition -- knowing full well that Labor and others would throw everything at pulling it apart -- were doing their most comprehensive piece of work to deliver a \"bullet proof\" policy that could withstand dissection and sustained attack.\n\nYet when Dutton and his colleagues stood up before the media yesterday, they outlined a policy with many questions unanswered -- including, most crucially, the actual cost of their nuclear rollout. The Coalition says it will reveal the cost down the track. But to leave unanswered such a crucial detail when the entire debate is centred around the cost of energy leaves the policy vulnerable and impossible to critically assess.\n\nIt is stunning and unheard of for a mainstream political party to put forward such a significant and consequential policy blueprint without the numbers attached.\n\nOne senior Liberal suggested the delay in releasing the figures was to rob Labor of the ability to question the economic basis of the policy -- you can't pull and pick apart numbers that haven't been provided. Conventional politics would involve the unveiling of modelling and robust independent accounting to explain the cost for taxpayers.\n\nTony Barry, the director of political research organisation RedBridge Research, and a former Liberal Party strategist, says the way the policy had been announced made the Coalition vulnerable to criticism.\n\n\"It isn't so much 'bullet proof' but rather wearing a high-vis vest with a bullseye on it,\" Barry told me. \"The Coalition has to try and sell its product while Labor only has to convince people not to buy it, and in that scenario Labor has the easier job.\"\n\nAmong the many hurdles for the Coalition to jump before it can even develop a nuclear site will be the state premiers, who have lined up against this blueprint to establish nuclear power plants at seven locations across the country. Peter Dutton says the states' concerns were easy to deal with.\n\n\"Somebody famously said, 'I would not stand between the premier and a bucket of money', and we've seen the premiers in different debates before where they've been able to negotiate with the Commonwealth and will be able to address those issues,\" he says.\n\nA Coalition government would also have to convince federal parliament -- the Senate too -- to lift restrictions on nuclear power and find a solution for nuclear waste. It would also have to build a nuclear workforce from scratch.\n\nIs it achievable? It would be a big departure from the usual way Australia does business.\n\nAnd then there's the question of social license. Communities would need to get on board and provide support to build nuclear facilities in their neighbourhood. The Coalition says polling in some of these seats shows that there is support -- even if it's tight.\n\nA poll released by the Lowy Institute earlier this month of 2,000 voters showed 61 per cent said they supported Australia including nuclear generation in its energy mix. Public opinion towards nuclear power in Australia has shifted over time. A significant minority (37 per cent) \"somewhat\" or \"strongly\" oppose it. Those who \"strongly support\" nuclear power generation (27 per cent) outnumber those who \"strongly oppose\" it (17 per cent).\n\nBut on the question of the rights of communities to raise objections, the Nationals were at odds yesterday.\n\nNationals leader David Littleproud contradicted his deputy Perin Davey, who said that, \"if a community is absolutely adamant then we will not proceed\". But the Nationals leader later said Davey's claim was \"not correct\".\n\n\"Peter Dutton and David Littleproud, as part of a Coalition government, are prepared to make the tough decisions in the national interest. We will consult, and we will give plenty of notice.\"\n\nPart of the motivation for this massive climate pivot is the opposition to the rollout in renewables. Given the controversy on poles and wires and their rollout on the basis that some communities don't want them it seems a stretch that other communities would be pushed to accept nuclear.\n\nThe Coalition is right to observe some questioning of the pace and cost of the renewables rollout. But it's a big leap to go from detecting softening support for renewables to assuming there will be full-blown support of nuclear in the community.\n\nIf we accept that community opposition to the idea of nuclear is softening -- although we can't be sure of how much -- then the fight shifts to cost.\n\nWill the Coalition be able to convince the public that nuclear will really give them cheaper bills? On this pivotal question the evidence has not been provided.\n\nTony Wood from the Grattan Institute says there are many unanswered questions about the Coalition's nuclear policy.\n\n\"This is such a fundamental change in direction that the Opposition needs to provide a more compelling case than we might normally demand of opposition parties,\" he says.\n\n\"Everything we have so far says nuclear would be much more expensive. If the Opposition provided a supportable cost figure (even order-of-magnitude) then others, including the Labor government can compare that with Plan A, which itself is not cheap\".\n\nWood says there is also a timing problem (as with Labor's 82 per cent renewables plan) which needs the coal shutdown to align with the nuclear startup.\n\n\"There would seem to be a big gap here and it's not clear how the Opposition is planning to fill it.\"\n\nAn unusual part of the Opposition's proposal is that the nuclear plants would government-owned and operated.\n\n\"Putting aside the unusual position for Labor to be pushing private capital and the Coalition pushing public capital, there are no numbers to support the price claims,\" Wood says. \"I am pretty sure that Dutton's claim that high prices are down to Labor's renewables policies is just wrong. Prices are coming down a tad from July 1 and they went up over the last two years for reasons that had little to do with renewables.\"\n\nHe added: \"If we abandon Plan A, what will the Opposition do about the emissions that will occur between now and when the nuclear is in place\".\n\nChris Bowen, the minister for climate change and energy, labelled Dutton's nuclear plan as a \"risky nuclear scam\" that raised more questions than answers.\n\nDutton says he is ready for \"the mother of all scare campaigns\" and welcomes a referendum on his nuclear plan.\n\nSo we are now in a new phase of the climate wars: the stakes are high for both Labor and the Coalition and the debate will quickly move from the vibe to the detail.\n\nTony Barry points to one statistic that he says should be framing our thinking. When the Voice referendum debate started support was around 65 per cent; by the time Australians voted it was 39 per cent.\n\nCampaigns matter, good will can be squandered.\n\nThere will now be months of discussion about the merits of this big and controversial idea. The answers will matter enormously.", "source": {"uri": "abc.net.au", "dataType": "news", "title": "Australian Broadcasting Corporation"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8186773276", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "10:01:52", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T10:01:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T10:01:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://www.afr.com/politics/federal/dutton-is-prepared-to-take-risks-but-he-is-no-onion-eater-20240620-p5jn9w", "title": "Nuclear energy: Peter Dutton", "body": "Even if scepticism lingers over the Coalition's motives, given its track record on climate policy, the argument between now and the next election will be over the best way to go about it, not whether the Earth is round or flat. Small mercy indeed.\n\nIt bears repeating that Dutton has undertaken a sizeable risk, on a par with John Hewson's release of Fightback! more than a year before the 1993 election.\n\nA key difference between then and now is that, at 650 pages, Fightback! contained an extraordinary amount of detail, allowing it to be skewered by Paul Keating.\n\nIt will further increase growing concerns inside Labor that it is the Coalition leader who has set the agenda.\n\nDutton's nuclear plan is light on detail. He revealed the proposed sites for five large-scale reactors and two small modular reactors, with a rough aim to have the first one running by either 2035 or 2037.\n\nAll would be government-owned, using the same model as the Commonwealth's Snowy Hydro Limited, but that's pretty much it.\n\nAnother more recent comparison is then-Labor leader Bill Shorten unveiling so much policy before the 2019 election, including franking credits and an uncosted climate policy, that it cost him the Lodge.\n\nBoth 1993 and 2019, however, were considered \"unlosable\" elections for Hewson and Shorten. This time, Dutton has nothing to lose.\n\nUnderstandably, the government zeroed in on Dutton's lack of costings and pointed to examples overseas where large-scale power stations were costing tens of billions of dollars to build.\n\nBut Dutton and his energy spokesman, Ted O'Brien, were quick to assure full costings - which would include a business case that would ameliorate the build costs - would be released before the election, as would the Coalition's plans for renewables, gas and batteries.\n\n\"Storage will be important,\" says O'Brien.\n\nThey are implying that people should reserve their judgment until the full policy, of which nuclear will be a key but not the sole component, is released.\n\nDutton is advancing his strategy in three stages.\n\nFirst, how to deal with nuclear waste, was done for him when Labor embraced the AUKUS pact and committed to setting up a high-level waste repository in Commonwealth land.\n\nThe second came on Wednesday when the object was to confirm the sites. Given the stigma that has been attached to nuclear power, it's always the easiest aspect of a scare campaign, and Labor was gaining traction with memes of pristine coastal landscapes being blighted by giant cooling towers.\n\nOn this front, Dutton as a minister, learnt the lesson in the run-up to the 2007 election when John Howard examined the feasibility of nuclear power by asking nuclear physicist and businessman Ziggy Switkowski to undertake a review.\n\nUltimately, Howard baulked at following through due to internal misgivings by climate-sceptical colleagues, and due to a very successful scare campaign led by a young shadow environment minister named Anthony Albanese, who produced maps showing the east coast festooned with nuclear power stations.\n\nThe Coalition polled the communities around the planned sites for its seven reactors and said support in all seven was above 50 per cent, with the highest being 60 per cent. Not overwhelming but better than expected, said a source.\n\nThis was backed by focus group research, the outtakes from which included \"these communities are used to having energy in their backyard, and shifting from coal to nuclear isn't difficult for them to consider\".\n\n\"They are worried about what happens when the coal plants close. These areas need industry. They don't understand how they will have jobs in solar or wind.\"\n\nThat's not to say it won't be difficult. Significant objections have already arisen in the West Australian town of Collie, the proposed site of a small modular reactor.\n\nNationally, Labor MPs are distributing memes of three-eyed fish to demonise nuclear energy, but Dutton believes this will fail.\n\nAfter all, South Australian Labor Premier Peter Malinauskas says his only concern with Dutton's proposal is the potential cost, not the technology.\n\nDutton believes that having neutralised as best as possible fears over waste and sites, the third and final stage will be to make it all about cost of living, and that will come when the costings are released. Because that is what the election will be all about.\n\nThe suggestion is that these costings will purport power prices to be cheaper than under Labor's model, once the thousands of kilometres of transmission infrastructure that Labor's plan will require are factored in.\n\nThe CSIRO argued the opposite in its GenCost report released last month, but O'Brien contends the CSIRO's assumptions were flawed because they understated both the life-span and operating frequency of the power plants.\n\nSwitkowski, who was consulted by Dutton before the plan was released, believes nuclear is feasible as part of the energy mix, and that the opposition leader was right to relate it to climate change.\n\nHis 2006 report concluded nuclear power would be 20 per cent to 50 per cent more expensive than coal-fired electricity, meaning it would not be viable without a price on carbon and the support of government subsidies.\n\nMuch has changed since then.\n\n\"There is no reason I can think of as to why it should be so uniquely difficult to build more nuclear reactors,\" Switkowski said.\n\nHe and O'Brien agree with the CSIRO's build cost estimates of $8.6 billion for large reactors and around $3 billion for an SMR.\n\nSwitkowski said the power plants could be successfully monetised and ultimately taxpayers would be better off.\n\nOnce up and running, they could be privatised, or the government could retain full ownership, or an equity stake.\n\nInevitably, all these arguments and more will be ventilated over coming weeks and months, which suits the Coalition fine.\n\nIt will further increase growing concerns inside Labor that ever since last month's federal budget, the Coalition leader has set the agenda.\n\nAnd hope as they might, he's not going to eat
