{"uri": "2024-06-394948677", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "16:23:18", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T16:23:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T16:00:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://www.abc.net.au/listen/programs/abc-news-daily/peter-dutton-and-the-seven-nuclear-reactors/103999002", "title": "Peter Dutton and the seven nuclear reactors", "body": "Sam Hawley: It's a big gamble, but will it pay off? Peter Dutton is going all in on nuclear energy, announcing seven sites for reactors and setting the stage for an energy referendum at the next election. The choice for voters, do you want a renewable future or a nuclear one? Today, the ABC's national political lead and Insider's host, David Speers, on what will be one of the biggest policy debates of our time. I'm Sam Hawley on Gadigal land in Sydney. This is ABC News Daily.\n\nPeter Dutton: Today we announce seven locations that we have looked at in great detail over a long period of time that can host new nuclear sites. We have a vision for our country to deliver cleaner electricity, cheaper electricity and consistent electricity.\n\nDavid Littleproud: It's about a vision for regional Australia, one that isn't covered in solar panels and wind turbines and transmission lines.\n\nSussan Ley: Our nuclear plan will put our country back on track.\n\nSam Hawley: Speersy, if you thought the Coalition wasn't actually serious about nuclear, you were wrong, right?\n\nDavid Speers: Yeah, look, they are deadly serious about this and they've been talking it up for months and months that the policy announcement would come. Now it's come, at least in part. We don't yet have the cost of all of this. We'll come to that, but we do have the locations. Even just giving these locations and making the commitment they've made is a big political gamble. It's up there, I think, with oppositions trying to do big things like Bill Shorten's tax plans, John Hewson's fightback plan. Now Peter Dutton is saying he'll go to the election with a nuclear policy plan and it's in large part driven by the Nationals, the junior partner in the Coalition, very worried about the rollout of big renewable projects and transmission lines in the regions and they reckon simply replacing retiring coal-fired plants with nuclear means you solve a lot of those problems. You can just plug them into the existing transmission and problem is solved.\n\nSam Hawley: All right, so this is a big announcement from Peter Dutton and it will be a huge part of the battle at the next election, clearly. Just tell me then, what did he say? Where are these seven nuclear reactors going to be if, of course, the Coalition wins the election?\n\nDavid Speers: So they're all on the sites of retiring coal-fired power plants and remember that 90 per cent of our coal fleet is due to go in the next decade. So in New South Wales, the Liddell Power Station, which is already closed, and the Mount Piper Power Station, the Loy Yang Power Stations in Victoria, in Queensland, the Tarong Power Station and the Callide Power Station near Biloela, the Northern Power Station in South Australia and the Muja Power Station in WA. So they're dotted around and the idea, as I say, is to simply use that existing infrastructure to build a nuclear plant so that you can plug it straight into the network.\n\nSam Hawley: Yes, and five of the seven are actually in Coalition seats, that's worth noting. So when are they going to be built, did he say?\n\nDavid Speers: Good question. So the first two, he expects, would come between 2035 and 2037. The rest wouldn't come until the 2040s. The idea here is to have them all up and running so that we can still hit net zero by 2050. But, of course, what it would mean for emissions in the meantime is very unclear. The Coalition is not going to be taking any interim emissions targets to the election, nor is it clear what the cost of all of this would be. But those first two could be either large or small-scale reactors.\n\nSam Hawley: OK, because the Coalition, of course, is dumping the 2030 target under the Paris Agreement.\n\nDavid Speers: That's right. They think it's unachievable, the one the government has set, but they're not even going to take a less ambitious target to the election. Peter Dutton last week made that clear, that he will wait until he's in government to work out what that interim target should be. He says that means he'd still stay in the Paris Agreement and still hit that 2050 emissions target. And really this whole nuclear plan is about having a feasible way of hitting 2050 net zero, but without having to really reduce emissions much at all before then.\n\nSam Hawley: As you mentioned, Speersy, they haven't said how much this is actually going to cost, but we do know it's wildly expensive, right, to build a nuclear reactor. Massively expensive.\n\nDavid Speers: Yeah. Expensive to build and expensive in terms of the power that's generated, according to the CSIRO. Last month the CSIRO and the energy market operator released their GenCost report, most detailed research really into what this would cost, the nuclear option, and it found large-scale, a fair bit cheaper than the small modular reactors, but even the large-scale reactors would cost about $17 billion for the first one and then about $8 billion for each one after that. The power generated would be about double the cost of renewables backed by firming, and that is pumped hydro batteries and so on. So renewables with firming, still half the price of what nuclear power would be. The Coalition took issue with that report. They say a few inputs are wrong and that they don't buy it. They think power would be cheaper under their plan, but they haven't produced any detail to explain how.\n\nSam Hawley: Speersy, there has been really deep concern, I guess, leading up to this announcement about how viable this policy actually is. I mean, there's been a number of analysts and scientists saying that, number one, as we've discussed, it's really, really expensive, but also they argue, I think, that it's come too late, that we've missed the boat, that now is not the time, that it's a risky move, right?\n\nDavid Speers: Yeah, the consensus seems to be the best time for Australia to go nuclear would have been 20 years ago. Yes. And certainly in the nine years they were in office, most recently under the Abbott, Turnbull, Morrison governments, they didn't go down this path at all. The Nats would bowl it up from time to time and it kept getting knocked back. Now we're at a point where a lot of renewables are already being rolled out. And so the problem here is how does nuclear fit in with that and is it too late? Have we missed the boat on nuclear? Yes, plenty of other countries are doing it, and the simple pitch from Peter Dutton is, well, if everyone else can do it, why can't we? They all started a lot earlier and they don't have the renewable resources that we have in Australia with plenty of sunshine and wind in particular. So look, if you start now and you don't get one of these nuclear plants at the earliest for another 10 or 12 years and the full fleet for another 20 or so years, what happens in the meantime? What are we relying on and what does that mean for our power prices? Now, Peter Dutton wants to string out as long as possible the existing coal-fired plants and use a lot more gas. But given the ageing fleet that we're talking about and the price of gas, again, it's unknown whether it would be any cheaper. He says it would, but we just don't have that detail.\n\nSam Hawley: And as you say, we were debating this 20 years ago. The Coalition was debating whether or not it was a good idea. And then, of course, in 1998, John Howard actually banned nuclear power. So it's not even legal here. That would have to change too.\n\nDavid Speers: That's the first big hurdle. It was John Howard who did that deal with the Greens, in fact, to put a ban on nuclear power. It was part of an arrangement that - a compromise that included an expansion of the Lucas Heights Medical Research Reactor. But, yeah, removing that ban would have to be the first thing a Dutton Coalition government would have to do. And while they might win in the House of Representatives, they would still face a crossbench in the Senate that they would have to convince. Then you've got the states who have their own bans in place and the states are all opposed to what he's talking about at the moment as well. He reckons you could win them over with a bucket of money. He referenced Paul Keating's famous quote about never standing in between a Premier and a bucket of money. But, you know, again, how much money are we talking here on top of the price of these nuclear power plants themselves? So a lot of hurdles to overcome.\n\nSam Hawley: Yeah, absolutely. Victoria's Premier, Jacinta Allan, she's been out there saying, no way, it's too toxic and it's risky.\n\nJacinta Allan: This is the Liberal Party's solution to the challenges of transitioning our energy mix in this country. They want to bring more expensive, more risky, more toxic energy solutions to the people of this country and we won't stand for that. We absolutely won't...\n\nSam Hawley: So she's definitely not on board at this point.\n\nDavid Speers: Yeah, and even more politically difficult for Peter Dutton is that his own Queensland LNP colleague, David Crisafulli, who is opposed to this nuclear plan as well, he could well be Premier by the end of the year after the Queensland election.\n\nJournalist: Do you support the Coalition's newly announced nuclear policy?\n\nDavid Crisafulli: We've been very consistent, it's not part of our plan. That's a matter for Canberra.\n\nDavid Speers: So even on his own side of politics, there's resistance at the state level.\n\nSam Hawley: And obviously the government totally rejects this idea.\n\nJim Chalmers: Nuclear takes longer, it costs more, and it will squander Australia's unique combination of advantages. It is the worst combination of economic and ideological stupidity.\n\nSam Hawley: It says, of course, that it threatens our green transition.\n\nDavid Speers: Well, it certainly does threaten the transition to renewables, the path that we're on, because yes, Peter Dutton is saying he'd prefer to keep those coal-fired power plants running much longer, use more gas as well, and clearly there's hostility towards these big renewable projects in the regions from the Nationals and from the Liberals. Look, there are obviously difficulties in this energy transition, no doubt about it, and yes, energy prices have risen and Peter Dutton is really tapping into those concerns about costs, about the impact on the regions of all the transmission lines required for wind and solar projects as well, and that's why he's saying that the much simpler solution is this nuclear idea.\n\nSam Hawley: Alright, well, Speersy, let's have a look then at whether this is really what Australians want, because this is going to be, as we mentioned, a key election issue now, whether you support the government's push to renewables or you want nuclear. This is, isn't it, the climate war's back with a vengeance?\n\nDavid Speers: Yeah, and in fact, Peter Dutton, he said that he's happy to have a referendum at the election on energy and nuclear. Now, it's clear that he really wants to focus and tap into the anger that's there in the regions and elsewhere about power prices and about issues around the renewables rollout, whether it's wind farms, transmission lines, this is where he really wants to focus people's attention. But he also has to defend his alternative and what that would all mean, and it's difficult to defend when we don't have many of the details around the cost, the impact on power prices, but it's a big gamble. Polls have shown growing support for nuclear power. There was a Lowy Institute poll only a couple of weeks ago, which had supported about 61 per cent. So the principal idea of nuclear isn't proving to be a turn-off according to the data we've seen so far. Now that we move into a more informed debate about what the Coalition are planning, perhaps the polling will be more relevant, will tell us a little more about how Australians feel, particularly in some of those local communities as well, where there's so far been a mixed reaction to the idea of having a nuclear plant down the road.\n\nSam Hawley: This is going to be a very different battlefield this time around, right, with two very distinct policies. There's a real choice there when it comes to climate.\n\nDavid Speers: There's a big choice there now, absolutely, two very different visions as to what the Australian energy market and therefore the Australian economy should look like. And yes, there are big risks for Peter Dutton. It's hard to see how this and dropping any notion of a 2030 target going into the election, how that helps the Coalition win back those teal seats. They really do need to win back to have any chance at forming government. Now Peter Dutton will be hoping that this plays more strongly in the suburbs and the regions in particular, and there are a handful of seats where, yes, concerns over cost of living are much higher and this might be appealing to some, but the government's task is to really focus minds on what the cost of this nuclear alternative would be, both in terms of the debt the taxpayers would have to rack up and the power price impact as well. This is where the contest will be fought.\n\nSam Hawley: Yes, and these are two very different paths for Australia, two very different Australias, depending on who wins.\n\nDavid Speers: Yes, a renewable future or a nuclear future.\n\nSam Hawley: David Speers is the ABC's national political lead and the host of Insiders, which goes to air on Sunday mornings on ABC TV. This episode was produced by Bridget Fitzgerald, Jess O'Callaghan. Audio production by Sam Dunn. Our supervising producer is David Coady. I'm Sam Hawley. ABC News Daily will be back again tomorrow. {"uri": "8185538574", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "15:11:36", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T15:11:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T15:07:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/does-coalition-case-nuclear-power-150012104.html", "title": "Does the Coalition's case for nuclear power stack up? We factcheck seven key claims", "body": "The Coalition has made a range of claims about what nuclear energy could do for Australia, and why it is better than building solar and wind.\n\nWhat is the reality? We factcheck the key claims.\n\nNo evidence - such as economic modelling - has been produced to back up the opposition leader, Peter Dutton's main argument about nuclear energy: that it would make Australians' electricity bills cheaper than under a renewable-energy run grid and bring down other costs. As things stand, it is a baseless claim.\n\nThe CSIRO and the Australian Energy Market Operator (Aemo) have assessed the cost of different electricity sources and found that solar and wind backed by storage energy, new transmission lines and other \"firming\" - what the country is building now, in other words - were the cheapest option.\n\nThey found nuclear generation would be significantly more expensive - the most expensive technology available - for consumers. They suggested Australia's first large-scale nuclear power plant (1GW capacity) could cost about $17bn, not counting finance costs. If a nuclear industry established that might eventually drop to $8.6bn.\n\nRelated: 'Raises red flags': Coalition nuclear power plan met with widespread scepticism from business groups\n\nSmall modular nuclear reactors (SMRs), a developing technology that the Coalition has suggested could be used in South Australia and Western Australia, are likely to be far more expensive again. They do not exist anywhere on a commercial basis. The leading proposal for an SMR in the US was last year cancelled due to rising cost.\n\nConfronted with this, the Coalition argues the nuclear experience in Ontario, Canada, demonstrates that nuclear energy is cheaper than Australian renewable energy.\n\nThis is not a relevant comparison. Like France, Ontario runs on nuclear plants built decades ago. Construction costs in the 1980s tell us nothing about the costs in the 2030s and 2040s.\n\nEven then, the claim electricity is cheaper in Ontario is misleading. Wholesale electricity prices - the only part of the bill that is affected by the cost of generation - in Ontario are actually higher than the cost of new firmed renewable energy in Victoria and Queensland.\n\nA more relevant comparison may be the ongoing construction of the large Hinkley C generator in the UK. It was initially expected to open in 2017 and cost about A$34bn. That has now been pushed out to 2031, and up to A$89bn.\n\nThere is no evidence it will.\n\nGas is the most expensive form of electricity generation currently used in the National Electricity Market, connecting the five eastern states and the ACT.\n\nThe price of gas is set on the international market - what fossil fuel companies can get by selling the gas in Asia. Nearly all Australian gas is exported. Opening a couple of new gas fields is not likely to materially change this.\n\nCurrently, gas is used in \"peaking\" plants that are turned on only when needed, at times of high demand. This is expected to continue for at least the next couple of decades. Gas-fired power provided less than 5% of total generation last year.\n\nThe Coalition has not explained how it would get more gas into the electricity grid. Would taxpayers pay to build several new gas power plants? It has also not explained how the resulting power could be as cheap as renewable energy.\n\nNo. Using more gas, less renewable energy and extending the life of coal-fired power plants will increase Australia's greenhouse gas emissions.\n\nThe Coalition admits this. It wants to abandon the country's 2030 emissions target and allow significantly more heat-trapping pollution while arguing it is still committed to net zero by 2050.\n\nAgain, no evidence has been released to explain how this would be possible. The experience in developed democracies internationally is that it would take much longer.\n\nThe Coalition says if it decided to build SMRs there could be \"two establishment projects\" in place by 2035. If it opts for large-scale plants it says first power would be in 2037.\n\nCSIRO found an initial nuclear power plant of any size would not be possible until after 2040. Other analysts, including the pro-nuclear Blueprint Institute, agree.\n\nThat's just the technology challenge. The Coalition would also have to get legislation through both houses of federal parliament to overturn a nuclear energy ban. Labor and most of the cross-bench oppose lifting the ban, and the Coalition is 20 seats short of a majority in the lower house and hasn't had a majority in the Senate since 2007.\n\nIt would also need to persuade three states that ban nuclear energy - and remain strongly committed to their current position - to change their laws.\n\nNo. It has a much smaller effect than factors related to fossil fuels.\n\nTony Wood, the energy and climate change program director for the Grattan Institute, says there was a 20% jump in wholesale electricity costs last year for four reasons: the war in Ukraine pushing up the price of gas; gas shortages; outages at ageing coal power plants reducing competition; and extreme weather causing flooding at coalmines. Prices have since started to come back down.\n\nThe renewable energy in the system has a smaller effect on price as the cost of incentive schemes is passed on, but it also helps reduce costs by increasing capacity and competition in the power grid.\n\nRelated: Peter Dutton names seven potential nuclear power station sites but avoids questions on cost\n\nThe coal-fired power plants in the grid are ageing, increasingly have units offline and need to be replaced. Evidence from government agencies and most independent experts is that renewable energy plus firming is the best path to an affordable, reliable, clean grid.\n\nNo. The lights are still on.\n\nCoalition MPs making this claim were referring to the findings of Aemo's \"electricity statement of opportunities\" report, which was portrayed as warning blackouts were imminent.\n\nThis misrepresents what the statement does. It is a message to the industry about how much more generation will be needed over time. This year's statement found there could be reliability gaps in NSW, Queensland, South Australia and Victoria unless there was faster deployment of renewable energy and batteries.\n\nThis is consistent with other warnings that investment has slowed and needs to accelerate. But Aemo did not say blackouts were inevitable, or that renewable energy would cause them.\n\nNo - again, based on evidence from experts and industry.\n\nThe energy and economic transformation is challenging whatever technology is used. But the electrons are the same, regardless of the source.\n\nIndustry leaders have repeatedly welcomed renewable energy investment. Rio Tinto this year signed what it called Australia's largest renewable energy power purchase agreement to run its operations in Gladstone.\n\nBlueScope Steel applauded the creation of an offshore windfarm zone in the Illawarra, saying it had the \"potential to supply significant quantities of renewable energy to help underpin BlueScope's decarbonisation of iron and steelmaking in Australia\".\n\nAemo has repeatedly found an optimal future power grid, including one that would power new green industries, would run on more than 90% renewable energy.\n\nOther countries, including those with some nuclear power, have similar goals. Both the US and Germany are targeting 80% renewable energy by 2030.", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8184936699", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "08:33:16", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T08:33:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T08:31:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.theage.com.au/national/nsw/unanswered-questions-dog-dutton-s-nuclear-dream-20240619-p5jmzu.html", "title": "Unanswered questions dog Dutton's nuclear dream", "body": "Save articles for later\n\nAdd articles to your saved list and come back to them any time.\n\nGot it\n\nThe Nuclear Energy Institute estimates that one nuclear reactor needs billions of litres of water per year for cooling, and \"all of this water requires filtering somehow\" (\"Dutton reveals locations for seven nuclear power plants under Coalition plan\", smh.com.au, June 19). As nuclear reactors need to be operational 24/7 and can't be switched on and off at short notice to cover peak demand times, where does Dutton suggest this water will come from for his chosen sites? Dam and river supplies will not suffice in times of drought, and the tritium and other radioactive substances released from nuclear plants are not suitable to be released into rivers that supply downstream towns and agricultural areas. Does his timeframe also include the decommissioning and deconstruction of the current coal-fired power plants, or does he propose to plonk them on top or next to the current power plants? And any plan for dealing with the radioactive nuclear waste produced that will remain radioactive for tens of thousands of years? Alan Marel, North Curl Curl\n\nCountries around the world have indicated they will impose trade barriers on other countries that are not pulling their weight in reducing their carbon emissions. It seems like the warning of Lee Kuan Yew in 1980, of Australia becoming the poor white trash of Asia, is part of Dutton's election policy. Bob Dillon, Bathurst\n\nThe Coalition intends to build up to seven nuclear power plants. I can't imagine there would be a skilled workforce large enough to build all of these simultaneously. If using an optimistic 15-year time span to build one reactor, we could anticipate the last one being completed in 2129. I assume the Coalition would be burning coal up to that point. Hopefully, the rest of the world doesn't have a Coalition timeline for addressing climate change. Unless we take strong climate action and burn a lot less fossil fuels, people in the future may be wearing gum boots while they sip coffee at Circular Quay cafes. Dennis O'Hara, Wanniassa (ACT)\n\nNuclear energy is disregarded by voters who are thoughtful, rational, logical, contemplative, reflective, intelligent. They believe the scientists from the CSIRO, who state that nuclear is more expensive than renewable energy and would take many years to build for the climate change that is happening now. I suggest that his plan for nuclear energy includes all nuclear waste to be dumped outside his home. Bea Hodgson, Gerringong\n\nIf Labor offers to subsidise batteries for homes and businesses for half the amount seven nuclear plants will cost, then Dutton will be done like slow-cooked mutton at the next election. Miles Lane, Manilla\n\nThe opposition's nuclear power fixation on top of the government's nuclear submarine plan reminds me of the old East German joke about the fellow ordering a new car. When told it will be delivered on 1 January 2040, he replies: Can you make it the afternoon, as I am having the power connected in the morning? {"uri": "2024-06-395355341", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "03:43:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T03:43:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T03:22:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://uk.news.yahoo.com/coalition-nuclear-fantasy-hamper-price-032245928.html", "title": "Coalition's nuclear 'fantasy' will hamper price falls from more renewable energy, Albanese says", "body": "Anthony Albanese has accused the Coalition of hampering power price reductions in the short-term by pursuing a nuclear power \"fantasy\" and \"disrupting certainty\" of investment in renewable energy.\n\nOn Thursday the prime minister muscled up against Peter Dutton's proposal to build seven nuclear power plants, arguing it had not survived one day of scrutiny and accusing the Coalition of pursuing the \"destination of denial\" instead of more practical steps to reduce emissions and prices.\n\n\"Now they've moved away from coal but they've found another destination of denial,\" he said.\n\n\"There will be issues of more energy insecurity, because we know it is disrupting the certainty that the business community have been crying out for.\n\n\"That's how you reduce prices - by increasing supply.\"\n\nSenior Coalition figures have struggled to explain how they would overcome key obstacles to the policy include the federal and state bans on nuclear, unwilling sellers of the seven sites and what technology would be used.\n\nOn Thursday the shadow treasurer, Angus Taylor, confirmed the opposition would unveil its costings before the election.\n\nDutton made a virtue of the lack of detail in the plan, telling ABC TV the opposition had \"taken a deliberate step not to be held hostage by the Labor Party in the scare campaign\".\n\n\"We want the information out there in bite-sized bits, if you like, so that people can consume exactly what it is that we're proposing and understand what it's not proposing,\" he told ABC TV.\n\nThe CSIRO's Gencost report advised nuclear power could be set up in Australia no sooner than 2040 and would be at least 50% more expensive than solar and wind, even factoring in the costs of transmission and firming of renewables. A theoretical 1,000MW nuclear plant built today would cost at least $8.6bn.\n\nBut Dutton claimed nuclear would be cheaper because \"a wind turbine project probably has an amortisation period, or a lifespan, of about two decades\" whereas nuclear has \"an 80-to-100 year amortisation period ... so the capital cost is spread over a longer period of time\".\n\n\"So, in terms of the current debate in the Illawarra, it's about $10bn over 20-to-30 years, the proponents say.\"\n\nAlbanese said the Coalition had made \"an announcement without any substance: no costings, no real timelines, [and] no idea of what form the reactors will be\".\n\n\"This is economic catastrophe,\" he told Sky News. \"When we look at the costs of nuclear, what we know is that it's the most expensive form of new energy.\"\n\n\"The Dutton opposition are saying in two decades we'll give you the most expensive form of energy there is.\"\n\nAlbanese pointed to state Coalition governments' record of selling government-owned power assets, and said the Coalition would \"struggle to assemble an Ikea flat pack\" let alone develop an industry the federal government had no record experience in.\n\nAlbanese noted the International Energy Agency, which is pro-nuclear, has nevertheless said it is not appropriate for Australia given its \"comparative advantages\" with wind and solar resources.\n\n\"Not only will this [nuclear] cost more, it will make energy supply insecure because there's no answer, either, of what happens between now and two decades' time for how energy supply is secured.\"\n\nAlbanese noted in its nine years in office to 2022, the Coalition had wanted to build new coal power plants \"and it ended up in zero\". He said the Coalition had also wanted to extend the life of existing coal plants but instead 14 announced closure \"on their watch\".\n\nAlbanese said it was \"tacky\" that the Coalition had invoked the late Labor prime minister, Bob Hawke, in their advocacy for nuclear because he \"can't speak for himself\" and had quoted him \"out of context\".\n\nEarlier, Taylor told Radio National there is an \"appropriate time and place\" for government ownership, citing the precedent of Robert Menzies in the 1950s.\n\nTaylor accused Labor of confusing government ownership with subsidies, revealing the Coalition expects nuclear \"to deliver a return on investment so it can be off-budget\" like the national broadband network and Australia Post.\n\nTaylor argued power prices could be reduced sooner than 2035-37 - the timescale the Coalition has put on the first two nuclear plants - because of \"shorter term strategies\" to use more gas in the meantime. Guardian Australia has previously reported that there is no evidence to suggest using gas would cut costs.\n\nThe Coalition has promised to abandon Labor's 2030 emissions reduction target of 43% on 2005 levels and proposed limiting or capping the amount of investment in large-scale renewables.", "source": {"uri": "uk.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo News UK"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8184865267", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "07:42:50", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T07:42:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T07:42:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.afr.com/companies/energy/nuclear-no-help-in-today-s-energy-supply-crisis-industry-20240619-p5jn0w", "title": "Nuclear no help in today's energy supply crisis: industry", "body": "\"We can't kick the emissions reduction can down the road, we have to deal with it, and unfortunately the nuclear plan looks like it kicks the emissions can down the road,\" he said.\n\nThe EUAA head's views are at odds with support voiced for the Coalition's nuclear vision by mining companies.\n\nThe loosely outlined policy envisages the first nuclear reactor up and running by 2035, the second by 2037 and five others coming online by 2050, all at former or existing coal power generator sites to sidestep the major stumbling block of building new transition to connect renewables.\n\n\"Nuclear energy stands out as a reliable, zero emissions, 24/7 baseload energy source that can deliver long-term stability and support for Australia's miners, manufacturers and communities,\" said Tania Constable, chief executive of the Minerals Council of Australia.\n\n\"High future demand for reliable and clean energy means that all energy types, including nuclear power, will be indispensable in meeting Australia's future energy needs.\"\n\nThe South Australian Chamber of Mines and Energy also endorsed the policy, noting the state's costs for electricity system security charged by the Australian Energy Market Operator had more than trebled since 2016 when its last baseload power plant closed.\n\nAustralia is one of the few Western economies aiming to decarbonise its electricity supply system without nuclear power, the use of which has been banned here since 1998. The Albanese Labor government has refused to put nuclear on the table for debate, despite growing evidence the country is falling increasingly behind its 2030 emissions reduction and renewables targets.\n\nAi Group chief executive Innes Willox called for the Coalition vision to be fleshed out with more detail around cost, viability and timelines, pointing to the long delays and cost blowouts in installing reactors in other Western economies.\n\nHe also said the proposal does nothing to help with short-term emissions reductions, energy costs and reliability, and suggested it could kill off private investment in the sector if it effectively renationalises electricity in Australia.\n\nOthers pointed to numerous hurdles in the way of the development of a domestic nuclear power industry, including unanimous opposition from state premiers, the lack of a skilled workforce, as well as high costs, long lead times and the need to store highly toxic waste.\n\nAGL Energy, which owns one of the sites that would host a nuclear reactor, described the cost of the technology as \"prohibitive\", while Origin Energy chief executive Frank Calabria pointed to several challenges, including when it could be deployed, the cost and its compatibility with the existing market.\n\n\"They are all considerations because I don't think we can see it being scalable for many years, probably well into the next decade ... and the cost is uncertain at that scalable level right now,\" Mr Calabria told a business conference in Sydney.\n\n\"So it's not a decision that I think we can make immediately in order to achieve our goals today.\"\n\nOpposition Leader Peter Dutton did not give an estimate of the costs involved in building the seven nuclear reactors, two of which, in Western Australia and South Australia, would be small modular reactors.\n\nEnergyAustralia, which owns the Mount Piper site in Lithgow that would host a reactor, said it was focusing on rolling out existing, readily available technologies, including batteries, gas power and pumped hydro, as well as underpinning more renewables.\n\nAn EnergyAustralia spokeswoman said the company was \"technology neutral\" when it came to what would be required for the transition in the 2030s and beyond, while noting that nuclear technology \"needs a good regulatory framework and a well-developed industry to deliver support it\".\n\nShe said Energy Australia had not discussed the use of any of its sites in the context of nuclear.", "source": {"uri": "afr.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Australian Financial Review"}, {"uri": "8186254119", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "03:28:00", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T03:28:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T03:27:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/commentisfree/article/2024/jun/20/peter-dutton-nuclear-power-plan-economic-disaster-australian-electricity-prices-opinion", "title": "Peter Dutton's nuclear plan is an economic disaster that would leave Australians paying more for electricity | Tristan Edis", "body": "The Peter Dutton-led Coalition has announced that, if elected, the government will build seven nuclear power stations located across every mainland state.\n\nOne can understand the appeal of nuclear power to those who are unfamiliar with the history of the technology. Nuclear power has been with us for many decades, supplying large amounts of emission-free power across a wide number of democratic, developed countries in Europe and North America. Why wouldn't we make use of a power source that can be turned up and down independent of the weather and which other developed nations have used for decades?\n\nWhat many Australians probably don't realise is that almost all of these nuclear power plants were constructed in the 1970s and 1980s. The technology was then largely abandoned as an option for new power supply. Over the 2000s there was talk of a renaissance of the technology as concerns around global warming grew, and the industry unveiled new \"generation 3\" designs to address nuclear meltdown risks. Yet this expected renaissance never eventuated, with just five generation 3 nuclear power plants under construction over the past decade across Europe and North America.\n\nThere is a very good reason for why the appetite to build new nuclear power stations in western nations that already have nuclear power is minimal. Fans of nuclear like to think this is just because of irrational fears of reactor meltdowns and radiation. But in reality it's got more to do with the fact that nuclear power plants cost too much to build.\n\nWhat several countries, particularly France and the United States, encountered during their nuclear build programs over the 1970s and 1980s was that the promised costs for nuclear reactors turned out to be badly underestimated. They also found that things didn't improve as they built more of these reactors - instead they got worse.\n\nOxford University professor Bent Flyvbjerg, an expert in construction management, has built up a large database of the time and budget records for 16,000 major construction projects across the globe covering a wide array of fields. He finds that nuclear reactors encounter the greatest budget and time blowouts in his database of construction projects, with the exception of just two other project types. One, worryingly, is nuclear waste repositories, which Australia would also need to build. The other is host city Olympic Games infrastructure. Interestingly, Flyvbjerg's database also reveals the projects which are most likely to achieve construction timeframes and budgets are wind and solar power.\n\nThe poor experience over the 1970s and 80s meant there was almost no new nuclear plant construction commitments in Europe and North America until the second half of the 2000s. The table below summarises the horrific budget blowouts with the five generation 3 reactors committed to construction since then. Of note is that the two projects in the US used the same reactor model Dutton has indicated he'd like to use - Westinghouse's AP1000. Also worth noting is actual real world experience indicates costs for nuclear per megawatt of capacity, which are significantly higher than the $8.6m estimated recently by the CSIRO.\n\nWhat we can see is that, contrary to the promises of nuclear technology companies, generation 3 designs did not improve on past experience of budget blow-outs. It should also be noted that one of these projects - Virgil C Summer - was abandoned prior to completion, as the cost blowouts became too great to bear. Unfortunately for South Carolina energy consumers, this was only after the expenditure of $13.5bn on the failed project.\n\nSo what does this all mean for you personally?\n\nContrary to Dutton's claims, it means you'll be paying more on your electricity bill. As the table above shows, exactly how much more will be subject to wide variation depending on how badly the construction process unfolds, as well as a range of other assumptions.\n\nIf we use Vogtle as an example, which is the one completed project that employed Dutton's favoured Westinghouse AP1000 technology, the extra cost to consumers would be very high. Power retailers would need to pay prices for wholesale energy at least three times higher than what they currently pay to recover the cost of this plant. For the average household that would result in an increase in their power bill in the realm of $1,000 per year from Dutton's plan to go nuclear.", "source": {"uri": "theguardian.com", "dataType": "https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/e74d92e0a70c9eb36887e6c710adf9bcbde56d86/9_0_3483_2090/master/3483.jpg?width=1200&height=630&quality=85&auto=format&fit=crop&overlay-align=bottom%2Cleft&overlay-width=100p&overlay-base64=L2ltZy9zdGF0aWMvb3ZlcmxheXMvdGctb3BpbmlvbnMucG5n&s=3e6949a45bbf1a02112a3f95728d27e3", {"uri": "2024-06-395298517", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "01:59:38", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T01:59:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T01:59:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://independentaustralia.net/politics/politics-display/duttons-nuclear-lights-are-out-and-no-ones-home,18701", "title": "Dutton's nuclear lights are out and no one's home", "body": "Dutton's alternative facts on nuclear energy demonstrate that the Coalition is no longer fit for purpose as a credible opposition, let alone a serious government contender. Michelle Pini reports.\n\nAPART from frequently changing leaders, nothing has changed about the Liberal-National Party Opposition for a very long time, certainly not since the Abbott/Turnbull/Morrison retrograde regime.\n\nPut simply, since the whole point of an opposition party in a two-party system is to provide credible alternative policies - not to recycle the ideas and innovations of a bygone era - today's Coalition is simply no longer fit for purpose.\n\nThis is perhaps best illustrated by Dutton's most recent set of alternative facts masquerading as policies, the recycled 1950s nuclear power plan.\n\nPeter Dutton's recycled nuclear contamination\n\nNuclear power is one hell of a way to boil water. ~ Albert Einstein\n\nSure, the Liberals/Nationals are the parties of the status quo but the fact is, they have taken this concept well past its natural use-by date. Basically, if this was the age of the telephone invention, Opposition Leader Peter Dutton and his band of unmerry naysayers would be advocating to keep tin cans and string because phones would put can and string manufacturers out of business -- not to mention the plight of carrier pigeon trainers.\n\nWait, that is actually the same reasoning that led to over a decade of third-world-standard NBN, but we digress.\n\nCarrier pigeons and tin cans notwithstanding, today, the Coalition want us to get behind a leader who, if elected, would catapult us back to an age before science, before technology and before we worked out the Earth wasn't flat -- in every facet of our lives.\n\nA word is needed about the role of the entire mainstream media, here, including the national broadcaster - yet again - in providing a framework where Dutton's idiotic ramblings are given prominence -- nay, are exalted as if they came from the Heavens.\n\nThere are so many subtle ways in which his party's every brain fart is reported in the media as a credible idea and Alan Austin's latest analysis provides a more detailed explanation of how the ABC's news coverage, in particular, subtly facilitates this Liberal Party agenda. (You can read more here.)\n\nSo, to summarise the Dutton Coalition \"policy platform\", it goes something like this:\n\nFinding it hard to keep up with the changing world? Need a scapegoat for your woes?\n\nThen, has Dutton got an idiotic plan, a minority group and a few gaslights, courtesy of the establishment media, for you?!\n\nIt is the exploitation of these core fears - the primal fears of change and of \"others\" - that form the basis of Dutton's Coalition \"policy structure\". It is the reason he does not provide any substantial \"detail\" in support of his claims. And it provides ongoing ammunition for the climate and culture wars he favours. It's really no more complicated than that.\n\nLet's take a close look at Dutton's banal nuclear \"power plan\", which has been presented as a legitimate argument in the legacy media.\n\nWhy nuclear power won't work in Australia -- yet another explainer\n\nWhile the Liberal Party continues its push for nuclear power in Australia, there are many reasons why renewables are a far better option.\n\nA NUCLEAR NIGHTMARE\n\nDutton - or at least the Coalition's expert advisers, assuming they still have any - is abundantly aware of the following:\n\nnuclear energy is not safe by any stretch of the imagination; it is not clean; it is prohibitively expensive; and a nuclear energy industry is unachievable, certainly in the foreseeable future.\n\nBut none of this matters to Dutton. The reason he is pushing for nuclear is plain: since any nuclear energy plan is unattainable for at least 20 years, it ensures his coal and gas mining mates can continue destroying our natural environment for a long, long time to come.\n\nWith the main game already established, it is only necessary to deflect and obfuscate, providing no \"details\", such as properly calculated costs or a realistic timeline. Even his claim that the first seven reactors would be built in Victoria, New South Wales and Queensland was debunked by the state premiers, who have unanimously rejected the idea. According to one ABC report, even some state Liberal and National MPs have 'distanced themselves from nuclear'.\n\nIt's fine, though, according to Dutton, who may eventually give us the details after his party is elected.\n\nDutton's devoid-of-details nuclear plan an atomic failure\n\nGiven the absence of substance in Peter Dutton's nuclear policy so far, his 'lack-of-details' cry over The Voice must surely come back to haunt him.\n\nNO RENEWABLES FOR US!\n\nBecause the efficiency of renewable energies poses a real and imminent threat to fossil fuels, Dutton also plans to ensure any further great strides in this sector will die a quick and unceremonious death by imposing a cap on renewable energy investment.\n\nAnd because Dutton's plan is only about fear, he harnesses the fear of running out of power, or of exorbitant energy prices with idiotic statements like, \"We can't allow the lights to go out.\"\n\nThere is no informed debate. No detail (of which he was once so fond). Not even an attempt to appear informed.\n\nA point proved, yet again, by one of Dutton's unmerry naysayers, Keith Pitt, who told RN Breakfast yesterday (19 June) that nuclear is needed because:\n\n\"[Electricity] grids can't handle more than ten per cent wind and solar.\"\n\nUm... Keith, as the latest report from the Clean Energy Council points out, wind and solar already constitute almost 40 per cent of the national electricity market in Australia.\n\nOh, those pesky details!\n\nThen there are all the Indigenous and other community groups, environmental groups and scientific experts - occasionally consulted in the mainstream media and then summarily ignored - who have voiced their opposition to nuclear en masse.\n\nSuch as Climate Council CEO Amanda McKenzie who described Dutton's plan as:\n\n'A sickening smokescreen for its commitment to coal and gas...\n\nDutton's scheme is: let the climate burn, let the mega fires burn, let the sea levels rise, let the heat become unbearable. Let's send our children towards climate disaster.'\n\nBut not to worry, said Nationals Leader and would-be deputy prime minister, David Littleproud, confirming on Afternoon Briefing that the Coalition's nuclear plans would go ahead anyway:\n\n\"As part of a Coalition government [we] are prepared to make the tough decisions in the national interest.\"\n\nThat's right, bothersome particulars like scientific advice, environmental consequences, community consultation and possible atomic annihilation be damned! Oh, and we'll give you the details after we're elected.\n\nToday's Coalition is aptly headed by Peter Dutton, a climate-denying fossil, who would take us back to tin cans and string if this would appease his coal and gas mining mates.\n\nAs long as the Coalition remains mired in backward thinking such as this latest nuclear \"policy plan\", we will continue to put all its \"policies\" in inverted commas to indicate the absence of any credibility.\n\nToday's Liberal-National Party Coalition under Peter Dutton is simply not fit for purpose as a credible opposition party, let alone a serious government contender.\n\nFollow managing editor Michelle Pini on Twitter @vmp9. {"uri": "2024-06-395886929", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "12:21:37", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T12:21:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T12:06:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.businessinsider.in/tech/news/this-new-technology-for-nuclear-power-could-help-fuel-the-ai-revolution/articleshow/111141002.cms", "title": "This new technology for nuclear power could help fuel the AI revolution | Business Insider India", "body": "Ancient alchemists once tried transmuting elements, toying with metals like lead to create gold. That pursuit of quick riches has since been abandoned, but scientists are now using a similar idea to level up one of the world's most promising energy sources.\n\nTransmutex, a Swiss startup, is pioneering a new method for \"nuclear transmutation\" that not only destroys nuclear waste but can also turn it back into energy -- solving a key problem in nuclear energy production.\n\nScientists have long considered nuclear energy one of the cleanest and most reliable forms of energy production. However, the waste it creates must be stored in deep geological repositories for thousands of years to prevent the environment from being exposed to harmful radiation. Transmutex says its technology can \"transmute\" 99% of the world's high-level radioactive waste into new fuel.\n\nNagra, the Swiss agency that manages nuclear waste, validated the claim as a \"theoretical possibility\" in a letter to the company last month.\n\nSwitzerland, however, has pivoted away from nuclear energy, in part because of the safety concerns made apparent by Japan's Fukushima disaster in 2011. But such disasters are rare and many other countries -- like the United States and Saudi Arabia, for example -- are betting on nuclear energy as the most efficient and sustainable option.\n\n\"To reach our goal of net zero by 2050, we have to at least triple our current nuclear capacity,\" US Energy Secretary Jennifer Granholm said in May.\n\nTech companies at the forefront of the AI revolution are also turning to nuclear energy to power their vast AI data centers.\n\nTransmutex CEO Franklin Servan-Schreiber believes the company can help these businesses go nuclear by destroying that long-term waste.\n\n\"If we know how to deal with the waste, even if it takes a long time, we still know that in the future there is a limit to that waste, which is not gonna be a million years. That's the key,\" he told Business Insider in an interview.\n\nA new fuel cycle for nuclear power\n\nTransmutex's technology uses high-energy subatomic particles known as neutrons to destroy highly radioactive nuclear waste. While it can take hundreds of thousands of years for nuclear waste to decay to safe radiation levels, Transmutex says its technology can shorten that timeframe to just decades.\n\nServan-Schreiber says that over time, this system can also turn that waste into fuel that can be used again in nuclear power plants -- a sort of nuclear recycling program.\n\n\"Because you're able to burn waste and release energy, overall the process is very profitable,\" Cameron Porter, a venture capitalist who manages Steel Atlas and is an investor in Transmutex, told Business Insider.\n\nNuclear physicists say the company's technology avoids one of the biggest concerns with nuclear energy: that the same fuel used to power nuclear plants can also be used to manufacture atomic weapons.\n\n\"We don't want that to happen,\" Andrei Afanasev, a professor of physics at George Washington University's Institute for Nuclear Studies, told Business Insider.\n\nTransmutex avoids this risk because it doesn't produce plutonium, a key element for making nuclear bombs.\n\nThe technology is also more efficient, Afanasev said. According to the Department of Energy, spent nuclear fuel can still have about 90% of its potential energy even after five\u202fyears of operation in a reactor.\n\nWith nuclear reactors, \"you just throw away a big chunk of energy that you could use for everybody,\" he said. \"So this technology addresses this issue. They can extract more energy from the existing fuel.\"\n\nAI firms on the lookout for energy solutions\n\nThe AI industry is looking for new, more reliable power sources as the race to develop artificial intelligence ramps up.\n\n\"Energy, not compute, will be the No. 1 bottleneck to AI progress,\" Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg said on the Dwarkesh Podcast in April, referring to the computational resources needed for training and running AI models.\n\nOklo, a startup backed by OpenAI CEO Sam Altman, is betting on generating nuclear power through small nuclear reactors. Its Aurora reactor can run on spent nuclear waste.\n\nServan-Schreiber said nuclear power might be the only way to support the industry's massive energy demands.\n\n\"AI requires massive, industrial-scale amounts of energy,\" Servan-Schreiber said. \"Only nuclear power will be able to supply this massive energy demand in a reliable manner. With a technology like Transmutex (only one currently being proposed), the US can build classic uranium-based nuclear plants, such as the Vogtle plant in Georgia, without being burdened with high-level nuclear waste for hundreds of thousands of years.\"", "source": {"uri": "businessinsider.in", "dataType": "news", "title": "Business Insider India"}, "authors": [{"uri": Even his claim that the first seven reactors would be built in Victoria, New South Wales and Queensland was debunked by the state premiers, who have unanimously rejected the idea. Under the plan, the first two plants would be operational by 2037, with the remaining five online by 2050.\n\nDutton said all the nuclear power plants would be built at locations where there are currently power stations that have closed or are scheduled to do so, and that the facilities would be government-owned. All the proposed sites are on the Australian mainland, with two each in the eastern states of New South Wales (NSW) and Queensland, and one each in south-eastern Victoria, South Australia, and Western {"uri": "2024-06-395173476", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "21:29:23", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T21:29:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T21:05:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.crikey.com.au/2024/06/20/peter-dutton-nuclear-reactors-energy-renewables/", "title": "Dutton makes the news go nuclear", "body": "It's all nuclear today as your Worm covers the nation's response to Peter Dutton's audacious plan to build seven nuclear reactors across Australia.\n\nAustralian newspapers are absolutely saturated with stories about Peter Dutton's nuclear proposal this morning. From Western Australia to the east coast, front pages are dominated by takes on the Coalition's announcement it will seek, if elected at the next election, to build seven nuclear reactors in five states. It's hard to find a positive angle among the barrage of articles: the most encouraging spin comes from News Corp papers, which have highlighted the fact voters will be asked to decide their own energy future at the ballot box.\n\n\"Energy referendum gamble: Dutton's historic power play\" reads the top line of The Australian, above an all-caps headline saying \"Voters' nuclear option\". The Daily Telegraph called it Dutton's \"Nuclear strike\", arguing it would set up an \"energy election\". The Australian Financial Review's Phillip Coorey also focused on the fact voters will get a say in the matter, writing that Coalition electorates earmarked for possible reactors are feeling positive about the prospect, but pointing out it's \"one of the riskiest plays by an opposition since John Hewson released Fightback more than a year before the 1993 election\".\n\nGuardian Australia leads with a story saying: \"'No credible reason' to expect cheaper power bills under Peter Dutton's plan, experts say\". The ABC reports: \"Nuclear proposal rejected by premiers, who say Dutton has no power to lift state nuclear bans\" (more on that below).\n\nThe West Australian has a splash on its website saying: \"Dutton's nuclear energy plan bedevilled by unknowns\". And so on and so on. At least no one can claim Dutton doesn't know how to set a news agenda.\n\nNUCLEAR REACTIONS\n\nHow are the local politicians in the areas where Dutton wants to build nuclear reactors feeling about the idea? In Queensland, where the federal Coalition would like to build two reactors, Liberal-National Party state leader David Crisafulli said on Tuesday he would not repeal the state's nuclear ban and added nuclear was \"not on our plan, not on our agenda\", per Guardian Australia. Crisafulli is campaigning for an election that will be held in October. Labor Premier Steven Miles wasn't impressed either: \"We've been very clear about the fact that we don't believe in that model,\" he said, according to The Courier-Mail.\n\nNSW would also get two reactors under the proposal, but some state Coalition MPs feel negative about the idea there, too. Nationals MP Paul Toole, whose electorate would be a proposed reactor site, said \"the announcement lacks detail and raises more questions than answers. I'll be backing the views of my community 100%,\" according to The Daily Telegraph. Dave Layzell, another Nationals MP whose electorate would be impacted, said: \"I do not accept a federal government decision to lob a facility onto the community of the Upper Hunter.\"\n\nLabor Premier Chris Minns said he had no plans to repeal the state's nuclear ban: \"Our ban stays in place, we're not repealing it. I'd be surprised if the NSW Liberal and National party want to repeal it as well.\"\n\nIn Victoria, where Dutton wants to build one reactor, Premier Jacinta Allan said, according to the Herald Sun: \"We won't stand for that. We absolutely will not stand for that ... it is unfathomable\".\n\nIn Western Australia, a Labor stronghold where another reactor was proposed, state Energy Minister Reece Whitby said the plan was \"a recipe for disaster\", according to the ABC.\n\nThat leaves South Australia, where Dutton wants two reactors. Labor Premier Peter Malinauskas might be the Labor leader most warm to the idea of nuclear power, but even he wasn't down with the Coalition plan. \"I would support nuclear power unless it makes electricity more expensive, and all the evidence says that it will make electricity a lot more expensive,\" he said, according to news.com.au.\n\nON A LIGHTER NOTE...\n\nTalk about a vintage: archeologists have found an urn in Spain containing wine that's more than 2,000 years old. The newspaper El Pais reports: \"The finding supersedes the Speyer wine bottle, discovered in 1867 and dated between 325 and 350 AD, which is preserved in the Historical Museum of Pfalz (Germany) and considered the world's oldest known bottle of wine.\"\n\nThe new discovery was made at a Roman necropolis in the city of Carmona in Spani's southern Andalusia region. While the urn was actually filled with white wine, the liquid had turned red with age. Before you entertain any notions of having a sip, however, consider the fact there was a skeleton submerged in the booze.\n\nSay What?\n\nWe will do everything to prevent the secession of the rich.\n\nIn Italy, a proposal to reward authorities in areas of the country that run their affairs efficiently with more power has exposed a \"deep wound in Italy's national psyche\", Politico reports. The proposed law has exposed a geographic divide, amid accusations the Giorgia Meloni government is \"abandoning\" the poorer south in favour of the wealthy, industrialised north. Tensions came to a boil last week when a fistfight erupted in Parliament. Ruotolo, a centre-left MP from Naples, was one of the critics who used their words to oppose the proposal.\n\nPutin says Russia and North Korea will help each other if attacked, taking ties to a 'new level' (CNN)\n\nDutch leader Mark Rutte clears a big hurdle to becoming NATO chief after Hungary lifts objections (Associated Press)\n\nIn South China Sea dispute, Philippines' bolder hand tests Beijing (Reuters)\n\nTHE COMMENTARIAT\n\nCivil war, what civil war? The so-called Tory moderates never even put up a fight -- Rafael Behr (The Guardian): \"[Conservative] ministers have resorted to pleading with voters not to give Keir Starmer too big a majority. There is a deficit of drama in the contest to be prime minister. The gap is filled with speculation over the size and character of Britain's next opposition.\n\nConvention dictates that this be construed as a civil war. On one side is the remnant of the traditional Tory party that David Cameron led until 2016. These are MPs who mostly voted remain and endorsed Theresa May's Brexit deal. They venerate fiscal discipline and managerial sobriety. They are moderate, at least by demeanour and in comparison with the other side -- a messy coalition of nationalist demagogues, social reactionaries, libertarian ultras and Brexit puritans who hanker for congress with Nigel Farage's Reform party. In reality, the lines are blurred. Vibes count for more than policy.\"\n\nPeter Dutton's expensive nuclear folly another deplorable outcome after ditching carbon pricing scheme -- Tom Dusevic (The Australian) ($): \"If voters decide they want to have nuclear power to achieve net zero by 2050, it won't come cheap: higher debt and taxes and the heavy hand of government ownership that has bequeathed money pits like the NBN and Snowy 2.0.\n\nThere is no other way because private capital won't go anywhere near this risky energy play, with huge upfront costs, very long lead times and the madness that has pervaded our energy transition to meet international obligations. Peter Dutton is all the way with enriched uranium, with details to follow, presumably on costs, benefits and how we'll cover the period before the first power plants are online in 2035 and 2037.\n\nA new government business enterprise may be \"off-budget\", as many of today's green industry and decarbonisation measures are, but their funding and finan\u00adcing won't be a free lunch. This is pure folly with taxpayers' money at this time, in this way.\"", "source": {"uri": "crikey.com.au", "dataType": "news", "title": "Crikey"}, "authors": [{"uri": "anton_nilsson@crikey.com.au", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9662030", "eventUri": "eng-9662030", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.08235294117647052, "wgt": 149, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8184673938", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "05:07:36", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T05:07:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T05:07:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://www.abc.net.au/news/2024-06-19/analysis-dutton-nuclear-plan-betting-on-ability-to-sway-voters/103997648", "title": "Peter Dutton has placed a staggering bet on his ability to sell Australians nuclear power  --  it's a huge gamble", "body": "There's a great story from Kelvin McKenzie's stint as editor of Britain's The Sun newspaper, notorious for its salacious headlines and outrageous beat-ups. A journo came panting back in from a job and gabbled out his story to McKenzie, concluding with the words \"and the most amazing thing is, it's actually true!\"\n\nMcKenzie is said to have bellowed across the newsroom: \"True story alert, folks! Repeat: We have a TRUE STORY!\"\n\nPolitical leaders make policy decisions based on all kinds of factors -- too often, the driving force is a sickly alloy of cowardice and polling.\n\nThe one that Peter Dutton rolled out today, however, is different. And certainly the riskiest gambit from opposition in many moons. He genuinely believes nuclear is the answer to Australia's energy problems and is confident that the details (yet to be established) will vindicate him.\n\nIn other words: \"Genuine conviction alert, folks! We have a GENUINELY HELD BELIEF here!\"\n\nThere is no chance Dutton and his climate and energy spokesman Ted O'Brien, another nuclear true believer, are basing this decision on polling, unless they're reading it upside down.\n\nA national energy survey conducted last month by the research company RedBridge, which asked 2,000 respondents how they felt about various energy sources, put public support for nuclear at 35 per cent. Coal was the only less popular option, at 28 per cent. Solar was at 80 per cent.\n\nDutton has been a highly effective opposition leader for two years now. Just surviving as Liberal leader for two years after a sickening election loss is a triumph, historically speaking. But Dutton has built support, and has a united party room. Or has had, until now.\n\nThis success has been built on caution. He keeps a fairly low profile, and has built political capital among his colleagues by being consultative and concentrating his efforts on criticising the government's errors rather than making his own.\n\nToday, Peter Dutton has taken every single chip he's amassed, and he's put the whole lot on yellowcake.\n\nHe's announced a full-strength tilt at nuclear power for Australia, said the first plant will be up and running within 13 years, doesn't know how much it will cost, but does hold out the promise that it will bring rivers of cheap energy to Australia just like it has in France (which started building nuclear power stations in the 1970s).\n\nWhere will the plants go? Mostly in National Party seats, and they're all on board, says Nats leader David Littleproud. Easy.\n\nWhere will the nuclear waste go? Probably on the sites of the reactors, came the opposition leader's response when questioned at his press conference today. The \"no big deal\" tone to his reply was sharpened by his observation that the average volume of radioactive waste emitted by the proposed reactors would fit into \"a can of Coke\". (One assumes that this is not actually the formal storage plan proposed, but in the absence of another model it's all we have at this stage.)\n\nNuclear has full-throated support from certain parts of the Coalition's party room, and among the high-volume, low-viewership opinion vendors who ply their trade on Sky as the evening shadows lengthen.\n\nBut among the broader population, there is a perceptible and fascinating pattern. Men don't mind nuclear - 51 per cent expressed approval in the RedBridge survey - but women really, really don't; only 19 per cent approved, and 40 per cent expressly disapproved.\n\nThe strongest support for nuclear is found among Coalition voters (52 per cent), the over-65s (47 per cent), people who own their houses outright (42 per cent) and people who describe themselves as under \"no housing stress at all\" (52 per cent).\n\nPeter Dutton has spent two years declaring that the cost of living is the biggest issue Australians face. But the solution he's proposing also happens to be the least attractive to the people with whom he's trying hardest to emote.\n\nHis job now is to convince them that an Australian government led by him can -- in just 15 years and at as-yet undisclosed national expense -- generate cheap power.\n\nIf elected, he would also need to convince state governments to cooperate in NSW, Victoria, SA and his home state of Queensland, where even the state LNP leader David Crisafulli, who quite possibly will be premier within months, today issued a polite \"no, thank you\" to Dutton's plan.\n\nThe whole thing certainly relieves John Hewson -- author of the GST-toting Fightback package that the Coalition took to the 1993 election to a large and sustained round of voter indifference -- of his mantle as the most courageous Liberal opposition leader in modern history.\n\nContacted today, Hewson did not appear to entertain any camaraderie with Dutton's policy boldness.\n\n\"The comparison is most insulting, given the detailed policy work -- including costings -- in Fightback,\" he said.\n\n\"This is the scam of the year. No detail, no costings.\"\n\nThe opposition leader is correct that high power prices -- and the exposure of Australian households to power shortages, and the concern over sacrifice of farming land to wind farms and transmission lines -- are genuine issues of concern to Australians.\n\nBut committing untold volumes of public money to speed-build reactors about which voters are already nervous ... well. Only a true believer would attempt such a thing. Which is what Dutton is, when it comes to nuclear.\n\nHe's not the first leader to feel this way: John Howard floated nuclear after a long consultation process in 2007, and was promptly flattened by Kevin Rudd and Wayne Swan who toured Australia sweetly asking voters how they'd feel about a reactor in their backyard. Bob Hawke was a fan, but didn't have a crack at it while in an actual position to do so.\n\nIn whipping this decision through the shadow cabinet and then an online meeting of the party room, Dutton has also put his greatest political asset -- party stability -- on the table. Every marginal seat MP or candidate attempting to win back metropolitan seats for the Liberal Party will now be obliged to talk about nuclear power stations, when they'd prefer to be talking about the cost of living under Labor.\n\nUp until now, the opposition leader has enjoyed -- among his own colleagues -- a reputation for caution, for keeping the party a small target, and for capitalising on the government's mistakes rather than bolting out and making his own.\n\nNot any more, folks. Peter Dutton has today placed a staggering bet on his own ability to sell Australians something they presently don't want, at a price yet to be determined. They don't make targets bigger than this.", "source": {"uri": "abc.net.au", "dataType": "news", "title": "Australian Broadcasting Corporation"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8185739315", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "17:43:07", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T17:43:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T17:40:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://thewest.com.au/politics/duttons-nuclear-reactor-over-budget-and-a-joke-c-15079678", "title": "Dutton's nuclear reactor 'over budget' and a 'joke'", "body": "Dutton's nuclear reactor 'over budget' and a 'joke'Tess IkonomouAAPThu, 20 June 2024 1:35AM\n\nA type of nuclear reactor put forward by the coalition as an option under its energy plan has been slammed by an energy economist as \"irresponsible\".\n\nSeven nuclear power plants would be built at the sites of coal-fired power stations if the coalition wins the federal election.\n\nThe coalition wanted to \"rely\" on the Westinghouse-manufactured AP1000 reactor, Opposition Leader Peter Dutton said when unveiling his long-awaited policy.\n\n\"In terms of the small, modular reactor, or the AP1000 or whatever it might be, that we believe would be the best for each of those sites, we'll have those discussions in due course,\" Mr Dutton said.\n\nTheNightlyGet in front of tomorrow's news for FREE\n\nJournalism for the curious Australian across politics, business, culture and opinion.\n\nREAD NOW\n\nBut Curtin University Sustainable Engineering Group's Associate Professor Liam Wagner rubbished the proposal, because the AP1000 had consistently been late in its build time and was over budget.\n\n\"It would be irresponsible to seek that as the preferred option, given that significant delays that it's faced in installation in the US,\" he told AAP.\n\n\"It's essentially like ripping up $100 bills.\"\n\nThe sites nominated for nuclear plants include Loy Yang Power Station in Victoria, Callide and Tarong in Queensland, Mount Piper at Lithgow in central west NSW and Liddell in NSW's Hunter region.\n\nSmall, modular reactors would also be built at Northern Power Station in Port Augusta and at Muja Power Station, southeast of Perth.\n\nNo costings have been provided.\n\nAssociate Professor Wagner was scathing of the coalition's \"absolute joke\" of a plan and questioned if they had checked the locations announced were appropriate for nuclear plants.\n\n\"We would need to have significant geological investigation into those areas, whether they would be suitable to have that type of plant built there,\" he said.\n\n\"Are they the right places to install them based on the geological properties of that area? I sincerely doubt that the opposition has sought an opinion on that.\"\n\nOn the coalition's pledge that the first two nuclear power plants would be built between 2035 and 2037, Associate Professor Wagner said it was \"extremely unlikely\".\n\n\"It is undoubtedly extremely difficult to build them and highly technical,\" he said.\n\n\"We don't have the human capital here in Australia to be able to do that on our own.\n\n\"Even if we were able to procure the right people to build it, I sincerely doubt that it would be built by 2035 ... it's just not feasible.\"\n\nMr Dutton said the planned rollout is sensible and achievable.\n\nThe CSIRO last month reported the first nuclear plants would not be achieved until 2040 at the earliest.\n\nEnergy Minister Chris Bowen said the announcement produced many more questions than answers.\n\n\"The Liberals and Nationals promised you a sensible energy plan. Instead, they're giving you a risky nuclear scam,\" he said.\n\n\"We know that nuclear is too expensive, too slow to build, and too risky for energy reliability.\"\n\nGet the latest news from "title": "'Train wreck': Ley blasts Labor on energy as Coalition's nuclear agenda is unveiled", "body": "Deputy Opposition Leader Sussan Ley has hit out at Labor's \"train wreck\" energy policies as Liberal Leader Peter Dutton prepares to unveil his highly-anticipated nuclear energy policy.\n\nMr Dutton is on Wednesday set to reveal that nuclear reactors would be owned and operated by the Federal Government should the Coalition win the next election, according to The Australian.\n\nCoalition members convened virtually at 8.30am on Wednesday morning to discuss the draft policy in the party room, following a snap shadow cabinet meeting on Tuesday night, according to The Daily Telegraph.\n\nMr Dutton is expected to officially reveal the finer details of the nuclear energy agenda in a press conference on Wednesday morning.\n\nSpeaking to Sky News Australia, Deputy Opposition Leader Sussan Ley was asked whether the Coalition's nuclear energy plans would be given the tick of approval on Wednesday morning.\n\n\"Well, we'll go through our normal processes and consult with the Australian people and we'll have more to say later,\" Ms Ley said.\n\n\"But, let's face it, policy in this country around energy under this government is an absolute train wreck.\n\n\"We're paying the highest electricity prices in the world... today is the coldest day so far this year, there will be Australians who are choosing between heating and eating.\"\n\nMs Ley reiterated the Opposition's push for nuclear power to be included in the path forward for Australia's energy future, as the country transitions to net zero emissions by 2050.\n\n\"With 90 per cent of base load power due to exit the system by 2034 the government has no answer to that, so we want cheaper, cleaner, consistent power, and we have said that nuclear should be part of that mix,\" she said.\n\nThe locations of the proposed nuclear reactors are yet to be revealed by the Coalition, but the Hunter Valley in New South Wales is one region rumoured to be earmarked for the infrastructure.\n\nQueensland is also expected to have at least two nuclear power plants, but whether Victoria's La Trobe Valley will be a host is up in the air, The Daily Telegraph reports.\n\nMr Dutton reportedly only briefed those Coalition MPs whose electorates could be a host of a potential nuclear reactor during the meeting on Tuesday evening.\n\nPressed on reports the Coalition will approve the nuclear plans during a teleconference on Wednesday morning, Ms Ley said would not speak to \"internal processes\".\n\n\"I think it's clear there will be a conversation and there will be an announcement later this morning,\" she replied.\n\n\"I urge people who care about the future of this country who want a policy around energy, around electricity, around manufacturing, which is my particularly area in opposition I stand on factory floors cross this country every day and I see we have record insolvencies, three times as many in the manufacturing and construction industry.\"\n\n\"So you'll rubber stamp it this morning? Where will they go? That's the big question, where will they go?\" Stefanovic pressed.\n\nHis line of questioning prompted a swift response from Ms Ley who remained tight-lipped on the finer details of the Coalition's nuclear plan.\n\n\"You wouldn't expect me to have a scoop at 7am on your program,\" Ms Ley hit back.\n\n\"But what I will say... we will consult with communities unlike this government that is forcing renewable energy solutions on communities like the Hunter, like the south-west of WA with offshore wind, communities not been consulted on.\n\n\"So consultation is critical to this and we've always said that and it will remain at the core of the policies that we bring forward. Communities matter.\"\n\nAsked how the Coalition would maneuver around state bans on building nuclear power facilities, Ms Ley said the Coalition would \"work through\" that detail and had a
