{"uri": "8186074741", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "23:57:05", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T23:57:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T23:36:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/aap/article-13548771/Nuclear-renewables-battle-election.html", "title": "Nuclear and renewables to battle it out at election", "body": "Australians will go to the polls with a choice on energy: renewables or the nuclear option.\n\nThe federal election, which must be held by May 2025, is shaping up to be a battle of energy policies.\n\nWithout publishing costs, the opposition on Wednesday vowed to build seven nuclear power plants at the sites of coal-fired power stations if they win the political contest.\n\nThe Labor government, on the other hand, has committed $22.7 billion over the next decade for its Future Made in Australia plan - which aims to increase investment from the private sector to key renewables in Australian industry.\n\n\"This election is a choice between two different energy policies,\" Energy Minister Chris Bowen said.\n\n\"Our energy policy, which we've been very clear about and implementing, and their fantasy which they can't answer key questions on.\"\n\nLabor politicians have already drawn attack lines.\n\nView this post on Instagram\n\nA post shared by Andrew Leigh MP (@andrewleighmp)\n\nMP Andrew Leigh posted a meme of a three-eyed Blinky Bill with Simpsons-style nuclear reactors, while Prime Minister Anthony Albanese warned the opposition leader's plan would cost families.\n\n\"It makes sense for households to reduce their energy bills by having renewable energy, and just as it makes sense for an individual household, it makes sense for our national economy,\" he told ABC Radio on Thursday.\n\n\"Peter Dutton is taking a radioactive sledgehammer to the Australian economy and Australian families will pay.\"\n\nMr Dutton said he would feed more details to the public in due course, and condemned the government's \"scare\" tactics.\n\n\"We have taken a deliberate step not to be held hostage by the Labor Party in the scare campaign,\" he told ABC.\n\n\"We want the information out there in bite-sized bits so that people can consume exactly what it is that we're proposing and understand what it's not proposing.\"\n\nThe costs of the reactors would also be announced before the election, Shadow Treasurer Angus Taylor assured.\n\nBut even without specifics, the opposition's plan is already being picked apart.\n\nCurtin University Sustainable Engineering Group's Liam Wagner rubbished Mr Dutton's proposal to rely on the Westinghouse-manufactured AP1000 reactor, saying the AP1000 had consistently been late in its build time and was over budget.\n\n\"It would be irresponsible to seek that as the preferred option, given the significant delays that it's faced in installation in the US,\" Associate Professor Wagner told AAP.\n\n\"It's essentially like ripping up $100 bills.\"\n\nThe sites nominated for nuclear plants include Loy Yang Power Station in Victoria, Callide and Tarong in Queensland, Mount Piper at Lithgow in central west NSW and Liddell in NSW's Hunter region.\n\nSmall, modular reactors would also be built at Northern Power Station in Port Augusta and at Muja Power Station, southeast of Perth.\n\nProf Wagner savaged the coalition plan as an \"absolute joke\" and questioned if they had checked the locations announced were appropriate for nuclear plants.\n\n\"We would need to have significant geological investigation into those areas, whether they would be suitable to have that type of plant built there,\" he said.\n\n\"Are they the right places to install them based on the geological properties of that area? I sincerely doubt that the opposition has sought an opinion on that.\"\n\nOn the coalition's pledge that the first two nuclear power plants would be built between 2035 and 2037, Prof Wagner said it was \"extremely unlikely\", citing a lack of human capital.\n\n\"It is undoubtedly extremely difficult to build them and highly technical,\" he said.\n\n\"Even if we were able to procure the right people to build it, I sincerely doubt that it would be built by 2035 ... it's just not feasible.\"\n\nMr Dutton said the planned rollout is sensible and achievable.\n\nThe CSIRO in May reported the {"uri": "8186797815", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "10:15:14", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T10:15:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T10:14:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://www.businessinsider.com/nuclear-energy-nuclear-power-ai-data-servers-transmutex-nuclear-waste-2024-6", "title": "This new technology for nuclear power could help fuel the AI revolution", "body": "This story is available exclusively to Business Insider subscribers. Become an Insider and start reading now. Have an account? Log in.\n\nScientists have long considered nuclear energy one of the cleanest and most reliable forms of energy production. However, the waste it creates must be stored in deep geological repositories for thousands of years to prevent the environment from being exposed to harmful radiation. Transmutex says its technology can \"transmute\" 99% of the world's high-level radioactive waste into new fuel.\n\nNagra, the Swiss agency that manages nuclear waste, validated the claim as a \"theoretical possibility\" in a letter to the company last month.\n\nSwitzerland, however, has pivoted away from nuclear energy, in part because of the safety concerns made apparent by Japan's Fukushima disaster in 2011. But such disasters are rare and many other countries -- like the United States and Saudi Arabia, for example -- are betting on nuclear energy as the most efficient and sustainable option.\n\n\"To reach our goal of net zero by 2050, we have to at least triple our current nuclear capacity,\" US Energy Secretary Jennifer Granholm said in May.\n\nTech companies at the forefront of the AI revolution are also turning to nuclear energy to power their vast AI data centers.\n\nTransmutex CEO Franklin Servan-Schreiber believes the company can help these businesses go nuclear by destroying that long-term waste.\n\n\"If we know how to deal with the waste, even if it takes a long time, we still know that in the future there is a limit to that waste, which is not gonna be a million years. That's the key,\" he told Business Insider in an interview.\n\nTransmutex's technology uses high-energy subatomic particles known as neutrons to destroy highly radioactive nuclear waste. While it can take hundreds of thousands of years for nuclear waste to decay to safe radiation levels, Transmutex says its technology can shorten that timeframe to just decades.\n\nServan-Schreiber says that over time, this system can also turn that waste into fuel that can be used again in nuclear power plants -- a sort of nuclear recycling program.\n\n\"Because you're able to burn waste and release energy, overall the process is very profitable,\" Cameron Porter, a venture capitalist who manages Steel Atlas and is an investor in Transmutex, told Business Insider.\n\nNuclear physicists say the company's technology avoids one of the biggest concerns with nuclear energy: that the same fuel used to power nuclear plants can also be used to manufacture atomic weapons.\n\n\"We don't want that to happen,\" Andrei Afanasev, a professor of physics at George Washington University's Institute for Nuclear Studies, told Business Insider.\n\nTransmutex avoids this risk because it doesn't produce plutonium, a key element for making nuclear bombs.\n\nThe technology is also more efficient, Afanasev said. According to the Department of Energy, spent nuclear fuel can still have about 90% of its potential energy even after five\u202fyears of operation in a reactor.\n\nWith nuclear reactors, \"you just throw away a big chunk of energy that you could use for everybody,\" he said. \"So this technology addresses this issue. They can extract more energy from the existing fuel.\"\n\nThe AI industry is looking for new, more reliable power sources as the race to develop artificial intelligence ramps up.\n\n\"Energy, not compute, will be the No. 1 bottleneck to AI progress,\" Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg said on the Dwarkesh Podcast in April, referring to the computational resources needed for training and running AI models.\n\nOklo, a startup backed by OpenAI CEO Sam Altman, is betting on generating nuclear power through small nuclear reactors. Its Aurora reactor can run on spent nuclear waste.\n\nServan-Schreiber said nuclear power might be the only way to support the industry's massive energy demands.\n\n\"AI requires massive, industrial-scale amounts of energy,\" Servan-Schreiber said. \"Only nuclear power will be able to supply this massive energy demand in a reliable manner. With a technology like Transmutex (only one currently being proposed), the US can build classic uranium-based nuclear plants, such as the Vogtle plant in Georgia, without being burdened with high-level nuclear waste for hundreds of thousands of years.\"", "source": {"uri": "businessinsider.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Business Insider"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-394372140", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "08:01:06", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T08:01:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T08:00:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://www.afr.com/politics/federal/dutton-is-ready-for-a-fight-over-his-crazy-brave-nuclear-play-20240619-p5jmy7", "title": "Dutton is ready for a fight over his crazy-brave nuclear play", "body": "\"Man Who Was Paralysed With Fear Over Lack Of Details About Indigenous Voice Provides A One-Page Media Release For His Half A Trillion Dollar Nuclear Plan.\"\n\nFor now, however, Dutton and his colleagues are banking on the plug-and-play concept being enough.\n\nThat is, replace coal-fired generators with nuclear power stations, so the existing transmission infrastructure can be used to distribute the zero-emission energy, which would complement renewables.\n\nAnd contrast this with Labor's alternative to festoon the countryside and oceans with wind and solar farms and thousands of kilometres of poles and wires - all of which will still require back-up power.\n\nYou only have to consider the political context in which Wednesday's announcement was made to understand the Coalition feels it is a risk worth taking.\n\nIt was anticipated Dutton would announce his plans in July, during the parliamentary winter break. But given the Coalition had been setting the agenda since the May budget, which the opinion polls show is paying dividends, why stop now?\n\nParliament resumes on Monday for another fortnight and Dutton is not perturbed at what he knows will be coming from the government.\n\n\"He wants the fight,\" said a colleague.\n\nMoreover, once upon a time, advocating nuclear power was political suicide. Now Dutton is proposing seven nuclear plants in Coalition electorates, but not before polling them to gauge sentiment.\n\nClearly that sentiment was deemed favourable enough, especially when accompanied by the offer of cut-price power for locals, to enable the policy announcement to proceed.\n\nIt is understood there was 55 per cent support in the seat of Gippsland for a power plant on the site of the Loy Yang coal station. Support was 60 per cent in another of the seats.\n\nThe Coalition is not ruling out releasing more detail, such as cost, but wanted to get the sites on the record to kneecap a growing government campaign which featured beautiful coastal landscapes blighted by nuclear power plants.\n\nThe Albanese government began carpet-bombing Dutton's nuclear plans about a month ago, suggesting it, too, was picking up positive vibes towards the concept of nuclear power.\n\nThat campaign will intensify over coming months given this issue, which Dutton is conflating with the cost of living, will be front and centre come election time.\n\nLabor would be well advised to mount its attack on fact - cost, achievability, believability and plausibility - and not demonise a power source that is more popular than coal, but still lags solar, gas, wind and hydrogen, as the most recent The Australian Financial Review/Freshwater Strategy poll reaffirmed.\n\nThe same poll showed Dutton's stature had grown while Labor was being marked down on its handling of climate change and the cost of living.\n\nThe question now is whether Dutton has pushed it too far with an uncosted announcement and will be deemed by voters to have over-egged the pudding?", "source": {"uri": "afr.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Australian Financial Review"}, "authors": [{"uri": "phillip_coorey@afr.com", "name": "Phillip soaring billions of dollars above projections.\n\nMoreover, concerns over managing nuclear waste and environmental risks are also being considered.\n\nDutton argues his power plant by stating his I will be in a tent outside Tarong gates,\" she told AAP.\n\n\"It's a death sentence to that land.\n\n\"It's not happening. I can guarantee you now it will not happen at Tarong.\"\n\nMs Smith said building a nuclear plant on that land would be \"severing the connection to that sacred site of ours\".\n\n\"We are the custodians of the land, the land is our mother and we don't own our mother, we care for her,\" she said.\n\nQueensland Conservation Council's Paul Spearim said \"white Australia has a short-sighted approach to country\".\n\nHe pointed to Maralinga and Emu Field in South Australia where the British held nuclear tests.\n\nMore than 1000 Indigenous people were exposed to radiation from the tests.\n\n\"You have forced poison onto the lands of traditional owners, and now Peter Dutton is proposing to create poisons that would last (hundreds of thousands) of years,\" Mr Spearim said.\n\n\"We have learnt that white Australia cannot be trusted with nuclear power, and you continue to act without care for our sacred country.\n\n\"We will fight these poisons, they are not welcome, and we will fight against proposals to force them upon us.\"\n\nOther sites put forward for nuclear plants include Loy Yang Power Station in Victoria, Callide in Queensland, Mount Piper at {"uri": "8186541286", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "07:34:40", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T07:34:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T07:34:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://www.theepochtimes.com/world/prime-minister-rejects-nuclear-stands-by-cheapest-form-of-energy-5671875", "title": "Prime Minister Rejects Nuclear, Stands by 'Cheapest Form of Energy'", "body": "Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says the Coalition's plans for a nuclear future for Australia are fantasy.\n\nThe prime minister has been critical of the plan by Opposition Leader Peter Dutton to introduce seven nuclear reactors across the nation, should Mr. Dutton take his job at the next election.\n\nSpeaking on the ABC's Breakfast Radio program, Mr. Albanese remained firm in his stance that renewables are the cheapest form of power.\n\nThe leader spoke of a 25 percent increase in renewables since Labor came to power, with record amounts spent on batteries and storage.\n\n\"We've seen 330,000 additional rooftops have solar panels on them,\" Mr. Albanese said.\n\n\"Because households recognise that it makes sense for households to reduce their energy bills by having renewable energy. And just as it makes sense for an individual household, it makes sense for our national economy as well.\n\n\"That's why we've approved 50 major renewable energy projects right around the country. And we know that it's the cheapest form of new energy.\"\n\nHe has also expressed concern over a lack of detail in Mr. Dutton's plan, such as the absence of costings, a definite timeframe or information on what proportion of nuclear will be incorporated into the power system.\n\nAustralian Foreign Minister Penny Wong also chimed in on the debate, saying on the ABC that the plan was \"a risky and expensive gamble that won't work.\"\n\nShe said nuclear reactions would deliver more expensive power following years of public subsidy.\n\n\"Is this what Peter Dutton wants Blinky to look like in 50 years?\" he said.\n\nMr. Leigh said the Coalition's plan would prevent the delivery of reliable renewables and clean energy jobs, subject Australia to years of rolling black-outs, and raise taxes to pay for what he says is the most expensive form of energy.\n\nBut Mr. Dutton has proposed a full roll-out of the seven reactors by the 2040s, if elected.\n\nHe told reporters Labor's renewables policy was \"not fit for purpose.\"\n\n\"No other country in the world can keep the lights on 24/7 with the renewables-only policy. We need to ensure hospitals can stay on 24/7, we need to ensure that cold rooms can stay on 24/7, we need to make sure that our economy could function 24/7 -- and we can only do that with a strong baseload power,\" he said.", "source": {"uri": "theepochtimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "www.theepochtimes.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8187271185", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "15:09:30", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T15:09:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T15:08:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/article/2024/jun/21/power-bills-could-rise-by-1000-a-year-under-coalition-plan-to-boost-gas-until-nuclear-is-ready-analysts-say", "title": "Power bills could rise by $1,000 a year under Coalition plan to boost gas until nuclear is ready, analysts say", "body": "Australians could face an increase in annual household power bills of up to $1,000 under a Coalition plan to slow the rollout of large-scale renewable energy and use more gas-fired electricity before nuclear plants are ready, analysts say.\n\nAs Peter Dutton faced cross-party resistance to his announcement that he would go to the next election promising to eventually build seven nuclear plants, energy market analysts warned the Coalition's proposal would probably lead to a significant rise in prices over the next decade, before a nuclear industry came online.\n\nFew details of the opposition's proposal have been released, but Dutton told a press conference on Wednesday that the Coalition would restrict investment in solar and windfarms and cover the electricity shortfall created as old coal-fired plants shut over the next two decades by using more gas power.\n\nAnalysts said gas was a far more expensive power source in the national grid than renewable energy or coal, and opening new gas basins was unlikely to change this as the country's cheap gas had already been extracted. They said adding more gas power could also increase greenhouse gas emissions, accelerating the climate crisis.\n\nTristan Edis, a director with the firm Green Energy Markets, said the wholesale electricity price was set by the most expensive fuel being used at any given time. Those prices were \"very high\" - between $250 and $300 per megawatt hour of electricity, about three times the average price - whenever fast-start gas plants were used to complement cheaper coal, solar, wind and hydro energy.\n\nGas currently provides less than 5% of electricity in the national electricity market, and is only called on when needed to meet demand.\n\nEdis said if a Coalition government put a hold on investment in solar and windfarms and boosted gas power so that it was replacing coal and always setting the price, \"you're talking about an increase of $500 to potentially even $1,000 per annum for a household power bill\".\n\nDr Roger Dargaville, an associate professor and the interim director of the Monash Energy Institute, said it was difficult to predict what the Coalition's announcement would mean for bills due to a lack of detail, but agreed the increase in an annual bill could be $1,000.\n\n\"It seems the options being presented will either lead to extraordinary maintenance bills to keep old coal plants going or using a lot more gas,\" he said. \"Coal is a very cheap fuel, so if you're going from a coal-dominated system to a gas-dominated system, you are going to see very steep energy prices.\"\n\nDargaville said more renewable energy backed by \"firming\" support - including energy storage, new transmission lines and gas power only when required - was \"the only sensible option and almost certainly the least cost option\".\n\nDr Dylan McConnell, an energy systems researcher at the University of New South Wales, agreed that using more gas-fired power would push up prices for consumers.\n\nHe estimated the increase in annual bills, if gas replaced renewable energy as the main new energy source over the next decade, could be $400 or $500.\n\n\"If you slow the rollout of renewable energy and backfill with gas we're talking about quite a large cost,\" McConnell said.\n\nThe analysts' estimates are at odds with the Coalition's claim that its approach would lead to \"cheaper, cleaner and consistent electricity\" compared with the Albanese government's goal of 82% of generation coming from renewable sources by 2030.\n\nThe shadow treasurer, Angus Taylor, told the ABC's Radio National on Thursday that power prices could be reduced under the Coalition before nuclear came online because of \"shorter-term strategies\" including using more gas.\n\nThe opposition has said it would make announcements on gas and renewable energy before the election. Coalition MPs have signalled they may offer more support for household solar systems, but stall investment in the large-scale renewable developments. The Nationals leader, David Littleproud, has argued \"we won't need them\".\n\nDutton said he wanted the commonwealth to build nuclear plants on the site of existing or past coal-fired plants in Queensland, New South Wales, Victoria, Western Australia and South Australia.\n\nBut he has not released the cost of the plants, explained how the Coalition would lift legislated federal and state bans on nuclear power, or said why he believed the first two plants could be operating by 2035 or 2037 - a much faster timeframe than experts say would be possible.\n\nOn Friday, progressive thinktank the Australia Institute released the results of a survey of 1,005 Australians that it commissioned from the firm Dynata in May.\n\nIt found nearly two-thirds (65%) said they were not prepared to pay extra to have nuclear power in the mix.\n\nHowever, nearly one-quarter of respondents said they would be prepared to pay more to introduce nuclear. About 4% said they were prepared to pay more than $500 extra a year.\n\nThe executive director of the Australia Institute, Richard Denniss, said it showed that \"residents across the country, regardless of who they vote for, don't support a nuclear future that requires them pay more for electricity than they already do\".", "source": {"uri": "theguardian.com", "dataType": "news", "title": I will be in a tent outside Tarong gates,\" she told AAP.\n\n\"It's a death sentence to that land.\n\n\"It's not happening. I can guarantee you now it will not happen at Tarong.\"\n\nMs Smith said building a nuclear plant on that land would be \"severing the connection to that sacred site of ours\".\n\n\"We are the custodians of the land, the land is our mother and we don't own our mother, we care for her,\" she said.\n\nQueensland Conservation Council's Paul Spearim said \"white Australia has a short-sighted approach to country\".\n\nHe pointed to Maralinga and Emu Field in South Australia where the British held nuclear tests.\n\nMore than 1000 Indigenous people were exposed to radiation from the tests.\n\n\"You have forced poison onto the lands of traditional owners, and now Peter Dutton is proposing to create poisons that would last (hundreds of thousands) of years,\" Mr Spearim said.\n\n\"We have learnt that white Australia cannot be trusted with nuclear power, and you continue to act without care for our sacred country.\n\n\"We will fight these poisons, they are not welcome, and we will fight against proposals to force them upon us.\"\n\nOther sites put forward for nuclear plants include Loy Yang Power Station in Victoria, Callide in Queensland, Mount Piper at Lithgow in central west NSW and Liddell in NSW's Hunter region.\n\nSmall, modular reactors would be built at Northern Power Station in Port Augusta and at Muja Power Station, southeast of Perth.\n\nGet the latest news from thewest.com.au in your inbox.\n\nSign up for our emails", "source": {"uri": "thewest.com.au", "dataType": "news", "title": "The West Australian"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8186223794", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "02:57:09", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T02:57:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T02:54:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "url": "https://expressdigest.com/peter-van-onselen-deformed-pets-three-eyed-fish-and-even-lara-bingle-in-a-bikini-anthony-albaneses-anti-nuclear-power-campaign-is-an-insult-to-aussie-voters/", "title": "PETER VAN ONSELEN: Deformed pets, three-eyed fish and even Lara Bingle in a bikini: Anthony Albanese's anti-nuclear power campaign is an insult to Aussie voters", "body": "It's taken less than 24 hours for the childish scare campaign around Peter Dutton's nuclear energy policy to flood social media.\n\nI'm not talking about posts by the average user. Federal and state Labor leaders and the union movement quickly began posting improbable and downright ridiculous ways to try and undermine nuclear power.\n\nDeformed pets, references to The Simpsons, toxic spills causing three-eyed fish and images suggesting the sites might be located near iconic natural wonders such as Victoria's Twelve Apostles were just some of the immature games being played by parliamentarians.\n\nI did say yesterday that the mother of all scare campaigns would soon start but I didn't think it would be quite this pathetic.\n\nThe Australian Union movement suggested the family dog would become deformed as a result of Peter Dutton's nuclear power proposal\n\nVictorian Premier Jacinta Allan's team produced this Simpsons-inspired meme - with Ms Allan slamming nuclear power as 'toxic'\n\nAssistant Minister for Competition, Charities and Treasury Dr Andrew Leigh shared a photoshopped image of Blinky Bill with three eyes\n\nIt isn't as though there aren't serious problems with Dutton's announcement - I'll come to those shortly.\n\nVictoria's new premier Jacinta Allan, no less, posted mocked up images of three-eyed cartoon fish leaping out of the water in Gippsland, writing: 'The Liberal Party want a toxic and expensive nuclear reactor in Gippsland.'\n\nAnthony Albanese's contribution wasn't much better: 'Instead of Snow White and the Seven Dwarves, this is Peter Dutton and the seven nuclear reactors'.\n\nI wonder how long it took the PM's taxpayer funded team of 11 media advisers to come up with that one. Or did Albo proudly think it up all on his own?\n\nPoll\n\nDo you think Australia should embrace a nuclear power future?\n\nYes, nuclear energy is the way forward 121 votes No, I prefer renewables 10 votes We need a mix of both nuclear and renewables 25 votes\n\nSeizing upon The Simpsons theme, Victorian federal MP Josh Burns tweeted images of nuclear reactors with the Liberal Party logo on them, writing 'under Peter Dutton Australians will glow green'.\n\nClever stuff.\n\nDr Andrew Leigh - one of Labor's brainiacs, having completed his PhD at Harvard - shared a Photoshopped image of Blinky Bill with three eyes.\n\nThe guy used to be a professor. Does serving in parliament lower one's IQ?\n\nAt 62 years of age Labor MP for the Victorian seat of Corangamite, Libby Cocker, wasn't too mature to take a similar dig, days before Dutton's announcement.\n\nThe federal Victorian MP riffed off the 'where the bloody hell are you' tourism campaign of yesteryear spearheaded by Lara Bingle.\n\nCocker, who was a school teacher before entering politics, tweeted a mock up of a bikini-clad Bingle standing in front of the 12 Apostles on the Victorian coastline with three nuclear reactors billowing smoke behind her.\n\nThere really must be something in the water in Victoria - before the nuclear waste arrives as is being alleged.\n\nThe Simpsons references were running thick and fast\n\nThe Australian Manufacturing Workers Union shared an image of a Chernobyl-style dystopia\n\nThe Australian union movement's official X page posted an image of a deformed something or another, it was hard to tell, above the headline 'this will be your family dog'.\n\nScare campaigns are rarely rooted in accuracy, and that is a bipartisan problem. But they are rarely this childish in nature.\n\nIt will be interesting to see if these callow MPs and vested interests continue to act this way, or sharpen up their attacks in the weeks and months ahead.\n\nHistory tells us that scare campaigns work, especially against big bold policy ideas raised by Oppositions. But do they work when they are this low brow?\n\nAs mentioned earlier on, if anyone wants to seriously critique Dutton's policy there is plenty to dig into without having to resort to juvenile antics.\n\nFor example, Dutton says he plans to use existing coal fired power sites and the government will pay for and own the operations.\n\nBut most of the private owners of these sites have already ruled out relinquishing them to a Coalition government, and they weren't consulted before the policy was announced.\n\nBefore Dutton revealed where the reactors would be placed, Labor MP Libby Coker shared this meme, inspired by Lara Bingle's famous Tourism Australia ad\n\nMost of the sites Dutton has announced are in states that have legislatively banned nuclear power, and a number of these Premiers have already ruled out changing that.\n\nThe policy hasn't been costed, much less modelled to ascertain what taxpayers might be up for if or when construction was to begin.\n\nWe don't even know who the Coalition engaged to produce this policy. Is it rooted in any scholarly research beyond a superficial thought bubble announcement?\n\nWe're also still in the dark about which types of nuclear reactors the Opposition is proposing to build: the new smaller modules or the more established larger varieties used in other parts of the world?\n\nIt is a pretty basic choice - and it was not included in a major policy announcement.\n\nSo yes, there are serious questions for serious people to raise requiring serious answers before Team Dutton can expect Australians to get behind his proposal.\n\nUnfortunately the Labor government and its union mates seem largely incapable of reaching high and properly challenging the policy announcement.\n\nInstead they choose to play in the sandpit on social media.\n\nNo wonder the public has such a dim {"uri": "2024-06-395112011", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "19:48:04", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T19:48:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T19:43:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "url": "https://www.abc.net.au/news/2024-06-20/coalition-backs-away-from-nuclear-consent-community-call/103998784", "title": "Coalition backs away from plan to progress nuclear only with 'consent' of host communities", "body": "The Coalition's pursuit of nuclear reactors in seven communities would proceed even if locals reject them, despite Coalition MPs previously saying going nuclear would be conditional on obtaining community \"consent\".\n\nReleasing a report in 2019 titled \"Nuclear Energy -- Not without your approval\", then-chair of parliament's energy committee Ted O'Brien said a future government should only proceed with nuclear power on the condition that it make a \"commitment to community consent for approving nuclear facilities\".\n\n\"Most importantly the Australian people should be at the centre of any approval process,\" he said at the time.\n\nMr O'Brien, now the Coalition's shadow energy minister, stood with colleagues yesterday as they announced the party's proposal to build seven nuclear power plants as its answer to the nation's future energy needs and the promise to reach net zero emissions by 2050.\n\n\"Those seven communities which have been identified, which will host these zero-emissions nuclear power plants, we'll be working together with them to define the vision specifically tailored to their area,\" Mr O'Brien said.\n\nBut Nationals Leader David Littleproud confirmed yesterday the party's proposed nuclear plants would not live or die on the consent of host communities, correcting his deputy Perin Davey who said the Coalition would not proceed with nuclear in towns that were adamantly opposed.\n\n\"She is not correct and we made this very clear. [Opposition Leader] Peter Dutton and David Littleproud as part of a Coalition government are prepared to make the tough decisions in the national interest,\" Mr Littleproud told ABC's Afternoon Briefing.\n\n\"Ultimately, we need strong leadership in this country to have the courage of its convictions to follow through and to make the tough calls in the nation's interest.\"\n\nMr Littleproud said the Coalition would undertake a lengthy two-and-a-half-year consultation, and would seek a national mandate through the federal election.\n\nMr Dutton said yesterday he was confident earmarked communities would back the Coalition's nuclear proposal.\n\nRetiring Liberal MP Rowan Ramsey, whose seat of Grey in South Australia contains one of the seven proposed nuclear sites, said he would have to reconsider his support of a nuclear reactor if his community did not back it.\n\n\"I think we're a fair way away from that position, [but] if at the end of the day the community clearly expressed its view it didn't want it, I would probably reconsider my position as well,\" Mr Ramsey told the ABC.\n\nLiberal MP Rick Wilson, whose electorate of O'Connor has also been flagged for a nuclear site, told the ABC in March \"a social licence is a pre-requisite for any major energy infrastructure project\".\n\nFaults near earmarked nuclear sites would need further study\n\nAs well as finding the numbers in the Senate to lift a federal nuclear ban and convincing several states to lift state-level nuclear bans, a future Coalition government would also need to find out whether the seven sites it proposes for nuclear are actually geologically suitable.\n\nMr Littleproud said preliminary assessments had been made and there would be further assessments made.\n\nNuclear regulator ARPANSA has a long list of conditions that should be met for a controlled-nuclear facility to be established, including landslide and erosion considerations, soil and rock types, stability, groundwater levels and surface faulting.\n\nThe National Seismic Hazard Assessment by Geoscience Australia says \"damaging earthquakes in Australia are considered [a] low probability but high consequence event\".\n\nGeoscience Australia's earthquake hazard scientist Tamarah King told the ABC while some of the proposed nuclear sites are near faults, \"globally there are plenty of nuclear sites in high hazard regions that are engineered to withstand potential geological hazards\".\n\n\"There are only some geological characteristics that would pose an un-engineerable hazard which would mean the site could not be safely considered for a nuclear power point,\" Dr King said.\n\n\"In the Australian context, this includes the identification of a fault capable of producing large earthquakes and surface offsets within the immediate vicinity, the liquefaction potential of a site, the likelihood of underground cave collapse, and landslide potential.\"\n\nThe agency said it had identified faults across Australia with \"demonstrated or suspected history\" of generating large earthquakes, but they would require detailed study to understand whether they pose a hazard to infrastructure near-term or into the future.\n\nSeismology Research Centre chief scientist Adam Pascale said site-specific seismic hazard assessments would be necessary.\n\n\"For the Victorian site at Loy Yang ... there is a lot of earthquake activity in Gippsland and that region. We've seen even in recent years large earthquakes in the region, so that would be something certainly to look at,\" Mr Pascale said.\n\n\"Some of the other areas where there's proposed sites I know there have been studies, but again, everything would need a site-specific study.\n\n\"Within Australia, we can have a magnitude-7.5 earthquake, that's our maximum credible earthquake for within our plate, and that could happen anywhere at some point in the future, so you can't really rule out anywhere as immune from earthquakes.\"\n\nMr Pascale said earthquake risk did not necessarily invalidate a site, but rather would require more investment to make a facility earthquake-resistant.", "source": {"uri": "abc.net.au", "dataType": "news", "title": "Australian Broadcasting Corporation"}, {"uri": "8184954050", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "08:44:24", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T08:44:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T08:43:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "url": "https://www.afr.com/policy/energy-and-climate/towns-at-ground-zero-say-if-nuclear-means-jobs-bring-it-on-20240619-p5jn5e", "title": "Towns at ground zero say if nuclear means jobs, bring it on", "body": "And while the nuclear disasters in Chernobyl and Fukushima are etched into his mind, the 56-year-old said people in the region need work.\n\n\"Nobody wants a three-eyed fish in their town. But I still think nuclear is worth considering,\" Mr Ceeney told The Australian Financial Review.\n\n\"Peter Dutton is pretty brave to open up the discussion in today's political climate before an election. I don't know if I support it, but I applaud it.\"\n\nUnder Mr Dutton's plan, which was supported without dissent by the Coalition party room on Wednesday, there would be five large-scale power plants and two small modular reactors, or SMRs, all in operation by 2050.\n\nThe large-scale plants, which would have a capacity of between 1 gigawatt and 1.4 gigawatts, would be built on the site of old coal-fired power stations including Loy Yang in Traralgon.\n\nThis comes despite the CSIRO last month warning the first large-scale nuclear power plant could cost as much as $17 billion in today's dollars, and would not be operational until at least 2040.\n\nMr Ceeney, who lives in the town of Churchill, about 15 minutes away from Loy Yang, said he would be open to nuclear in the region. But he's also open to renewables manufacturing. His main concerns are jobs and power prices.\n\n\"We used to have the cheapest electricity going and granted it's dirty and nasty, but now we've gone the other end of the spectrum where we're losing jobs in manufacturing because of it,\" the 56-year-old said.\n\n\"The buzzword around here is new energy. It's nice, exciting and attractive, but it doesn't appear to have any substance that would bring real jobs.\n\n\"Any power plant would have construction jobs and ongoing jobs. The power industry created so many skills and opportunities. And so I think nuclear could maybe do the same, but right now I just want to learn more.\"\n\nMorwell newsagent Ray Burgess is far more bullish about the prospect of nuclear in the Latrobe Valley, handing over a copy of a booklet produced by the University of Queensland called What would be required for nuclear energy plants to be operating in Australia from the 2030s.\n\nThe 69-year-old, who worked as a supervisor for the old State Electricity Commission in the early 1990s before taking over the newsagency, reckons nuclear is an opportunity for the Latrobe Valley.\n\n\"Ultimately, what I'm for is prosperity in the region,\" he said.\n\n\"The power stations had jobs for nearly everyone. You had people sweeping the turbine room floor, as well as fitters and joiners. That's all disappearing.\"\n\nLatrobe City Council mayor Darren Howe said if the Coalition was prepared to the run the next election on nuclear energy then it was a \"serious option\" that needed to be fully considered by the community. But the mayor said he was energy-agnostic and would be just as happy if Morwell and Traralgon became a manufacturing hub for wind turbines or solar panels.\n\n\"We've been the powerhouse of Victoria for 100 years, that's what we're known for and what our community hangs it hat on, so why can't we do that for the next 100 years? Whatever the energy mix ends up looking like, we need to leverage it as much as possible,\" he said.\n\nTraralgon clothing retailer Jill Magnuson, on the other hand, said that while she feared businesses like hers would suffer after Yallourn and Loy Yang power stations closed down, she didn't want nuclear anywhere near her.\n\n\"Nobody really wants a nuclear plant in their backyard,\" she said.\n\n\"But I'm also pretty sceptical about the cost and time it would take to set up. We can't seem to build enough houses for everyone right now, so how would we go building nuclear?\"\n\nThis outright rejection of nuclear in Traralgon was shared by a small group of protesters outside Gippsland MP Darren Chester's office on Wednesday.\n\nVoices of the Valley spokeswoman Wendy Farmer, who helped organise the protest, said the Latrobe Valley was not a \"dumping ground\".\n\n\"Peter Dutton is dreaming up a nuclear nightmare,\" she said.\n\n\"The proposal to build a nuclear power plant in the Latrobe Valley, on a geological fault line, in a community that already suffered the impacts of the Hazelwood coal mine fire, is dangerous and insulting\".", "source": {"uri": "afr.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Australian Financial Review"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8185738989", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "17:40:59", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T17:40:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T17:40:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://www.perthnow.com.au/politics/duttons-nuclear-reactor-over-budget-and-a-joke-c-15079680", "title": "Dutton's nuclear reactor 'over budget' and a 'joke'", "body": "A type of nuclear reactor put forward by the coalition as an option under its energy plan has been slammed by an energy economist as \"irresponsible\".\n\nSeven nuclear power plants would be built at the sites of coal-fired power stations if the coalition wins the federal election.\n\nThe coalition wanted to \"rely\" on the Westinghouse-manufactured AP1000 reactor, Opposition Leader Peter Dutton said when unveiling his long-awaited policy.\n\n\"In terms of the small, modular reactor, or the AP1000 or whatever it might be, that we believe would be the best for each of those sites, we'll have those discussions in due course,\" Mr Dutton said.\n\nBut Curtin University Sustainable Engineering Group's Associate Professor Liam Wagner rubbished the proposal, because the AP1000 had consistently been late in its build time and was over budget.\n\n\"It would be irresponsible to seek that as the preferred option, given that significant delays that it's faced in installation in the US,\" he told AAP.\n\n\"It's essentially like ripping up $100 bills.\"\n\nThe sites nominated for nuclear plants include Loy Yang Power Station in Victoria, Callide and Tarong in Queensland, Mount Piper at Lithgow in central west NSW and Liddell in NSW's Hunter region.\n\nSmall, modular reactors would also be built at Northern Power Station in Port Augusta and at Muja Power Station, southeast of Perth.\n\nNo costings have been provided.\n\nAssociate Professor Wagner was scathing of the coalition's \"absolute joke\" of a plan and questioned if they had checked the locations announced were appropriate for nuclear plants.\n\n\"We would need to have significant geological investigation into those areas, whether they would be suitable to have that type of plant built there,\" he said.\n\n\"Are they the right places to install them based on the geological properties of that area? I sincerely doubt that the opposition has sought an opinion on that.\"\n\nOn the coalition's pledge that the first two nuclear power plants would be built between 2035 and 2037, Associate Professor Wagner said it was \"extremely unlikely\".\n\n\"It is undoubtedly extremely difficult to build them and highly technical,\" he said.\n\n\"We don't have the human capital here in Australia to be able to do that on our own.\n\n\"Even if we were able to procure the right people to build it, I sincerely doubt that it would be built by 2035 ... it's just not feasible.\"\n\nMr Dutton said the planned rollout is sensible and achievable.\n\nThe CSIRO last month reported the first nuclear plants would not be achieved until 2040 at the earliest.\n\nEnergy Minister Chris Bowen said the announcement produced many more questions than answers.\n\n\"The Liberals and Nationals promised you a sensible energy plan. Instead, they're giving you a risky nuclear scam,\" he said.\n\n\"We know that nuclear is too expensive, too slow to build, and too risky for energy reliability.\"", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8186237945", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "03:11:35", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T03:11:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T03:10:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://www.miragenews.com/australian-prime-minister-television-interview-1259714/", "title": "Australian Prime Minister Television Interview 20 June", "body": "Let's go live to Prime Minister, Anthony Albanese. Prime Minister, thanks for your time, as always. One of your predecessors, a much loved figure in your Party and beyond that, the late, great Bob Hawke. He said in 2016, nuclear power would be a win for the environment and an essential part of attacking dangerous global warming. Why not at least consider it?\n\nANTHONY ALBANESE, PRIME MINISTER: Let's be clear here, Bob Hawke can't speak for himself, so I think it's pretty tacky that the Coalition attempting to use a quote out of context as well, of my dear late friend Bob Hawke. What we're dealing with here in 2024 is a Coalition so-called plan that hasn't lasted a day. They've said there are seven sites, but they haven't said whether they're going to be compulsorily required. They say there'll be a community consultation process. One of the Shadow Ministers has said that that'll have the right of veto. So, will they go and look for other spots? Others have said there'll be compulsory acquisition. Peter Dutton is now saying, after saying just that yesterday, now saying, 'Oh, well, we'll convince them that they're on board', even though six of the seven owners of those sites have rejected this proposal. Every state and territory where it's proposed has rejected the proposals. Even the Queensland LNP are saying they don't want a bar of this. They've made an announcement without any substance, no costings, no real timelines, no idea of what form the reactors will take, how big they will be, what the engagement with the community is. This is farcical, frankly, Kieran. This is economic catastrophe. When we look at the costs of nuclear, what we know is that it's the most expensive form of new energy. So, my Government is providing $300 off energy bills in two weeks. The Dutton Opposition are saying, 'In two decades, we'll give you the most expensive form of energy that there is, new energy. And what's more, we'll have government ownership and send all the bills to the taxpayers because there is no way that not a single private bank or financier in this country would go anywhere near this because it's such a risky economic proposition'.\n\nGILBERT: You say that it's economic catastrophe, but let's look at Europe. There are more than 100 nuclear plants. France has dozens. It provides a clear majority of that country's power supply. Why are you so adamant it can't be part of our mix?\n\nPRIME MINISTER: Listen to the experts, Kieran. The International Energy Agency that is very much pro-nuclear energy says that Australia is not an appropriate venue because of the comparative advantages that we have. Kieran, if you go outside in Australia, you can fry an egg on a footpath during the summer. We have the best solar resources in the world. We have such a comparative advantage if we seize the opportunities which are there. The CSIRO say that compared with renewable energy with firming, it's up to eight times more expensive. It is decades away. Not only will this cost more, it will make energy supply more insecure, because there's no answer either of what happens between now and two decades' time for how energy supply is secured. They spent almost a decade in office saying that we needed to extend the life of coal fired power. They had proponents like in Collinsville, where they paid the people who wanted to build a coal fired power plant money to do the study and to do the preparatory work, and it ended up in zero, just as they said that Liddell should stay open. Indeed, no new coal fired power plants were built on their watch. And 14 of them announced their closure. Now, they've moved away from coal, but they've found another destination of denial. And that destination of denial is nuclear. In the meantime, what will happen is that there'll be issues of more energy insecurity because we know that it is disrupting the certainty that the business community have been crying out for. That's how you reduce prices, by increasing supply, offering the business community the certainty that they've been asking for. And that is what we have done.\n\nGILBERT: But when you look at the cost question, I want to put this to you because this is one of the fundamental arguments Peter Dutton is making is that, say, if you look at something like the Illawarra wind farm, that in itself is going to cost billions. I think the figure out there is about $10 billion, but its lifespan is up to 30 years for wind turbines, a nuclear power facility is up to 100 years. So, the cost comparison needs to factor in the lifespan of the assets as well. What do you say to that?\n\nPRIME MINISTER: Kieran, this is a mob that when they were in government, couldn't build a commuter car park, but say that government, the Federal Government, that has no experience whatsoever in building government-owned energy assets, energy assets historically were owned by state governments, and Coalition governments were quite happy to flog them off when they found it convenient. Now, you would have us believe that a mob who'd struggle to assemble an Ikea flat-pack are going to start from scratch and be able to develop a nuclear energy industry in Australia, even though they can't say what form the nuclear reactors will take. Last night, I saw their Energy Shadow Minister struggling to concede the fact that these small modular reactors they speak about don't exist anywhere in the world right now. Don't exist. But they're going to be from scratch, ahead of the entire curve. That's why the International Energy Agency have said it's not appropriate for Australia. What we know is that the cheapest form of new energy is renewables. And what we know as well is that the business community have said we want certainty. That's what we've done. A 43 per cent legislated target, a net zero by 2050 legislated target in place. The capacity investment scheme, encouraging investment. The safeguard mechanism to drive that business certainty with the trajectory so that we reach net zero. That's why there's no business leaders coming out and saying they support this. In terms of the energy sector, where are they saying, 'We want to pitch in and build these nuclear reactors'? And that's why Peter Dutton has had to take the remarkable step for a Coalition government of having a command-style economy approach and building these nuclear reactors from scratch decades into the future, the most costly form of energy. And guess what? Guess what? Taxpayers will foot the bill for Peter Dutton's nuclear fantasy.\n\nGILBERT: Well, given those numbers and the facts as you see it, would you urge your colleagues, and I point to one of your frontbenchers who tweeted an image of Blinky Bill with three eyes, and Jacinta Allan tweeted a three-eyed fish today, you know, would you tell them to steer clear of some of that stuff and focus on the facts? I ask you that in the context of if that's the sort of scare campaign they're going to run, what about the submariners on the AUKUS submarines? And what would you say to our AUKUS allies about our ability to manage nuclear waste? It's a serious issue, isn't it? Would you urge your colleagues to steer clear of some of that stuff?\n\nPRIME MINISTER: We're not going to take lectures, Kieran, we're not going to take lectures from the Coalition that are out there running scare campaigns about everything. Every issue is an opportunity for them to steer away from the facts. Look, this is an announcement without any detail. I cannot recall a serious government or alternative government coming out with a policy such as this, with not a single costing, with just a media release, which is more than Peter Dutton's Budget Reply had, which had no media releases, no costings. This is a mob that have not produced a costing for policies in the more than two years now with three budget replies from Peter Dutton. When I was the Leader of the Labor Party and Leader of the Opposition, I produced fully costed policies in areas like child care, in rewiring the nation, in the National Reconstruction Fund, in a whole range of areas. I put them forward with substance. This mob think they can just get through by running. Remember where this has been driven by as well. This is a scare campaign. Worried about a solar panel scaring people is what they have tried. And six of the seven sites have said they don't want a bar of this. In Port Augusta, the site that they have so-called identified, this is how hopeless they've been, has already been taken up with other activity that is creating jobs. And I saw the local Member there saying, 'Oh, well, we'll put it somewhere near there and somehow connect it up with the grid'. Liddell is, I've been up at Liddell, what Liddell have done is sign deals with Sundrive. They're going to be doing a range of activities there, including manufacturing the world's most efficient solar panels there on the Liddell site, employing more people than were employed under the former when the coal fired station, power station that they said they would keep open into the never-never that shut years ago on their watch.\n\nGILBERT: Their polling of those communities suggests that it's upwards.\n\nPRIME MINISTER: Have you seen it, Kieran? Have you seen it?\n\nGILBERT: We haven't seen it yet. I've been advised of it.\n\nPRIME MINISTER: Exactly. Exactly. Oh, you've been advised. You've been advised. Seriously? Seriously. What a joke. They're out there, you know, talking about a half-baked plan. There are no costs. The reason why there are no costings out there is because it is so expensive, because it doesn't add up. That's why they're trying to hide it. Just as Peter Dutton has said, 'We'll tell you what we're going to do on 2030 after the election'. And I'll make this tip, Kieran. There's a reason why people hide costings, and that's because those costings would completely rule out any rational person going down this nuclear road. What we have here is a bloke who's incapable of leading his party in any serious ways, who just agrees to whatever some of the extreme people in his show who want to, as David Littleproud has said really explicitly, they want to wind back renewables. It's not clear what they're saying. I noticed in the person you were speaking to beforehand saying, 'Oh, they've announced this policy and they'll announce their gas policy and their renewables policy down the road'. Well, we have all of our policy out there. It's one energy policy. It's coherent. It has the support of the business community and it's driving investment. There are more than 50 renewable energy projects underway that have been approved. We've seen a 25 per cent increase already in heading towards our target, which is there. We've seen more than 300,000 Australians in the last couple of years put solar panels on their roofs. The reason why they've done that is because it makes economic sense to drive down costs. And just as it makes sense for households, it makes sense for our entire economy as well.\n\nGILBERT: I know you've got to go and get a plane. But I do want to ask you a few other issues. A big week of news and commitments for you. One of them, of course, the Premier of China, the visit. Now, Peter Dutton said you lacked the backbone to strongly criticise the behaviour of those officials when Cheng Lei was blocked at that media event. In hindsight, could you have been more immediate in your criticism?\n\nPRIME MINISTER: Kieran, you were there at that event, I would assume. Peter Dutton was there. He stood up at the lunch afterwards with Premier Li and said absolutely nothing. He was a lion outside and a pussycat when in front of Premier Li and other Chinese officials, said nothing. The truth is that we responded very clearly. It was inappropriate activity. We made that clear. And I made it clear directly to Premier Li, which is more than Peter Dutton did. He left it up to Simon Birmingham to speak up and didn't raise it himself. The truth is as well, just to put some perspective here, the reason why Cheng Lei was at that press conference is because of the work that we did to ensure that she was brought home. Strongly advocating, as we do, always in Australia's national interest. We've managed to stabilise the relationship without compromising any of our values. And Peter Dutton, for all of his macho nonsense he goes on with, he's incapable of standing up to his own party. He's got people in his Caucus room who've been out there praising Vladimir Putin. He's got people out there putting all sorts of extreme positions opposing any action on COVID. He's got anti-vaxxers sitting there giving speeches in the Parliament that he's refused to say anything against. He can't even stand up to people in his own Party, let alone stand up for Australia's national interests globally. That's something that I've done and that's why Cheng Lei brought home, Sean Turnell brought home from Myanmar. People in Vietnam taken off death row. The actions that we've continued to put. And we always defend Australia's national interests.\n\nGILBERT: The Putin and Kim Jong Un summit in Pyongyang, that's quite the spectacle. The two despots having their diplomatic dance. But I ask you a serious question. Should China be doing more to rein those despots in and to ensure world peace like in Ukraine? They've got the influence there, why not use it?\n\nPRIME MINISTER: It's one of the issues that we put forward very strongly when I met with Premier Li. We think that China should use its influence with Russia. Vladimir Putin's illegal and immoral invasion of Ukraine has had a devastating impact on the people of Ukraine who are standing up for their sovereignty. But it's also had a devastating impact on the global economy. It is one of the major sources of global inflation that saw inflation hit double digits in places like the UK and have a real impact. So, we want all countries to put pressure on Russia. And we do directly, as well, by standing up with our allies, by providing support, now has been over a billion dollars that we've supported for Ukraine, that's so important. It's a struggle for the rule of international law and for national sovereignty to be respected. And the people of Ukraine, and I had another discussion with President Zelenskyy just a couple of weeks ago and praised the courage of him and his people, as did Bill Shorten when he represented Australia at the important summit that was held in Europe just last week.\n\nGILBERT: And finally, one out of left field. It hasn't been a major commitment of yours this week or priority, but one of my colleagues reporting on this, the Australian company DefendTex, it's seeking to purchase a Brazilian weapons manufacturer, Avibras. They want $70 million. It would give us a sovereign capacity. Our own Aussie-owned missile maker. Is the Government considering offering that support as a line?\n\nPRIME MINISTER: Well, Export Finance Australia are looking at that proposal. We're big supporters of our defence industry. Part of our agenda for a Future Made in Australia is about renewables, it's about manufacturing, it's about our defence industry, our pharmaceutical industry. It's about new high tech as well, and making sure that we're not only dealing with the immediate issues. So, in less than two weeks now, Kieran, on July 1, Monday week, what we'll have is not just a tax cut for every taxpayer, we'll have $300 energy bill relief for every household. We'll have a wage increase for everyone on the minimum wage and award wages. We'll also have further cheaper medicines come into play. And in addition to that, we've managed to achieve all of that while putting that downward pressure on inflation, which is half of what we inherited. And one of the ways we've done that is producing two budget surpluses in a row. So, we've done all that in the immediate sense. But we're also looking for what are the opportunities for new industries into the future. And what we are doing with our Future Made in Australia is in part about defence industry and about us being able to be more resilient as a national economy. And part of that is the examination of proposals such as the one that you've raised today.\n\nGILBERT: Prime Minister, thanks for your time. Apologies to your officials. I've gone way over the time they allocated. But thank you for being generous with your time. And on a big day in Australian politics. It's been a big week. I thank you for that.\n\nPRIME MINISTER: Always great to chat with you, Kieran.\n\n/Public Release. "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://www.aap.com.au/news/nuclear-conflict-brews-in-coalition-over-renewables/", "title": "Nuclear conflict brews in coalition over renewables", "body": "An internal rift is emerging in the coalition over nuclear power as the major parties prepare for battle over Australia's energy future.\n\nThe opposition has vowed to build seven nuclear plants at the sites of coal-fired power stations if it wins the next election but has been criticised for not revealing costs.\n\nSome Liberals have suggested there will be a big contribution from renewable energy at the same time leading Nationals want to restrict wind and sun-generated power.\n\nLiberal senator James Paterson said his party supported renewable energy.\n\n\"Renewables will be an important part of the mix as it is internationally,\" he said on Thursday.\n\nEarlier this week, Nationals leader David Littleproud said the coalition should send a clear policy that large-scale renewable projects would be restricted.\n\n\"We want to send the investment signals that there is a cap on where we will go with renewables and where we will put them,\" he said.\n\nPrime Minister Anthony Albanese said the cheapest form of new energy was renewable.\n\n\"That's why there is no one in the business community who's putting their hand up, not a single bank, not a single financier, not a single equity firm, saying 'yeah, we want to be involved in this',\" he said.\n\nLabor has committed $22.7 billion over the next decade for its Future Made in Australia plan, which aims to increase investment from the private sector for the energy transition.\n\nVoters would have a clear choice at the election, Energy Minister Chris Bowen said.\n\n\"Our energy policy, which we've been very clear about and implementing, and their fantasy which they can't answer key questions on,\" he said.\n\nMore details of the coalition's nuclear plan would be revealed \"in bite-sized bits\", Opposition Leader Peter Dutton said.\n\n\"We want the information out there in bite-sized bits so that people can consume exactly what it is that we're proposing and understand what it's not proposing,\" he said.\n\nThe coalition has promised to detail the cost of nuclear reactors before the election expected early next year.\n\nLiam Wagner, an associate professor in sustainable energy systems at Curtin University, poked holes in the nuclear proposal.\n\nHe rubbished a potential reliance on Westinghouse-manufactured reactors, which had experienced delays and budget blowouts abroad.\n\n\"It would be irresponsible to seek that as the preferred option, given the significant delays that it's faced in installation in the US,\" Dr Wagner told AAP.\n\n\"It's essentially like ripping up $100 bills.\"\n\nSites nominated for nuclear plants include Loy Yang Power Station in Victoria, Callide and Tarong in Queensland, Mount Piper at Lithgow in central west NSW and Liddell in NSW's Hunter region.\n\nSmall, modular reactors would be built at Northern Power Station in Port Augusta and at Muja Power Station, southeast of Perth.\n\nDr Wagner questioned whether the coalition checked the locations were {"uri": "8186163319", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "01:39:29", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T01:39:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T01:38:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13548855/PVO-Dutton-nuclear-Albo-scare-campaign-childish.html", "title": "PVO: Albo's childish anti-nuclear scare campaign an insult to Aussies", "body": "By Peter van Onselen, Political Editor for Daily Mail Australia\n\nIt's taken less than 24 hours for the childish scare campaign around Peter Dutton's nuclear energy policy to flood social media.\n\nI'm not talking about posts by the average user. Federal and state Labor leaders and the union movement quickly began posting improbable and downright ridiculous ways to try and undermine nuclear power.\n\nDeformed pets, references to The Simpsons, toxic spills causing three-eyed fish and images suggesting the sites might be located near iconic natural wonders such as Victoria's Twelve Apostles were just some of the immature games being played by parliamentarians.\n\nI did say yesterday that the mother of all scare campaigns would soon start but I didn't think it would be quite this pathetic.\n\nThe Australian Union movement suggested the family dog would become deformed as a result of Peter Dutton's nuclear power proposal\n\nVictorian Premier Jacinta Allan's team produced this Simpsons-inspired meme - with Ms Allan slamming nuclear power as 'toxic'\n\nIt isn't as though there aren't serious problems with Dutton's announcement - I'll come to those shortly.\n\nVictoria's new premier Jacinta Allan, no less, posted mocked up images of three-eyed cartoon fish leaping out of the water in Gippsland, writing: 'The Liberal Party want a toxic and expensive nuclear reactor in Gippsland.'\n\nAnthony Albanese's contribution wasn't much better: 'Instead of Snow White and the Seven Dwarves, this is Peter Dutton and the seven nuclear reactors'.\n\nI wonder how long it took the PM's taxpayer funded team of 11 media advisers to come up with that one. Or did Albo proudly think it up all on his own?\n\nSeizing upon The Simpsons theme, Victorian federal MP Josh Burns tweeted images of nuclear reactors with the Liberal Party logo on them, writing 'under Peter Dutton Australians will glow green'.\n\nClever stuff.\n\nAt 62 years of age Labor MP for the Victorian seat of Corangamite, Libby Cocker, wasn't too mature to take a similar dig, days before Dutton's announcement.\n\nThe federal Victorian MP riffed off the 'where the bloody hell are you' tourism campaign of yesteryear spearheaded by Lara Bingle.\n\nCocker, who was a school teacher before entering politics, tweeted a mock up of a bikini-clad Bingle standing in front of the 12 Apostles on the Victorian coastline with three nuclear reactors billowing smoke behind her.\n\nThere really must be something in the water in Victoria - before the nuclear waste arrives as is being alleged.\n\nThe Simpsons references were running thick and fast\n\nThe Australian Manufacturing Workers Union shared an image of a Chernobyl-style dystopia\n\nThe Australian Union movements official X page posted an image of a deformed something or another, it was hard to tell, above the headline 'this will be your family dog'.\n\nScare campaigns are rarely rooted in accuracy, and that is a bipartisan problem. But they are rarely this childish in nature.\n\nIt will be interesting to see if these callow MPs and vested interests continue to act this way, or sharpen up their attacks in the weeks and months ahead.\n\nHistory tells us that scare campaigns work, especially against big bold policy ideas raised by Oppositions. But do they work when they are this low brow?\n\nBefore Dutton revealed where the reactors would be placed, Labor MP Libby Coker shared this meme, inspired by Lara Bingle's famous Tourism Australia ad\n\nAs mentioned earlier on, if anyone wants to seriously critique Dutton's policy there is plenty to dig into without having to resort to juvenile antics.\n\nFor example, Dutton says he plans to use existing coal fired power sites and the government will pay for and own the operations. But most of the private owners of these sites have already ruled out relinquishing them to a Coalition government, and they weren't consulted before the policy was announced.\n\nMost of the sites Dutton has announced are in states that have legislatively banned nuclear power, and a number of these Premiers have already ruled out changing that.\n\nRead MoreLIVE How nuclear power plant neighbours could be in for a cash windfall under Dutton's new energy plan\n\nThe policy hasn't been costed, much less modelled to ascertain what taxpayers might be up for if or when construction was to begin.\n\nWe don't even know who the Coalition engaged to produce this policy. Is it rooted in any scholarly research beyond a superficial thought bubble announcement?\n\nWe're also still in the dark about which types of nuclear reactors the Opposition is proposing to build: the new smaller modules or the more established larger varieties used in other parts of the world? It is a pretty basic choice not to be included in a major policy announcement.\n\nSo yes, there are serious questions for serious people to raise requiring serious answers before Team Dutton can expect Australians to get behind his proposal.\n\nUnfortunately the Labor government and its union mates seem largely incapable of reaching high and properly challenging the policy announcement.\n\nInstead they choose to play in the sandpit on social media.\n\nNo wonder the public has such a dim view of the political class.", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": a commitment to higher energy bills for NSW households and more climate pollution.\n\nToday's announcement of an uncosted plan from the Federal Coalition to build nuclear reactors at Liddell power station in the Hunter Valley and Mount Piper power station near Lithgow is a dangerous distraction from the renewable energy transition underway in NSW.\n\nInternational experience shows that it takes up to twenty years to build nuclear reactors, meaning that ageing coal fired power plants would continue to emit dangerous climate pollution for years to come.\n\nStatements attributable to NCC Chief generation and storage, not with a nuclear fantasy.\n\n\"Renewable energy is the cheapest and most affordable form of energy, and NSW needs to get on with the job of scaling it up to deliver a sustainable future and sound economic growth prospects for our state.\"\n\nStatement ends\n\n/Public Release. {"uri": "8185109195", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "10:24:53", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T10:24:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T10:23:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "url": "https://www.miragenews.com/australias-energy-future-1259167/", "title": "Australia's Energy Future", "body": "Every Australian deserves and should expect access to cheaper, cleaner and consistent electricity. But under Labor, this isn't happening.\n\nRight now, in households and businesses around the country, Labor's expensive renewables-only approach is failing.\n\nThe Government is now talking about a 65 to 75 per cent emissions reduction target by 2035, but won't release modelling and won't tell us how much higher power prices will go up.\n\nPower bills have already increased by up to $1,000 for many Australians, when they were promised a $275 cut. And Labor's climate target of 43% emissions reduction by 2030 has become unachievable.\n\nThe Coalition believes Australia must have a balanced energy mix to deliver cheaper, cleaner and consistent 24/7 electricity. 90 per cent of baseload electricity, predominantly coal fired power stations, is coming to the end of life over the next decade.\n\nNuclear energy for Australia is an idea whose time has come.\n\nToday, we are announcing that a future Federal Coalition Government will introduce zero-emissions nuclear energy in Australia, which has proven to get electricity prices and emissions down all over the world, to work in partnership with renewable energy and gas as part of a balanced energy mix.\n\nAnd today, we announce seven locations, located at a power station that has closed or is scheduled to close, where we propose to build zero-emissions nuclear power plants:\n\nLiddell Power Station, New South WalesMount Piper Power Station, New South WalesLoy Yang Power Stations, VictoriaTarong Power Station, QueenslandCallide Power Station, QueenslandNorthern Power Station, South Australia (SMR only)Muja Power Station, Western Australia (SMR only)\n\nEach of these locations offer important technical attributes needed for a zero-emissions nuclear plant, including cooling water capacity and transmission infrastructure, that is, we can use the existing poles and wires, along with a local community which has a skilled workforce.\n\nA key advantage of modern zero-emissions nuclear plants is they can be plugged into existing grids. This means they can effectively replace retired or retiring coal plants and avoid much of the new spending needed for Labor's 'renewables-only' system, including new transmission poles and wires. All of which will be passed on in the form of higher bills.\n\nLabor's approach requires imposing 58 million solar panels, 3,500 new industrial wind turbines, and up to 28,000 kilometres of new transmission lines across the country. Energy experts have warned the cost of Labor's rollout will be between $1.2 trillion and $1.5 trillion.\n\nNo country in the world relies solely on solar and wind as Labor is proposing. By contrast, there are 32 countries operating zero-emissions nuclear plants. Another 50 countries are looking to do so.\n\nOf the world's 20 largest economies, Australia is the only one not using nuclear energy, or moving towards using it.\n\nOur plan will deliver a net-zero electricity grid by 2050 and a strong and resilient economy. It will set our country up for decades to come.\n\nAt the front of this next wave of growth will be those communities which host zero-emissions nuclear plants. Not only will local communities benefit from high paying, multi-generational jobs but communities will be empowered to maximise the benefits from hosting an asset of national importance by way of:\n\nA multi-billion dollar facility guaranteeing high-paying jobs for generations to come;An integrated economic development zone to attract manufacturing, value-add and high-tech industry; andA regional deal unlocking investment in modern infrastructure, services and community priorities.\n\nA Community Partnership will be formed in each host community, consisting of experienced local representatives, as the focal point for community engagement and to play an important role in planning the future of the region.\n\nThis community engagement process will occur alongside a comprehensive site study including detailed technical and economic assessments.\n\nA Federal Coalition Government will initially develop two establishment projects using either small modular reactors or modern larger plants such as the AP1000 or APR1400. They will start producing electricity by 2035 (with small modular reactors) or 2037 (if modern larger plants are found to be the best option).\n\nThe Australian Government will own these assets, but form partnerships with experienced nuclear companies to build and operate them.\n\nAustralia is fast running out of energy. The way of life for everyday Australians and the cost of doing business in Australia is already in jeopardy and it is only going to get worse under Labor's expensive all-eggs-in-one-basket 'renewables-only' policy.\n\nWe know the Prime Minister and his Government will mount the mother-of-all scare campaigns on zero-emissions nuclear energy.\n\nBut we believe Australians are up for this discussion and are open-minded about including zero-emissions nuclear technology as part of a balanced energy mix.\n\nIf you are serious about meeting our net zero by 2050 emissions commitments, then you must include zero-emission nuclear as part of your energy mix. Zero-emission nuclear power plants produce no air pollution or carbon emissions. For example, a 1.1 GW AP-1000 reactor cuts approximately seven million metric tonnes of CO2 emissions, equivalent to removing 1.5 million cars from the road.\n\nA zero-emissions nuclear power plant will be a national asset delivering cheaper, cleaner and consistent energy for 80 years. Getting started now on establishing a civil nuclear programme is the right decision for you, your children and your grandchildren.\n\nFrom today, we will be speaking right across the country on the merits of our plan.\n\nOur plan is bold, visionary and what Australians need to secure our energy and economic future.\n\nFor more information visit australianeedsnuclear.org.au\n\n/Public Release.
